#  file: fsfProjectInfo2010-May.txt
#  package: fsfRawData
#  description of file/package:
#
#  This package includes raw data files from our database of Free Software 
#  Foundation project information generated from the list of projects gathered 
#  in 2010-May
#
#  Scripts & raw data available at http://flossmole.org
#  Scripts written by Megan Squire and contributed to the FLOSSmole project
#
#  This data is free and available for any use (after all we just spidered it ;)
#  We do however request that those using the data in any published form provide 
#  a citation to: FLOSSmole Project (2004-2010) 
#  The project is available at: http://flossmole.org
#  
#  SELECT proj_num, proj_unixname, date_collected, datasource_id, url, real_url, desc_short, desc_long, user_level 
#  FROM fsf_projects 
#  WHERE datasource_id=221 
#  ORDER BY proj_num
#
#  datasource_id = 221 is the 2010-May collection from FSF.
proj_num	proj_unixname	date_collected	datasource_id	url	real_url	desc_short	desc_long	user_level
2	zynaddsubfx	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zynaddsubfx	http://zynaddsubfx.sourceforge.net/	Free implementation of a sound synthesizer	ZynAddSubFX is a free software implementation of a\nsoftware synthesizer. It can imitate countless numbers of instruments,\nfrom some commonly heard from expensive hardware to interesting sounds\nthat you'll boost to an amazing universe of sounds.\n	
3	zthread	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zthread	http://zthread.sourceforge.net/	Object-oriented threading and synchronization library	ZThread is an advanced object-oriented threading\nand synchronization library, implemented in C++. It provides an\nexcellent and powerful abstraction from native threads. It includes\ninterruptable thread objects and several other synchronization control\nobjects and lets you safely terminate threads without the complications\nof using cancellation handlers or other similar constructs.\n	
4	zsh	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zsh	http://www.zsh.org/	Shell resembling the Korn shell	'Zsh' is a *NIX command interpreter (shell) which\nof all the standard shells most resembles the Korn shell (ksh). It\nincludes enhancements of many types, notably in the command-line\neditor, options for customising its behaviour, filename globbing,\nfeatures to make C-shell (csh) users feel more at home and extra\nfeatures drawn from tcsh.\n	
5	zorp	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zorp	http://www.balabit.com/products/zorp_gpl/	Proxy firewall suite	Zorp is a proxy firewall suite. Its core framework\nallows the administrator to finetune proxy decisions (with its\nbuilt-in script language), and fully analyze complex protocols\n(including SSH with several forwarded TCP connections, or SSL with an\nembedded POP3 protocol). FTP, HTTP, finger, whois, and SSL protocols\nare fully supported with an application-level gateway. Zorp aims for\ncompliance with Common Criteria/Application-level Firewall Protection\nProfile for Medium Robustness Enviroment.\n	
6	zope	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zope	http://www.zope.org/	Web application server	Zope is a web application platform used for\nbuilding high-performance, dynamic web sites. It contains a powerful\nand simple scripting object model and high-performance, integrated\nobject database.\n	
7	zoidberg	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zoidberg	http://zoidberg.student.utwente.nl/	Shell written, configured, and operated entirely in Perl	A modular Perl shell written, configured, and\noperated entirely in Perl. It aspires to be a fully operational login\nshell with all the features one normally expects. But it also gives\ndirect access to Perl objects and data structures from the command\nline, and allows you to run Perl code within the scope of your command\nline.\n	
8	zoem	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zoem	http://micans.org/zoem/	General purpose macro language	Zoem is a general purpose macro/programming\nlanguage. It supports inside-out evaluation, dictionary stacks,\narithmetic evaluation, iteration, regular expressions,\nmultidimensional data storage, comprehensive IO, control operators,\nsystem commands, and more.\n\n<P>One specific use is its support for creating small mark-up\nlanguages that map to+different devices. It has character filtering\ncapabilities tailored to this application. Two such languages come\npackaged with zoem; one for creating manual pages that can be output\neither in troff or in cross-linked HTML, the other for creating FAQs\nagain in either troff or HTML output.\n	
9	zmixer	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zmixer	http://zwin.org/projects/zmixer/	Simple volume control	'zmixer' is a volume control that tries to be\nminimalistic yet useful. It uses the Advanced Linux Sound Architecture\n(ALSA) interface.\n	
10	zlib	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zlib	http://www.gzip.org/zlib/	Data compression library	A free, lossless data compression lib for use on\nvirtually any computer hardware and operating system. The zlib data\nformat is itself portable across platforms. The compression method\ncurrently used in zlib never expands the data. Zlib's memory footprint\nis also independent of the input data by more than a few bytes and can\nbe reduced (at some cost in compression).\n	
11	ziproxy	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ziproxy	http://ziproxy.sourceforge.net/	Proxy that gzips files and reduces image size	'ziproxy' is a forwarding (non-caching) proxy that\ngzips text and HTML files, and reduces the size of images by\nconverting them to low quality JPEGs. It is intended to increase the\nspeed for dial-up Internet connections. Most browsers support gzipped\ncontent, so Web pages appear as normal, but as they are only a\nfraction of their original page size, pages are much quicker to\nload. Even for browsers that don't support it, hints how to overcome\nit using SSH port forwarding are included. \n\n<P>Images are on average one third smaller with only marginal visible\nimage quality loss. It should be used with inetd/xinetd, but if you\ncan't use them, a simple replacement "netd" is provided\n	
12	zinf	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zinf	http://www.zinf.org/	Cross-platform audio player	Zinf is an extensible, cross-platform audio player\nformerly known as Free Amp. As per the zinf web site "Zinf is based on\nthe FreeAmp source code. However, AMP is a trademark of PlayMedia\nSystems, Inc., and therefore the original name of the project cannot\nbe used any longer. On this website the old project will be referred\nto as FreeA*p."\n\nZinf features an optimized version of the GPLed Xing MPEG\ndecoder, a powerful music browser and playlist editor, and a built in\ndownload manager which supports downloading files from sites using the\nRMP (RealJukebox) download process, and a number of the most common\nfeatures users have come to expect in a clean, easy to use interface,\nincluding:	
13	zina	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zina	http://www.pancake.org/zina.html	GUI tool for audio	Zina is a graphical interface to your MP3\ncollection, a personal jukebox, and an MP3/Ogg/WAV streamer. It has\ncustom, session, and random playlists, can skip tracks as desired, and\ncan search by artist, title, or song. It can also be run as a Postnuke\nmodule.\n	
14	zim	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zim	http://zoidberg.student.utwente.nl/zim/	A desktop wiki.	Zim is a WYSIWYG text editor written in Gtk2-Perl\nIt aims to bring the concept of a wiki to your\ndesktop. Every page is saved as a text file with wiki\nmarkup. Pages can contain links to other pages,\nand are saved automatically. Creating a new page\nis as easy as linking to a non-existing page. This\ntool is intended to keep track of TODO lists or\nto serve as a personal scratch book.\n	
15	zile	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zile	http://www.gnu.org/software/zile/	An Emacs clone.	Zile is a small, fast, and powerful Emacs clone. It is useful for small footprint installations (e.g. on floppy disk) or quick editing sessions.  Festures include:\n<ul>\n<li>Small.	Intermediate
16	zgv	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zgv	http://www.svgalib.org/rus/zgv/	Picture viewer for VGA/SVGA	'zgv' is a full-featured, svgalib-based picture\nviewer for VGA/SVGA displays which supports most popular formats. It\nprovides a file selector with thumbnails to select file(s) to view,\nand allows panning and fit-to-screen methods of viewing, slideshows,\nscaling, gamma adjustment, etc.\n	
17	zerotools	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zerotools	http://koltsoff.com/pub/zerotools	Tools to aid compression of virtual machine disks with Linux virtual machines.	Zerotools are a set of tools to aid keeping virtual disks clean by filling binary zero to those regions which are no longer in "use". This is done on-the-fly or manually, depending on which tool suits the needs best. The tools do not compete with other programs that rewrite removed files in order to make their restoration close to impossible. Zerotools are mostly useful for people who compress or archive virtual machines constantly. The tools are run inside the virtualized Linux system and are distribution-agnostic.	
18	zeppoo	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zeppoo	http://www.zeppoo.net	Software to detect if a rootkit is installed on your system.	Zeppoo allows you to detect rootkits on the i386\narchitecture under Linux by using /dev/kmem and\n/dev/mem. It can also detect hidden tasks,\nmodules, syscalls, some corrupted symbols, and\nhidden connections. Anti-Rootkits which don't use\nthese methods can be fooled easily.\n	
19	zenslideshow	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zenslideshow	http://www.zen-slideshow.com	Is a php slideshow application for web sites	Zen-slideshow is a free software php slideshow application for web sites. Zen-slideshow was designed to provide the web developer with a configurable slideshow application. The web developer decides: <br>\n<ul>\n<li>Where zen-slideshow will be installed.</li>\n<li>Where is the folder which will contain the images for the slideshow.</li>\n<li>What is the maximum width and height for the images in the slide show.</li>\n<li>Will there be thumbnails.</li>\n<li>What is the maximum width and height of the thumbnails.</li>\n<li>Will their be manual slideshow navigatioin controls. </li>\n<li>Will their be auto slideshow controls.</li>\n<li>Will there be a auto slideshow delay controls.</li>\n<li>What will be the auto slideshow delay contorl options.</li>\n<li>Will the slideshow be its own web page or will it be included in another web page.</li>\n<li>How the slide show will look</li>\n</ul>\n Once installed, the content for zen-slideshow is changed by adding and deleting images in the image folder.\n	
20	zenity	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zenity	http://cvs.gnome.org/bonsai/rview.cgi?cvsroot=/cvs/gnome&amp;dir=zenity	Displays Gtk+ dialog boxes from the command line or shell scripts	Zenity lets you display Gtk+ dialog boxes from the\ncommand line and through shell scripts. It is similar to gdialog, but\nis intended to be saner. It comes from the same family as dialog,\nXdialog, and cdialog, but it surpasses those projects by having a\ncooler name.\n	
21	zebra	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zebra	http://www.zebra.org/	Implementation of routing protocols	Zebra is a multi-server routing protocol that\nprovides TCP/IP based routing protocols. It's meant to be used as a\nroute server and router reflector. Not just a toolkit, it provides\nfull routing power under a new architecture. The user can dynamically\nchange configuration and use command line completion and history from\nthe terminal interface.\n\nThe programs supports:	
22	zebedee	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zebedee	http://www.winton.org.uk/zebedee/	Secure tunnel for TCP/IP or UDP data transfer	Zebedee establishes an encrypted, compressed\ntunnel for TCP/IP or UDP data transfer between two systems. This\nprotects telnet, ftp and X traffic from snooping. It has a small\nfootprint, low wire protocol overhead, and gives significant traffic\nreduction by the use of compression.\n	
23	zdisk	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zdisk	http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/Linux/system/recovery/	Creates a boot/rescue floppy or CD	Zdisk lets you have a kernel and a rescue system\non one floppy. The programs copies a kernel of your choice to a floppy\nand then adds a rescue system to the same floppy (the kernel can't be\nbigger than 975 Kb on a floppy, although it can be bigger on a\nCD). Zdisk has almost the same rescue system as ramf-86, except\nramf-86 comes with a kernel.\n	
24	zapping	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/zapping	http://zapping.sourceforge.net/	A TV viewer program for GNOME.	Zapping is a TV viewer for GNOME that supports Video4Linux, Video4Linux2, and XVideo. It's extensible through plugins.	
25	z2html	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/z2html	http://project.departure.dk/zdl.html	Converts files in the Z document language to HTML	'z2html' translates files written in the free Z\nDocument Language to compliant XHTML 1.1. It is both SGML and\nXML-compliant.\n	
26	yuv4mpeg	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yuv4mpeg	http://frodo.dyn.gno.org/~brettk/yuv4mpeg/	Let users creat yuv4mpeg filters in Perl	'yuv4mpeg' is a Perl module which provides access\nto the yuv4mpeg library, which is part of mjpegtools.  The library\nprovides functions for reading/writing stream and frame header\ninformation, as well as the frame data itself. Also, the Perl bindings\nhave been augmented with some fast data-access methods to make it\nquick and easy to pull out the raw frame data in various forms.  The\nmodule is meant to lets users create yuv4mpeg filters in Perl.\n	
27	yum-repo-sync	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yum-repo-sync	http://www.dotsharp.com.br/programas/yum-repo-sync.html	A script for creating a local repository for yum.	This shell script automatically downloads \nand synchronizes a Fedora Core repository with a local yum \nrepository. There are already configurations for FC3, FC4, \nFC5, and FC6 which only need to be activated. \n	
28	yudit	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yudit	http://www.yudit.org/	Unicode text editor for the X Window System	Yudit is a unicode text editor for the X Window\nSystem. It can do True Type font rendering, printing, transliterated\nkeyboard input, and handwriting recognition with no dependencies on \nexternal engines. Its conversion utilities can convert text between\nvarious encodings. Keyboard input maps can also act like text\nconverters for instant transliterations of your text. There is no need\nfor a pre-installed multi-lingual environment. The menus are available\nin many languages.\n\nThe program supports handwriting recognition and right-to-left\nwriting, and has built-in printing support and direct TrueType\nsupport. You can display and print your text in a combination of\nTrueType and X11 fonts.	
29	ytree	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ytree	http://www.han.de/~werner/ytree.html	File manager with an xtree-like interface	'ytree' is a file manager that t works under\nterminals using ncurses. It supports external programs to view/edit\nfiles. It is configurable, supports different architectures, if\navailable it has colors, and has an internal hex viewer and editor. It\nis designed with xtree's interface but *nix semantics. It is fast,\nlight, and can be compiled with x-curses.\n	
30	ytalk	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ytalk	http://www.impul.se/ytalk/	Multi-user chat program	'Ytalk' is a multi-user talk program that works like\nthe UNIX talk program but allows for multiple connections and shell\nsessions inside the talk window. It is compatible with older UNIX talk\nclients and daemons. You can save any side of the current conversion\nand define aliases for addresses or hostnames.\n\nYTalk connects to the talk daemon on each user's host and determines\nif that user has left an invitation for you to call. If not, YTalk\nleaves an invitation for him and tells his talk daemon to send an\nannouncement to his screen. There is no dedicated YTalk daemon.	
31	ysmicq	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ysmicq	http://ysmv7.sourceforge.net	An easy ICQ console client.	YSM (You Sick Me) v7 is an ICQ console client.  It\nwas originally meant to run in GNU/Linux, but it has\nbeen successfully tested in other systems. The client requires no \nextra libraries, and is written in the C language. YSM\nis based on the last ICQ protocol version, v7/8. \n	
32	ypserv	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ypserv	http://www.linux-nis.org/nis/ypserv/	Simple network lookup service	The Network Information Service (NIS) (formerly\nknown as Sun Yellow Pages (YP)) provides a simple network lookup\nservice consisting of databases and processes. The functionality of\nthe two remains the same, only the name has changed. It provides\ninformation, that has to be known throughout the network, to all\nmachines on the network.\n	
33	youhp3	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/youhp3	http://www.youpee.org/	HTML preprocessor	Youhp3 (Youpee's One Unlimited HTML PreProcessor)\nis an HTML preprocessor that allows you to embed code of any script\nlanguage, as well as calling any external program to generate text\nfiles. It is specifically designed to work with HTML/XML documents,\nand provide traditional features, such as define, include, macro,\nconditional tests, and loop.\n	
34	yhttpd	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yhttpd	http://www.yhttpd.org	Lightweight Web server	'yhttpd' is an XML-configurable, light, very\nportable, multi-platform Web server written in C++ and a small subset\nof C. It runs on all POSIX compatible operating systems and uses the\nGNU GCC C++ compiler from 3.1 and up with pthreads enabled. It is\nbased on the yChat socket and thread engines.\n	
35	ygl	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ygl	http://www.thp.uni-duisburg.de/Ygl/ReadMe.html	2D graphics library	Ygl is a two dimensional grpahics programs with a\nvariety of standard X11 routines. Included are most 2D graphics\nroutines, a queue device routine, some query routines,\ndoublebuffering, RGB mode with arbitrary visuals and most window\nattribute routines.\n	
36	yelp	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yelp		Gnome help browser	Help browser for GNOME 2.0 which supports docbook\ndocuments, info and man.\n	
37	yeemp	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yeemp	http://deekoo.net/technocracy/yeemp/	Decentralized instant messaging	'yeemp' is a decentralized instant messaging\nsystem. It uses GPG over SSL for encryption, and UTF-8 to enable\nnon-Latin text to be transferred. The clients include support for\nJapanese, Cyrillic, and Ogham input, as well as direct UTF-8. Yeemp\nincludes a command-line client, an X client, a server, and a simple\nWeb-based client. The clients can also use the AIM and ICQ protocols.\n	
38	yed	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yed	http://yed.sourceforge.net	Library of modules for object-oriented programming	Yed is a C software library made of modules\n(objects) instanceable according to the main paradigms of Object\nOriented Programming: incapsulation and data hiding. The library\ncontains objects that handle XML files, FTP connections, filesystem\noperations, etc. Yed acts only at the C compiler preprocessing level,\nusing particular macros; therefore, using Yed objects is transparent\nto the compiler, so users do not have to develop additional\n"translation" tools that have to be run before compiling.\n	
39	yaws	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yaws	http://yaws.hyber.org/	Light-weight, threaded Web server	'yaws' is a high performance, light-weight,\nthreaded HTTP 1.1 Web server targeted for the generation of dynamic\ncontent. It is written in Erlang, and the server side dynamic content\nis generated by Erlang code embedded in the HTML code. It is able to\nship several thousands of dynamically generated pages per second.\n	
40	yawk	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yawk	http://www.awk-scripting.de/cgi/wiki.cgi/yawk/00-WikiIndex	Wiki clone written in gawk	'yawk' is a wiki clone written in gawk. It supports\nthe usual text styles, lists, and tables. Additional and optional\nfeatures are formatting with stylesheet classes, file uploads, and a\nframed user interface mode. It works on plain text files and does not\nrequire a database.\n	
41	yavipin	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yavipin	http://yavipin.sourceforge.net/	Secure tunnel	Yavipind is a secure tunnel (2 peers securely\nforwarding packets toward each other). It forwards any kind of packet\n(IPv4, IPv6, or other) sent over the virtual point-to-point device\n(e.g., tun0). It runs in Linux userspace (no need to recompile the\nkernel). Yavipin is virtual, so you can apply any tool designed for\nthe network device.\n\n<P>Packet overheard is small (26 bytes) and packets can be compressed\nusing gzip. The tunnel can be established over NAT since all packets\nin a tunnel are sent over a single UDP/IPv4 connection. If one peer\nbecomes unreachable, it is detected; if a peer deliberately stops, it\nimmediately notifies the other peer.\n\n<P>Packages are encrytpted with blowfish. The program has strict\nanti-replay rules and no packet can be accepted twice. Traffic older\nthan a given delay (default 10 min) can't be decrypted since the keys\nare periodically renewed and securely erased.\n	
42	yasss	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yasss	http://moritz.faui2k3.org/en/yasss	A program that solves and generates Sudokus from the command line and curses.	YasSS (Yet another (simple|stupid) Sudoku Solver) is a Sudoku solver for the command line. It solves any Sudoku puzzle and generates Sudoku puzzles. It can calculate the number of solutions, print a difficulty rating, and generate a canonical form for a puzzle. It also provides a curses interface for playing Sudoku. 	
43	yassl	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yassl	http://yassl.com/	BuildS security functionality into applications and devices	The yaSSL Library version 0.9.9 includes the following:\n<pre>\n    * SSL version 3 and TLS version 1 (client and server)\n    * OpenSSL compatibility layer\n    * MySQL integration\n    * Initial stunnel integration\n    * MD5, SHA-1, HMAC, DES, 3DES, AES, ARC4, RSA, DSS, and DH\n    * Simple API\n    * Interchangeable crypto and certificate libraries\n    * PEM and DER certificate support\n\n</pre>   \n	
44	yasm	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yasm	http://www.tortall.net/projects/yasm/	A rewrite of the NASM assembler with additional support (64-bit, Mach-O, etc.)	The Yasm Modular Assembler accepts both NASM and GAS syntax; supports x86 and AMD64 instructions; and outputs binary, ELF32, ELF64, 32 and 64-bit Mach-O, RDOFF2, COFF, Win32, and Win64 object formats.	
45	yard	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yard	http://www.linuxlots.com/~fawcett/yard/index.html	Scripts for creating rescue disks	Yard is a suite of Perl scripts for creating\nrescue disks for GNU/Linux. A rescue disk is a self-contained kernel\nand filesystem on a floppy, usually used when you can't (or don't want\nto) boot off your hard disk, that contains utilities for diagnosing\nand manipulating hard disks and filesystems. Yard itself is not a\nrescue disk or boot disk; it is a tool for creating one. The user must\ndo a certain amount of file choosing to make it work, but the result\nis a customized rescue disk that is complete, useful, and up-to-date.\n\nYard does not use special, minimal files to make everything fit in\na small filesystem. Instead, it uses standard files from your hard\ndisk installation, so you can use as many diskettes as you need\n(usually 2-3, since everything is compressed)\n	
46	yappa-ng	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yappa-ng	http://www.zirkon.at/zirkon/scripts/yappa-ng/yappa-ng_main_eng.html	Manages an online photo gallery	'yappa-ng' is an easy to use online PHP photo\ngallery. It has a comfortable and elaborate album-oriented photo album\nadministration Web interface. Each picture can be viewed in many\ndifferent sizes with resizing created automatically on the fly. \n\n<P>It has complete user selectable language support, and supports\npassword protected albums, hit counters for albums and images, album\ninfo, image captions, gallery overview, different themes, and a 'Top\n10 images' ranking system for each photo album. It does not need a\ndatabase. The package has been translated into 13 languages.\n	
47	yapbib	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yapbib	http://www.cs.jhu.edu/~jcorso/yapbib	Manages a set of literature references	"Your Annotated Persional Bibliography" lets you\nmaintain and store a set of literature references, organize,\nmanipulate, take notes on, and categorize them. It even lets you\nexport to Bibtex files for inclusion into articles you write. The\ndatabase is in ASCII form that is easily read into other programs or\nmodified by hand. Yapbib also stores a cached copy of each article in\nPDF format.\n	
48	yam	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yam	http://dag.wieers.com/home-made/yam/	A tool that builds a local RPM repository from ISO files and RPM packages.	Yam builds a local APT/Yum RPM repository from\nlocal ISO files, downloaded updates, and extra\npackages from RHN (Red Hat Network) and 3rd party\nrepositories. It takes care of setting up the ISO files,\ndownloading the RPMs, configuring HTTP access, and\nproviding PXE/TFTP resources for remote installations.\nIt was primarily intended for doing remote network\ninstallations of various distributions from a\nlaptop without the need for CD media or floppies,\nbut is equally suitable for an organization's\ncentralized update server.\n	
49	yagtd	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yagtd	https://gna.org/projects/yagtd/	A utility designed to make the management of your to-do list quick and easy.	yaGTD is a very simple utility designed to make\nthe management of your to-do list quick and easy.\nIt incorporates major features from Allen's\nGetting Things Done philosophy and a notion of\nurgency and importance preached by Stephen Covey\nin his Seven Habits of Highly Effective People book.\n	
50	yagg	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/yagg	http://yagg.sourceforge.net/	Generates all strings of a user-specified length.	'yagg' generates all strings of a user-specified\nlength. The YACC-like language grammar file provides the grammar\nproductions for string generation and optional action blocks that\nperform context-sensitive checks in order to limit the generated\nstrings. The LEX-like terminal generator file provides specifications\nthat tell the program how to generate strings for terminals in the\ngrammar.\n\n<P>If you already have a YACC or Bison parser file, you need only to\nadd "unaction" blocks to allow the recursive generator to undo the\nside effects of the action blocks. If you already have a LEX or FLEX\nlexer input file, you need only remove extraneous code and replace any\nregular expressions with one of the terminal generator specifications.\n

63	xtide	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/xtide	http://www.flaterco.com/xtide/index.html	Tide clock and tide predictor	XTide provides tide and current predictions in a\nvariety of formats. It can generate graphs, text listings, and\ncalendars, or put a tide clock on your desktop. Xtide works through\nthree separate programs: the X Windows interface (xtide), the\nnon-interactive or command line interface (tide), and the web\ninterface (xttpd).\n\n<P>XTide uses the same algorithm to predict tides as the National\nOcean Service in the U.S. It is much more accurate than a simple tide\nclock from a novelty store. However, to predict tides accurately you\nalso need special data for every location for which you want to\npredict tides.  XTide reads this data from harmonics files that you\nmust get from Bob Kenney's web site,\nhttp://bel-marduk.unh.edu/xtide/files.html.\n\n<P>XTide's predictions are only as good as the available harmonics\ndata.  Due to issues of data availability and of compatibility with\nnon-U.S. tide systems, predictions for U.S. locations tend to be much\nbetter than for locations outside of the U.S.\n

The known strokes actions and there corresponding actions are\ndefined in the ${HOME}/.xstrokerc file described below.\n\nThe xstroke configuration file, (${HOME}/.xstrokerc), defines strokes\nand actions to be performed when the stroke is entered. Currently, the\nonly supported action is to send a KeyPress and KeyRelease event to\nthe currently focused window.\n\n<p>The default alphabet in xstrokerc is an original alphabet. Many\nstrokes are similar to the strokes in the program xscribble, although\nxstroke does not have any shift modes, (capitals, num-shift,\npunc-shift, etc). Instead, all letters, numbers, and punctuation are\ndefined in a single alphabet.\n

72	xsh	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/xsh	http://xsh.sourceforge.net/	XML editing tool	XSH is an XML editing tool/programming language\nthat can be used either interactively or for batch-mode XML\nprocessing. It may be used to query and modify XML documents. XPath\nexpressions are used to select parts of XML document to be\nprocessed. Both the system shell and Perl are accessible from XSH in a\nvery natural way. XSH uses XML::LibXML bindings of gnome-xml2 library\nin the background level.\n\n<P>Features include (among others) the ability to work with multiple\nDOM trees at once, filesystem-like navigation within the DOM tree\nusing XPATH, the ability to copy/move nodes within a DOM tree or\nbetween two DOM trees, a 'while' statement, and a Perl-like 'foreach'\nstatement that lets you iterate commands over a list of strings or\nnodes.\n	
73	xsd	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/xsd	http://codesynthesis.com/products/xsd/	XML Schema to C++ translator	'xsd' is a W3C XML Schema to C++ translator. It\ngenerates a vocabulary-specific, statically-typed C++ mapping (also\ncalled binding) from XML Schema definitions. The mapping consists of\ndata types that represent the given vocabulary, a set of parsing\nfunctions that convert XML instance documents to a tree-like in-memory\ndata structure, and a set of serialization functions that convert the\nin-memory representation back to XML. \n\n<P>'xsd' features C++ standard library-based language mapping,\nconfigurable base character type (char/wchar_t), support for all XML\nSchema built-in types, custom Schema to C++ namespace mapping,\nplatform-independent generated code, and more.\n	
74	xscreensaver	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/xscreensaver	http://www.jwz.org/xscreensaver/	Screen saver and locker for the X Window System	Once the keyboard and mouse have been idle for a\nperiod, xscreensaver runs a randomly chosen graphics demo. It turns\noff as soon as there is any mouse or keyboard activity. It can also\nlock the screen immediately, after a longer idle period, or on\ndemand. The package has two parts: xscreensaver itself, which detects\nidleness and does locking; and the graphics demos that it launches.\n\nAny X program that can draw on the root window can be used with\nxscreensaver. The xscreensaver daemon detects when the user is idle,\nlocking, and checking passwords and all the other book-keeping; all\nthe other programs need to do is draw. New graphics hacks are easier\nto install than with the combination of the xlock and xautolock\nprograms becuase you needn't recompile or re-run xscreensaver to add a\nnew display mode; you just change a config file.\n

80	xps	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/xps	http://motif-pstree.sourceforge.net/	Displays Unix processes as a tree under X	'xps' dynamically displays in an X Window the Unix\nprocesses as a tree, the roots on the left and the leaf processes on\nthe right. Within each level, processes are grouped so that those with\nthe same parent process id are grouped together (older processes\nnearer the top). The overall tree display uses diagonal lines; xps\ntries to effectively use the full 2-dimensional area of the screen by\nbalancing levels and centering the children of a node between their\nparent.\n\nThe status of each process or user can be indicated by a\ncolor. Process selection can be made per user, for all users, or\nthrough a regular expression pattern. A process can be selected to\nshow ps information or to send the process a signal. users can click\non a process to get more information (via ps) about it, send it a a\nsignal, or set its priority.

It works in much the same way as sed,\nawk, diff, patch, etc do for plain text files. It can be used for\nworking with many XML documents at the *NIX command prompt as well as\nfor automated XML processing with shell scripts.\n\nAmong other features, 'xmlstarlet' can:\n<pre>\n\t-Check or validate XML files \n\t-Calculate the values of XPath expressions on XML files \n\t-Search XML files for matches to given XPath expressions\n\t-Apply XSLT stylesheets to XML documents \n\t-Query, modify, format, or edit XML documents \n\t-Fetch XML documents using http:// or ftp:// \n\t-Browse the tree structure of XML documents \n\t-Include one XML document into another using XInclude\n\t-Escape/unescape special XML characters in input text\n\t-Print a directory as an XML document\n\t-Convert XML into PYX format and vice versa\n</pre>\n

116	xlit	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/xlit	http://billposer.org/Software/xlit.html	Converts text from one writing system into another.	Xlit converts text from one writing system into another. It allows the user to define a transliteration simply by typing the input strings in one window and the strings to which they are to be mapped in another. Xlit can also use external programs such as sed and iconv to perform the transliteration and can load plugins written in Tcl. It can be run without the GUI.\nXlit also provides some advanced facilities not found in typical transliteration and encoding conversion programs. It is often necessary to restrict transliteration to particular parts of the text. xlit understands a variety of delimiters and if so instructed will transliterate only the regions enclosed by the specified delimiters or only their complements. It can also convert one type of delimiter to another.\n

The program's optimization techniques save about 97% of\ncalculations needed for the next frame to make zooming as fast as\npossible.\n\nVarious coloring modes, formulas, planes and palettes are\nsupported. Xaos can also record and replay animations using simple\nscript language. Recently added features include: 10 each of out-,\nin-, and true-coloring modes, boundary detection, periodicity\nchecking, unrolled calculation loops, real-time image rotation, 50+\nexamples, and an AA driver that provides high quality ASCII art\nrendering at many platforms, SMP support, post calculation filters\n(motion blur, random dot stereograms in animation, interlace filter,\ntwo edge detection filters, star-firld generator, emboss, palette\nemulation filter), and dithering on devices without user defind palette.

180	wordgenerator	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/wordgenerator	http://billposer.org/Software/WordGenerator.html	Generates words from a specification of syllable structure.	WordGenerator generates hypothetical words from specifications of their syllable structure. The user specifies the maximum length of the words in syllables, the abstract structure of syllables in the language (in terms of such units as consonants and vowels or onsets and rhymes), and the actual sounds that comprise each abstract class (e.g. the list of vowels in the language); WordGenerator then generates the words that conform to this specification. Such lists are useful to field linguists exploring the vocabulary of a language, and to designers of artificial languages.

184	wn	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/wn	http://hopf.math.northwestern.edu/	HTTP server	WN is an HTTP server especially suited for servers\nthat must also perform other tasks. Both a standalone daemon and a\nversion intended for use under inetd are provided. The inetd version\nminimizes the use of system resources and is good for moderate or\nlightly loaded servers which cannot be totally dedicated to Web\nserving. Its goals are security and functionality usually available\nonly with complex CGI scripts; this includes extensive security\nchecks, full text searching and conditionally served text.\n\nDespite its extensive functionality the WN executable is\nsubstantially smaller than the CERN or NCSA servers. Its security\nmodel is based on the use of a small flat database in each directory\nwith information about the files in that directory. Unlike other\nservers, the default action for WN is to deny access to a file: a file\ncan only be served if explicit permission to do so has been granted by\nentering it in this database.

202	wipe	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/wipe	http://sourceforge.net/projects/wipe	Secure file wiping utility	Recovery of supposedly erased data from magnetic\nmedia is easier than commonly believed; Magnetic Force Microscopy\n(MFM) lets any moderately funded opponent recover the last two or\nthree layers of data written to disk. Wipe attempts to make this more\ndifficult by repeatedly overwriting special patterns to\nthe files to be destroyed, using the fsync() call and/or the O_SYNC\nbit to ensure that there is a file barrier between passes and that\neach pass is completely written.\n

Wine provides both a development toolkit for porting Windows source code to unixlike systems as well as a program loader, allowing many unmodified Windows programs to run.

216	wheretero	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/wheretero	http://www.iki.fi/karvinen/wheretero.html	A tool to detect country from network information.	Wheretero determines the country where the local computer is. This allows automatic keyboard layout configuration for live CDs. Network information is collected from DNS, DHCP, traceroute, GeoIpLookup, and Web IP address services. Information is scored and scaled. Wheretero prints its final decission as a two letter ISO country code, such as fi, de, fr, or us. Secondary choices are printed with probability estimations.

218	whatmask	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/whatmask	http://www.laffeycomputer.com/whatmask.html	Helps manipulate network settings	'Whatmask' is a tool to help manipualte network\nsettings. It can work in two modes. The first mode invokes Whatmask\nwith only a subnet mask as the argument; this mode echoes back the\nsubnet mask in four formats, plus the number of useable addresses in\nthe range.  \n\n<P>The second mode executes Whatmask with any ip address within the\nsubnet, followed by a slash ('/'), followed by the subnet mask in any\nformat. This echoes back the netmask in the following formats: CIDR,\nNetmask, Netmask (Hex) Wildcard Bits; the network address; the\nbroadcast address; the number of Usable IP Addresses; and the first\nand last usable IP addresses.\n

222	wget	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/wget	http://www.gnu.org/software/wget/wget.html	Retrieves files from the Web	Wget is a network utility to retrieve files from\nthe Web using http and ftp, the two most widely used Internet\nprotocols. It works non-interactively, so it will work in the\nbackground, after having logged off. The program supports recursive\nretrieval of web-authoring pages as well as ftp sites-- you can use wget to\nmake mirrors of archives and home pages or to travel the Web like a\nWWW robot.\n\nWget works particularly well with slow or unstable connections by\ncontinuing to retrieve a document until the document is fully\ndownloaded. Re-getting files from where it left off works on servers\n(both http and ftp) that support it. Both http and ftp retrievals\ncan be time stamped, so wget can see if the remote file has changed\nsince the last retrieval and automatically retrieve the new version if\nit has.	Intermediate

227	wellenreiter	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/wellenreiter	http://www.remote-exploit.org/	An easy to use, GTK/Perl-based wireless sniffer/scanner with enhanced features.	Wellenreiter is a GTK/Perl wireless network discovery and auditing tool. Prism2, Lucent, and Cisco based cards are supported. It is the easiest to use Linux scanning tool. No card configuration has to be done anymore. The whole look and feel is pretty self-explaining. It can discover networks (BSS/IBSS), and detects ESSID broadcasting or non-broadcasting networks and their WEP capabilities and the manufacturer automatically. DHCP and ARP traffic are decoded and displayed to give you further information about the networks. An ethereal/tcpdump-compatible dumpfile and an Application savefile will be automaticly created. gpsd can be used to track the location of the discovered networks.

240	webcdwriter	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/webcdwriter	http://JoergHaeger.de/webCDwriter/	A tool for network CD/DVD writing.	webCDwriter can be used to make the CD- and DVD-writer(s) connected to a Linux box available to all users in your network. It consists of the server CDWserver and the clients webCDcreator and rcdrecord. CDWserver stores the files transmitted by the clients, reserves the CD-writer and controls the CD-writer using cdrecord. webCDcreator is a Java applet that runs within your browser or by Java Web Start, assists you when putting together a CD, and transmits the files. Finally rcdrecord is a command line client that tries to offer the functionality of cdrecord over the network with full multi-user support.

248	web100	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/web100	http://www.web100.org/	Helps get 100% of the available bandwith for common TCP applications.	The Web100 project was created to produce a complete host-software environment that will run common TCP applications at 100% of the available  bandwidth, regardless of the magnitude of a network's capability. Web100 has endowed TCP  with better instrumentation. This instrumentation is the foundation for both the TCP autotuning performed in process-level code and the process- level tools designed to locate bottlenecks within the following major subsystems: the sending  application, the sending OS, the Internet path, the receiving OS, and the receiving application.  Measurement tools have also been built on this instrumentation to display performance indicators to end-users, as well as provide internal diagnostics for network and system administrators.

273	vthrottle	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/vthrottle	http://monkey.org/~jose/software/vthrottle/	SMTP throttling engine for Sendmail servers	'vthrottle' is an implementation of an SMTP\nthrottling engine for Sendmail. It lets sysadmins control how much\nemail users and hosts may send, hindering the rapid spread of viruses,\nworms, and spam. Exceptions can be made via a whitelist mechanism,\nwhich can be generated manually or with the included tool 'vmeasure'.\n'vthrottle' tells the misbehaving client to hold on to the deferred\nmail and resend it later.\n\n<P>'vthrottle' evaluates mail transactions at the connection, the HELO\n(or EHLO) statement, and the stated source address of the mail. For\neach of these, a list is traversed and the observed time interval\nbetween observations is evaluated. If the observed interval is shorter\nthan the policy interval, the mail is blocked by sending a failure\nreply code to the SMTP client; the message is then queued.\n\n<P>Because 'vthrottle' uses libmilter, it will not work with other\nMTAs, only with sendmail.\n	
274	vstr	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/vstr	http://www.and.org/vstr/	String library for network communications	'Vstr' is a string library for C designed for\nnetwork communication. Its design uses chunks of ptr+length data, so\nadding, substituting, and deleting data are all fast operations. It\ncan also do automatic referencing for mmap() areas of memory. Shortcut\nAPIs are included to mmap() a file into a Vstr string, and\nread()/write() data to/from a Vstr string.\n\n<P>Another feature is a POSIX and ISO 9899:1999 compliant printf()\nlike function, which can be extended with user supplied formatters\nthat are gcc warning compatible. The total API is over 140 functions,\nbut laid out in a easy to remember manner, including data parsing\nfunctions, a non-destructive split() function, and conversion\nfunctions (among others).\n

296	vloopback	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/vloopback	http://motion.sourceforge.net/vloopback/	Device driver that generates video pipes	The video4linux loopback device is a device driver\nthat generates video pipes. It lets a user program feed a video stream\nto another as if it were coming from an actual video4linux device. To\nachieve this a video pipe consists out of two video4linux devices: one\nfor the generating program to write its data to and one for a normal\nvideo4linux program to read from. At the moment there are only a few\nprograms that can feed the input of the pipe: invert and resize, the\nexample programs with the driver and motion, a motion detection\nprogram.\n

299	visprint	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/visprint	http://www.tastyrabbit.net/visprint	A visual fingerprint generator.	Visprint makes cool fractal fingerprint PNG images based on the contents of any file. The image will be different for almost every file with even slightly different contents. Visprint uses the IFS fractal generation process pioneered by Michael Barnsley. It is a way to create images that are self-similar to infinite depths. In other words, the picture is made up of smaller versions of itself. Visprint takes a hash function checksum as its input.	
300	visohotlink	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/visohotlink	http://www.visohotlink.org	Visohotlink is a php/MySQL script that helps you to detect and manage hotlinks of your files, but al	VisoHotlink offers several features that enables you to manage hotlinking. For each hotlink or hotlinking site, you have detailed stats giving the downloads number, the bandwidth used, the visits number, ... You can chose between several answer : sending or not the file, sending a replacement file, adding a watermark or redirect. Search engines and keywords are also detected. With VisoHotlink, you can know how many times a pictures is seen on Google Image.\nFinally, it's a very usefull tool to protect your files.\n

327	valgrind	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/valgrind	http://valgrind.org/	Memory debugger	Valgrind finds memory-management problems by\nchecking all reads and writes of memory are checked, and intercepting\nall calls to malloc/new/free/delete. As a result, Valgrind can detect\nproblems like the use of uninitialised memory, reading/writing memory\nafter it has been free'd, reading/writing off the end of malloc'd\nblocks, reading/writing inappropriate areas on the stack, memory\nleaks, and passing of uninitialised and/or unaddressible memory to\nsystem calls.\n\n<P>Valgrind tracks each byte of memory with nine status bits: one tracks\naddressibility, and the other eight validity. As a result, it can\ndetect the use of single uninitialised bits, and does not report\nspurious errors on bitfield operations. Valgrind debugs almost any\ndynamically-linked ELF x86 executable without modification or\nrecompilation.\n

331	uuid	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/uuid	http://www.ossp.org/pkg/lib/uuid/	Universally Unique Identifier (UUID) Toolkit	OSSP uuid is an application programming interface\n(API) and corresponding command line interface (CLI) for generating\nDCE 1.1 and ISO/IEC 11578:1996 compliant Universally Unique\nIdentifiers (UUID). It supports DCE 1.1 variant UUIDs of version 1\n(time and node based), version 3 (name based, MD5), version 4 (random\nnumber based) and version 5 (name based, SHA-1).\n\n<P>UUIDs are 128 bit numbers which are intended to have a high\nlikelihood of uniqueness over space and time and are computationally\ndifficult to guess. They are globally unique identifiers which can be\nlocally generated without contacting a global registration\nauthority. UUIDs are intended as unique identifiers for both mass\ntagging objects with an extremely short lifetime and to reliably\nidentify very persistent objects across a network.\n	
332	uucp	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/uucp	http://www.airs.com/ian/uucp.html	File copying program	Uucp copies files to or from another *nix system\nwhich also runs uucp. It transfers mail, news, and files between\nsystems which are not connected by more modern means. The connection\ncan be made via modem, a hard-wired serial connnection, or via an IP\nconnection.\n\n>P>is package has everything you need to make a UUCP connection,\nincluding versions of uucico, uusched, uuxqt, uux, uucp, uustat,\nuulog, uuname, uuto, uupick, and cu, as well as uuchk (a program to\ncheck configuration files), uuconv (a program to convert from one type\nof configuration file to another) and tstuu (a test harness for the\npackage).\n\n package currently supports the f, g (in all window and packet\nsizes), G, t and e protocols, as well a Zmodem protocol and two new\nbidirectional protocols. If you have a Berkeley sockets library, it\ncan make TCP connections. If you have TLI libraries, it can make TLI\nconnections. \n

334	ustl	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ustl	http://ustl.sourceforge.net	a size-optimized STL implementation	This library implements most of the standard C++ library with the goal of minimizing code size of client applications, achieving this goal by factoring out memory management code from the STL container templates into untyped memory block operations and modifying the templates to act only as a type-safety layer. Compared with the SGI STL implementation, shipped with gcc, using this library can reduce C++ overhead by a factor of four.

It automatically assembles multi-part binaries, provides searching via Perl regular expression syntax, and provides a pre-selection capability whereby the user can interactively choose which binaries to download. Ubh uses a standard .newsrc file to control which groups to process, and uses the .newsrc to keep track of articles already processed. It also handles uuencoded binaries, MIME attachments, and yEnc encoded binaries.

In addition, USBAuth comes with USB device serial checking support, so attackers won't be able to grab and copy your device easily (if this is the case, the device will be rejected).\n\nMoreover, USBAuth doesn't rely on USB libraries and device mounting so it may also be used at boot time for authentication.\n

For example, it cannot convert\nCelsius to Fahrenheit but it can convert temperature differences\nbetween those teperature scales.\n\nThe units are defined externally in an extensive, well annotated data\nfile that defines over 2000 units. You can also provide your own data\nfile.	
352	unit_circle	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/unit_circle	http://www.coyotegulch.com/products/unit_circle/index.html	A program to show the relationship between angles and trigonometric functions.	Unit Circle shows the relationship between angles and trigonometric functions like sine and cosine. To do this, the program implements an interactive "unit circle" (radius = 1) diagram, where the user can click or drag to set angles and see how the values of trigonometric functions change accordingly.	
353	unison	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/unison	http://www.cis.upenn.edu/~bcpierce/unison/	File synchronizer	Unison is a multi-platform file-synchronization\ntool. It stores two replicas of a collection of files and directories\non different hosts (or different disks on the same host), can modify\nthem separately, and then updates them by propagating the changes in\neach replica to the other. NON-conflicting updates are propagated\nautomatically; conflicting updates are detected and displayed. Unison\ncan deal with updates to both replicas of a distributed directory\nstructure.\n\n<P>It works across platforms, and is a user-level program- users do\nnot need superuser privileges on either host.  It works between any\npair of machines connected to the internet, communicating over either\na direct socket link or tunneling over an rsh or an encrypted ssh\nconnection. It conserves bandwidth, and runs well over slow links such\nas PPP connections. Transfers of small updates to large files are\noptimized using a compression protocol similar to rsync.\n

356	unidesc	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/unidesc	http://billposer.org/Software/unidesc.html	Utilities for analyzing Unicode-encoded text files	The Unicode Description Utilities is a set of four\nprograms for finding out what is in a Unicode file. 'uniname' defaults\nto printing the character offset of each character, its byte offset,\nits hex code value, its encoding, the glyph itself, and its\nname. Command line options allow undesired information to be\nsuppressed and the Unicode range to be added. \n\n<P>'unidesc' reports the character ranges to which different portions\nof the text belong. 'unihist' generates a histogram of the characters\nin its input. 'ExplicateUTF8' is intended for debugging or for\nlearning about Unicode. It determines and explains the validity of a\nsequence of bytes as a UTF-8 encoding.\n

358	unac	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/unac	http://www.senga.org/unac/	Removes accents from strings	'unac' is a C library and command that removes\naccents from a string. For instance, the string ?t? will become\nete. It provides a command line interface that removes accents from\nstandard input or from a string given as an argument. In the library\nfunction and the command, the charset of the input is specified as an\nargument. The input is converted to UTF-16 using iconv(3), accents are\nstripped, and the result is converted back to the original\ncharset. The iconv -l command on GNU/Linux will show all charsets\nsupported. It currently has Perl, PHP3, and PHP4 interfaces, and is\nUnicode-3.2 compatible.\n

It uses dynamic memory allocation, and has a\nsymbolic preordering and analysis phase that also reports the upper\nbounds on the nonzeros in L and U, flop count, and memory usage in the\nnumeric phase. 362	ulim	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ulim	http://v-lo.krakow.pl/~anszom/ulim-1.1.tgz	Enforces resource limits on processes	Ulim is a Linux kernel module which enforces\nresource limits on every process in the system. There are already\nsolutions like pam_limit, but there are some places where the user can\nexecute his programs, but PAM is not used (for example .forward or\n.procmailrc files, or CGI scripts). Ulim works in the kernel and sets\nthe limits whenever a process changes its real UID, so every process\nrun by a user will have the correct limits.\n

366	udt	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/udt	http://udt.sf.net	A UDP-based data transfer library	UDT is an application level data transport protocol for the emerging distributed data intensive applications over wide area high-speed networks. UDT uses UDP to transfer bulk data and it has its own reliability control and congestion control mechanism. This new protocol is not only for private or QoS-enabled links, but also for shared networks. Furthermore, UDT is also a composable framework that can accommodate various congestion control algorithms.	
367	udpcast	2010-05-03 16:09:19	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/udpcast	http://udpcast.linux.lu/	Install software via UDP multicast.	UDPCast allows for the sending of data simultaneously to many destinations on a local net. This can for instance be used to install an entire classroom's PCs at once. The advantage over using other methods (nfs, ftp, whatever) is that udpcast uses Ethernet's multicast abilities: it won't take longer to install 15 machines than it would to install 2. The tool comes with a busybox bootdisk for easy loading of the tool. However, udpcast can also be started from the command line of an already installed system, and can be used for purposes other than just system installation.

The Merkle Hash Tree is a hash construct that\nexhibits desirable properties for verifying the integrity of files and\nfile subranges in an incremental or out-of-order fashion. 'tthsum'\nuses the Tiger hash algorithm for both the internal and the leaf\nnodes, and has an interface identical to md5sum.\n

404	trickle	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/trickle	http://monkey.org/~marius/trickle/	Bandwidth shaper	'trickle' is a lightweight, portable,\nper-application bandwidth shaper. It works in collaboration with\ntrickled or in stand alone mode, has peak detection, and does\nsmoothing. \n\nIt works by taking advantage of the unix loader preloading: it\nprovides, to the application, a new version of the functionality that\nis required to send and receive data through sockets. It then limits\ntraffic based on delaying the sending and receiving of data over a\nsocket. Trickle works entirely in userland and does not require root\nto run.

What TreeMaker 5 adds to previous versions:\n<ul>\n<li>Full mountain-valley crease assignments;</li>\n<li>An x-ray image of the folded form of the base;</li>\n<li>Numerous new options for display and simplified editing.</li>\n</ul>\n\nAll files are under the GPL , except the files in the wnlib directory which are provide AS-IS without restriction.\n

Nodes in the tree are templated over the content type,\njust like they are for vector, list and all other STL\ncontainers. There are iterators that traverse the entire tree and\niterators that just traverse all children of a given node. You can use\nthe STL algorithms (like find) to manipulate the tree. It resembles PHP, JSP, or Mason, but the programming language used is C++, and the pages are compiled into native code before serving. Tntnet is fully multithreaded and supports http-keep-alive for best performance. Dynamic pages are served about as fast as static pages in other Web servers, while creating Web applications keeps simple.

455	tidydoc	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/tidydoc	http://savannah.nongnu.org/projects/tidydoc	A documentation organizer	The goal of tidydoc is to make documentation organization easier. You can add documents to a pool of documents, give them the right names and put them into the right directories, and generate a set of HTML pages to browse your documents. A bibtex file can also be generated. It is written in Python in the spirit of flexibility and easy tweaking, but with default behaviors that fit the needs of most people. You can add documents using most transmission protocols, such as a simple cp or through SSH with SCP. Tidydoc then generates HTML or bibtex files indexing your documents. A simple XML file is required for each document, including some information. These description files may be generated by using tidydoc's upload facilities, but this is not mandatory.	Intermediate
456	tinycc	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/tinycc	http://fabrice.bellard.free.fr/tcc/		TCC (Tiny C Compiler) is small, fast, unlimited,\nand safe. You can compile and execute C code everywhere (e.g., on\nrescue disks). It generates optimized x86 code, and can compile,\nassemble, and link several times faster than 'gcc -O0'. Any C dynamic\nlibrary can be used directly. It includes an optional memory and\nbounds checker, and bounds-checked code can be mixed freely with\nstandard code. C script is also supported--just add '#!/usr/bin/tcc'\nat the first line of your C source, and execute it directly from the\ncommand line.\n	
457	tinySRP	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/tinySRP	http://members.tripod.com/professor_tom/archives/index.html	Stripped-down password authentication library	The Tiny SRP library is a stripped-down version of\nsrp-1.7.1 and openssl-0.9.6 that contains only what is necessary for\nsecure remote passphrase authentication. No other libraries are\nrequired. If you already have libsrp installed on both server and\nclient then you don't need this. \n\nTiny SRP is designed for embedded or mini distributions, and is\nalso a quick and easy way to add secure authentication to small\nclient/server projects. Also included is the TSRP protocol, which\nreduces socket authentication to one function call on each of the\nclient and server.

481	textutils	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/textutils		Text utilities	Textutils contains the following software:\n<ul>\n       <li>cat- concatenates and prints files on the standard output</li>\n       <li>cksum- checksum and count the bytes in a file</li>\n       <li>comm- compares two sorted files line by line</li>\n       <li>csplit- splits a file into sections determined by context lines</li>\n       <li>cut- remove sections from each line of files</li>\n       <li>expand- convert tabs to spaces</li>\n       <li>fmt- simple optimal text formatter</li>\n       <li>fold- wrap each input line to fit in specified width</li>\n       <li>head- output the first part of files</li>\n       <li>join- join lines of two files on a common field</li>\n       <li>md5sum- compute and check MD5 messsage digest</li>\n       <li>nl- number lines of files</li>\n       <li>od- dump files in octal and other formats</li>\n       <li>paste- merge lines of files</li>\n       <li>ptx- produce a permuted index of file contents</li>\n       <li>pr- convert text files for printing</li>\n       <li>sort- sort lines of text files</li>\n       <li>split- split a file into pieces</li>\n       <li>sum- checksum and count the blocks in a file</li>\n       <li>tac- concatenates and prints files in reverse</li>\n       <li>tail- outputs the last part of files</li>\n       <li>tr- translates or deletes characters</li>\n       <li>tsort- perform topological sort</li>\n       <li>unexpand- convert spaces to tabs</li>\n       <li>uniq- remove duplicate lines from a sorted file</li>\n       <li>wc- prints the number of bytes, words, and lines in files</li>\n</ul>\t\t     \n\nThis program has been folded into 'coreutils.' Please see that entry\n(http://directory.fsf.org/coreutils.html) for the latest\ninformation on this software.\nThis project was a GNU package. It\nhas since been decommissioned and is no longer developed.

It is independent from any language, and even seems to work well with HTML files.\nFirst you have to train the program with sample text. (e.g. all of Grimm's fairy tales). It displays source and destination addresses and ports,\nconnection state, idle time, and bandwidth usage. \n\n<P>The filter expression is a standard pcap filter expression\n(identical to the expressions used by tcpdump) which can filter down\nthe characteristics of TCP connections that tcptrack will see.\n

You can use tar to create file\narchives, to extract files from previously created archives, store\nadditional files, or update or list files which were already stored.\n\n<P>The program saves many files together into a single tape or disk\narchive, and can restore individual files from the archive. It\nincludes multivolume support, the ability to archive sparse files,\nautomatic archive compression/decompression, remote archives and\nspecial features that allow 'tar' to be used for incremental and full\nbackups.\n\n<P>The supported archive formats are: V7 tar, GNU, ustar and POSIX\n(also known as pax interchange format). GNU tar can also read and\nextract 'star' archives. Tar can direct its output to available\ndevices, files, or other programs (using pipes); tar can even access\nremote devices or files (as archives).\n

All five programs provide fairly extensive checking of their input for errors and untranslatable codes. The ITRANS used is, by default, extended to include codes for the Tamil digits and to include HZ escapes (as defined in RFC 1843) that delimit the Tamil portion. This allows processing of mixed Tamil and ASCII text. The extensions and use of HZ escapes can be disabled by command-line switches.

544	syrep	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/syrep	http://0pointer.de/lennart/projects/syrep/	Generic file repository synchronization tool	'syrep' is a generic file repository\nsynchronization tool. It synchronizes large file hierarchies\nbidirectionally by exchanging patch files. It is peer-to-peer, does\nnot require a central server, and supports synchronization between\nmore than two repositories. Patch files can be transferred via offline\nmedia (ie removable hard drives or compact disks).\n\n<P>Files are tracked by their message digests, currently MD5. The\nsnapshot files track file creation, deletion, modification, creation\nof new hard or symbolic links, and renaming (which is merely a new\nhard link and removal of the old file). syrep doesn't distuinguish\nbetween soft and hard links; even copies of files are treated as the\nsame. Currently, syrep doesn't synchronize file attributes like access\nmodes or modification times.\n

When the program is given a document containing user defined\ntags and their definition, it produces a new document, which is\ngenerated by replacing the tags with their definition (you can\nasssociate functions to tags). SXML supports the XML 1.0 syntax\nexcluded entity support and documents' DTDs.\n\nWith SXML you can use XML to define sites that are accesssible by all\nbrowsers: since the output will be standard HTML, it's very good for\nmaintaining Web sites. You can also use SXML as a module in a\ngeneration system: the system generates the SXML documents that will\nbe transformed in the target language. You can also write a document\nin your markup language and compile it to different output\nlanguages. It is based on a fairly\nsimple philosophy intended to simplify the management of third party\nsoftware and their inter-dependencies.\n\n<P>Each software package is installed in a different directory, and\nsymbolic links are used to populate common directories (typically\n/usr/local/bin, /usr/local/sbin, ..) which are then referenced by\nusers (in their PATH and so on). The directories where the software\nactually lives are never referenced directly by users. For most\nsoftware packages, setup and installation is as straight forward as if\nyou were installing them directly in /usr/local.\n

You can also limit your search\nto words in HTML titles, comments, emphasized tags, and META tags. In\naddition, 8-bit HTML characters can be indexed, converted, and\nsearched.

562	swbis	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/swbis	http://www.gnu.org/software/swbis/	Extensions to the POSIX packaging standard	'swbis' aims to implement the POSIX packaging standard with useful extensions. Working utilities include swpackage, swverify, swcopy, swlist, and swinstall. Package security is provided by embedded control files containing md5, sha1, and sha512 digests, and GPG signatures. swbis is back-compatible with free software source tarballs because package meta-data is contained in-band in the prescribed directory. Since swbis supports nil control directory names, the package layout need not change except for the addition of this directory. The swbis utilities are network transparent by direct use of SSH, and do not have to be installed on the target hosts. swbis run-time packages can be delivered, by swinstall, to any GNU, BSD, or Unix-like host with no new provisioning requirements for the remote host. Since run-time packages are POSIX tar archives, they may be unpacked using the system tar utility. The spec is available at http://www.opengroup.org/publications/catalog/c701.htm.	Intermediate

It monitors the system memory and detects when swap\ncreation will be required. Swap size is determined automatically with\nrespect to the limits set by the sysadmin. It works with Linux kernels\nversion 2.4.23 or higher.\n

Its current features include: \n<pre>\n\n    -Most current CVS features\n    -Directories, renames, and file meta-data are versioned\n    -Commits are truly atomic\n    -Apache network server option, with WebDAV/DeltaV protocol\n    -Standalone server option\n    -Branching and tagging are cheap (constant time) operations\n    -Natively client/server, layered library design\n    -Client/server protocol sends diffs in both directions\n    -Costs are proportional to change size, not data size\n    -Efficient handling of binary files\n    -Parseable output\n</pre>\n

619	ssync	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ssync	http://angrypot.com/ssync/index.html	Filesystem synchronization utility	SSYNC is a minimalistic filesystem synchronization\nutility. Its primary goals are reliability, correctness, and speed in\nsyncing extremely large filesystems over fast, local network\nconnections. SSYNC does not implement encryption, compression,\ndifferencing algorithms, or remote synchronization over a pipe such as\nrsh / ssh since those features are already well covered by other\nutilities such as rsync.\n\n<P>It works well on large filesystems and can handle filesystem\nobjects with unusual and non-ASCII characters in their names while\ncorrectly preserving all symbolic and hard links and all mode bits. It\ncan be run at increased or decreased niceness and can provide several\nlevels of logging output.  Several options allow complete control of\nsynchronization behaviors such as selectively disabling updating of\ndata, ownership, and modes, as well as updating only newer objects or\njust performing 'test runs'.\n

646	spinner	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/spinner	http://www.laffeycomputer.com/spinner.html	Keeps telnet and ssh links from dropping	Spinner keeps telnet and ssh links from dropping\ndue to inactivity. Many firewalls and some ISPs drop connections when\nthey are perceived as idle. Spinner acts as a keep-alive by constantly\nsending a tiny amount of data over the link, preserving the\nconnection. It displays a little "spinning" ASCII character in the top\nleft corner of your terminal. It can also be activated with the -n\nswitch so that, instead of displaying a spinner, it simply sends out a\nperiodic null character to the terminal.\n\nIt supports any terminal capable of handling VT100-style escape\ncodes. It also has a mode called "Ghost in the Machine" mode, which\nyou can use to write the spinner character to ANY tty, not just your\nown.

659	spamtrainer	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/spamtrainer	http://spamtrainer.sourceforge.net/	A drag and drop spam filter trainer for GNOME.	Spam Trainer makes it easier for GNOME users to train spam filtering software (e.g. SpamBayes or SpamAssassin) that "learns" how to tell the difference between real email (ham) and unsolicited messages (spam).  Not all email clients have spam filtering (and training) built in, and training external filtering programs can be fiddly. Spam Trainer provides easy (drag and drop) training from the Evolution mail client, and should work just as well with any email client that supports the drag and drop protocol implemented by the GTK+ toolkit.	
660	spamresponder	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/spamresponder	http://www.thinknerd.org/~ssc/wiki/doku.php?id=spamresponder	Spamfilter that combines C/R with DNS validation	Spamresponder is a very simple and radical spam\nfilter that combines DNS validation with the challenge/response\napproach. It goes through the mail messages in /var/mail/$USER,\nlooking for specific "trusted" strings in the header and body parts of\nthe mail. It deletes and sends an automatic reply to messages which\nhave no "trusted" strings inside them. \n\n<P>Those replies will include one of the "trusted" strings, so the\nrecipient just needs to reply to this confirmation message. The\nMailFrom-address of an email containing a trusted string becomes a\ntrusted string itself\n

These simple HTTP interactions (i.e. RESTful interactions) allow data to be exchanged between servers in an organized way that makes it easy for the data to be processed and interpreted. This creates a data services layer that provides transformation and integration services and allows networked data sources to interact directly with one another so that integration can occur within the network.\n<br>\nThese techniques enable a building-block approach which supports interoperability and reuse of components to a level that would be unattainable with commercial or hand-coded integration alternatives.\n

704	smtpblock	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/smtpblock	http://www.angmar.com/smtpblock/	Automatically detects and blocks open mail relays	'Smtpblock' parses a *nix mail log. When new mail\nmessages are detected, it performs DNSBL/SMTP relay tests. If the host\nis listed in a DNSBL or relays third-party mail, Smtpblock creates a\nfirewall rule to block access to the localhost's SMTP port and/or\ncreates a hash that can be referenced by sendmail's RFC-822 pattern\nmatching feature.\n\nIt keeps track of each host's test status and time when it will need\nto be rechecked, reducing the need to constantly check every host\nsending mail to the local system. Smtpblock can be run as a daemon\ncontinuously checking the mail log or as a standalone program parsing\nthe entire log file. Hosts can be manually checked, blocked, or\nunblocked from the command line.

714	smarteiffel	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/smarteiffel	http://smarteiffel.loria.fr/index.html	Eiffel compiler	SmartEiffel, the GNU Eiffel compiler, is a small,\nfast multi-platform Eiffel compiler. It should work on any platform\nfor which an ANSI C POSIX compiler or a standard JVM exist. The\nproject was formerly known as 'smalleiffel.'\n\nThe Eiffel language is a pure object-oriented language providing\nstrong type-checking and based on the concept of 'design by\ncontract'. It allows multiple inheritance and does it\nwell. Design-by-contract means that a class guarantees that certain\nconditions will always hold, and that a routine guarantees certain\nresults given certain specified inputs. The rules for inheritance mean\nthat contracts can be relied on even when classes are reused through\ninheritance.	
715	smart_pointers	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/smart_pointers	http://axter.com/smartptr/	smart_ptr is a smart pointer policy class that can use different ownership logic and semantic police	The smart_ptr class can be used with STL containers to create containers of smart pointers, moreover it can be used to create a container of abstract based objects via smart_ptr. In general, smart_ptr is faster than boost::shared_ptr. When used with STL containers, the smart pointer is faster than the boost pointer containers. More importantly, the interface for an STL container of smart_ptr is a 100% compatible with STL containers, which is not the case with the boost pointer containers. smart_ptr has a policy that allows it to synchronize access to both the smart pointer and the pointee. The smart_ptr has been compiled and tested on VC++ 6.0, 7.1, 8.0, GNU 3.x, Borland 5.5, and Comeau 4.3.

721	sloccount	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/sloccount	http://www.dwheeler.com/sloccount/	Counts lines of code in a program	'SLOCCount' is a set of tools for counting\nphysical Source Lines of Code (SLOC) in a large number of\nlanguages. It can measure 19 different languages, including C, C++,\nPerl, LISP/Scheme, and Python (A complete list is available on the\nhome page).\n\nSLOCCount includes a number of heuristics, so it can detect many\nfiles that don't use the ``standard'' extensions. 734	skipper	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/skipper	http://home.freeuk.net/skipperproject/	Full GUI accessibility for severely movement impaired people	Skipper has two parts. 748	simsynch	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/simsynch	http://swiss.csail.mit.edu/~jaffer/SIMSYNCH	SIMSYNCH is a simulator for digital electronics at scales from chip to board.	The design files are comprised of Scheme definitions and expressions.\n These design files can be run as a Scheme program at high speed.  The\n design files can also be translated into formats suitable for logic\n compilers (MACHXL, Verilog, and VHDL).\n\n SIMSYNCH simulates blocks of synchronous logic, signals whose states\n change simultaneously on a clock signal transition.  Each block also\n has a reset signal, which forces all signals to the state specified in\n the design file.  SIMSYNCH can simultaneously simulate multiple blocks\n with different clocks and resets.  Devices can contain multiple blocks;\n Blocks can span multiple devices.\n

764	siege	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/siege	http://www.joedog.org/	HTTP regression testing and benchmark utility	Siege is a free and open source regression test and\nbenchmark utility that lets Web designers measure the\nperformance of their code under a heavy load of hits. 'Siege' lets\nthe user hit a server with an adjustable number of concurrent users,\nthus placing the server "under siege." \n\nIt can stress test a single URL with a user defined number of\nsimulated users, or it can read many URLs into memory and stress them\nsimultaneously. The program reports the total number of hits recorded,\nbytes transferred, response time, concurrency, and return status. Most\nfeatures are configurable with command line options, which also\ninclude default values to minimize the complexity of the programs's\ninvocation.
