787	sharutils	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/sharutils	http://www.gnu.org/software/sharutils/sharutils.html	Creates and helps unpack shell archives	Sharutils consists of two shell archiving\nutilities: "shar" and "unshar."\n\n<P>"shar" makes shell archives out of many files and preps them for\ntransmission by email. A shell archive is a collection of files that\ncan be unpacked by /bin/sh.  Among other things, the program can\ncompress files, uuencode binary files, split long files and construct\nmulti-part mailings, ensure correct unsharing order, and provide\nsimplistic checksums.\n\n<P>"unshar" scans mail archives, looks for the start of shell\narchives, and automatically strips off headers and other introductory\ntext. The bodies of the messages are then unpacked by a copy of the\nshell; the program may also process files containing linked shell\narchives.\n	Intermediate

Instead, the model is manipulated much like clay, push or pull an area, smooth it, make a hollow or a hill. The entire process is both simple and organic; you won't need years of modeling experience to create detailed models in SharpConstruct.\n\nThis project is no longer maintained.

791	shared-app-vnc	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/shared-app-vnc	http://shared-app-vnc.sourceforge.net/	Share application windows from your desktop to remote computers.	SharedAppVnc allows desktop windows to be shared\nor replicated between remote computers. It is\nbased on a modified VNC protocol. Traditional VNC\nshares a users entire desktop, but this can be\nproblematic if some content, such as email, should\n be kept private. SharedAppVnc resolves the\nprivate-public content problem by only sharing the\nwindows a user selects. Each shared window is\nshown in its own frame on the clients computer.\nThis allows for independent resizing, moving, or\nhiding of shared windows. Window positions on the\nlocal and remote client are not dependent.\n

prints user information</li>\n       <li>printenv- prints environment variables</li>\n       <li>printf- formats and prints data</li>\n       <li>pwd- prints the working (current) directory</li>\n       <li>seq- prints numeric sequences</li>\n       <li>sleep- suspends execution for a specified time</li>\n       <li>stty- prints/changes terminal settings</li>\n       <li>su- lets you adopt the ID of another user or superuser</li>\n       <li>tee- sends output to multiple files</li>\n       <li>test- evaluates an expression</li>\n       <li>true- returns a successful exit status</li>\n       <li>tty- prints terminal name</li>\n       <li>uname- prints system information</li>\n       <li>uptime- tells how long the system has been running</li>\n       <li>users- prints current user names</li>\n       <li>who- prints a list of all users currently logged in</li>\n       <li>whoami- prints effective user ID</li>\n       <li>yes- prints a string indefinitely</li>\n</ul>\nThis program has been folded into 'coreutils.' 794	sft	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/sft	http://nbenoit.tuxfamily.org/sft_en.htm	File transfer program	SFT (Simple File Transfer) is a file transfer\nprogram, a bit like rcp. It is designed to simplify file transfers\nfrom one computer to an another when they are connected to the\nInternet. The person receiving the file has to run the program in\nserver mode (-s), while the sender of the file has to run the program\nin client mode (-c), specifying the destination host IP and the file\nnames. File integrity is checked by using checksums.\n\n<P>Server options include -k (keeps the server running after\nsessions), -d (+ path- lets you choose the reception directory), and -l\n(+ number- limits the number of incoming bytes).  For the client, -d\n+ path lets you choose the program's working directory.\n

It provides\nroutines and help for implementing IP based servers (currently TCP,\nUDP and ICMP). It is also possible to use named pipes for all\nconnection oriented protocols. The application demonstrates various\naspects of advanced network programming in a portable manner.\n\nYou can use it for implementing your own servers or for\nunderstanding how certain network services and operations work. 800	serlvers	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/serlvers	http://freshmeat.net/redir/serlvers/64146/url_homepage/serlvers	Serlvers is a set of Erlang modules designed to help in the implementation of IP services (i.e. TCP/	Serlvers is a set of Erlang modules designed to help in the implementation of IP services (i.e. TCP/IP or Internet servers). Serlvers consists of a set of behaviours to abstract the internals of each protocol, and other modules to help with the infrastructure. The goal is that when making a server, you only need worry about how to store, handle, process, etc. the information instead of the internals of each protocol (to save countless hours of RFC reading).

822	sdir	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/sdir	http://ibsmirnov.narod.ru	Scans the directory hierarchy.	The command "sdir" scans directories starting from the current directory, and passing through all directory tree originated from the current directory, possibly (if requested) prints the directory names and possibly (if requested) executes any command in each (sub)directory. "Sdir" changes the current directory to each of the passed subdirectories and runs the target command once per each directory (including the initial current directory). The program supports various ways of calling executed target command, which allows the user to adapt the output for his needs. \n<br>\n"Sdir" is well combined with basical UNIX commands like "ls", "du", "grep", and is a good addition or alternative for "find".\n<br>\nAn additional experimental syster program "sdirstat" does some more.\nInstead of executing another command it analyses the directory tree itself by in-built algorithms. For example it allows the user to print all file names (from the whole tree) in a chronological order or to estimate the number of lines of code in complicated source code depositories. \n

827	sdcc	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/sdcc	http://sdcc.sourceforge.net/	ANSI-C compiler	"Small Device C Compiler" is a retargetable,\noptimizing ANSI C compiler. The current version targets the Intel 8051\nand recently the Zilog Z80 based MCUs., but can be retargeted for\nother 8 bit MCUs or PICs. SDCC uses ASXXXX and ASLINK, a retargettable\nassembler and linker. SDCC has extensive MCU specific language\nextensions, which lets it effectively use the underlying hardware. The\nfront end (parser) will be enhanced as targeted to handle language\nextensions for other MCUs.\n\nIn addition to the MCU Specific optimizations, SDCC \ndoes a host of standard optimizations like global sub expression\nelimination, loop optimizations (loop invariant, strength reduction\nof induction variables and loop reversing), constant folding and\npropagation, copy propagation, dead code elimination and jump tables\nfor 'switch' statements.

The library also provides various helper\nfunctions for managing timers and UDP communication.\n

833	screen	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/screen	http://www.gnu.org/software/screen/screen.html	Runs separate screens on a single terminal	A full screen window manager that lets a physical\nterminal handle several processes, typically interactive shells.\n\nEach virtual terminal provides the functions of a DEC VT100 terminal\nas well as several control functions from the ANSI X3.64 and ISO 2022\nstandards. Each virtual terminal has a scrollback history buffer and a\ncopy/paste mechanism to move text regions between windows.\n\n<p>"Screen" creates a single window with a shell (or a specified command)\nin it; after that you run the program as you normally would. You can\ncreate new full-screen windows with other programs in them, including\nmore shells, at any time; you can also kill the current window, view a\nlist of active windows, toggle output logging, copy text between\nwindows, view the scrollback history, switch between windows,\netc. Windows run their programs independently of each other; programs\nkeep running even if their window is not visible or the whole screen\nsession detaches from the terminal.\n

845	schedutils	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/schedutils	http://tech9.net/rml/schedutils/	&#39;chrt&#39; and &#39;taskset&#39;	The Linux scheduler utilities take advantage of\nthe scheduler family of syscalls that Linux implements across various\nkernels. These system calls implement interfaces for scheduler-related\nparameters such as CPU affinity and real-time attributes. Standard\nutilities do not support these interfaces, thus 'schedutils.'\n\n<P>'Schedutils' includes 'chrt' and 'taskset'. Together with nice and\nrenice (not included), they allow full control of process scheduling\nparameters. 'taskset' manipulates task CPU affinity; 'chrt'\nmanipulates scheduling priority and policy.\n\n<P>'irqset' and 'lsrt' are no longer included.\n

848	scapy	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/scapy	http://www.secdev.org/projects/scapy	An interactive packet manipulation tool.	Scapy is a powerful interactive packet\nmanipulation tool, packet generator, network\nscanner, network discovery tool, and packet\nsniffer. It provides classes to interactively\ncreate packets or sets of packets, manipulate\nthem, send them over the wire, sniff other packets\nfrom the wire, match answers and replies, and\nmore. Interaction is provided by the Python\ninterpreter, so Python programming structures can be used (such as variables, loops, and functions). Report modules are possible and easy to make. It is intended to do about the same things as ttlscan, nmap, hping, queso, p0f, xprobe, arping, arp-sk, arpspoof, firewalk, irpas, tethereal, tcpdump, etc.\n	
849	scanlogd	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/scanlogd	http://www.openwall.com/scanlogd/	TCP port scan detection tool	'scanlogd' is a TCP port scan detection tool which\nattempts to log all portscans of a host to the syslog, in a secure\nfashion. It was designed to illustrate various attacks an IDS\ndeveloper has to deal with; thus, unlike some other port scan\ndetection tools, 'scanlogd' is designed to be totally safe to use. The\ncurrent released can be built with support for one of several packet\ncapture interfaces. In addition to the raw socket interface on\nGnu/Linux, scanlogd is now aware of libnids and libpcap.\n\n<P>The author discourages the use of libpcap. If you're on a system\nother than GNU/Linux and/or want to monitor the traffic of an entire\nnetwork at once, he suggests using libnids in order to handle\nfragmented IP packets.\n

864	sambascan2	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/sambascan2	http://asturio.gmxhome.de/sambascan.html	A tool that scans SMB networks for shares using Samba.	Sambascan2 allows you to search an entire network or a number of hosts for SMB shares. It will also list the contents of all public shares that it finds. The difference between sambascan2 and other SMB viewers and scanners is that it will scan everything using TCP/IP, and it will not send a lot of broadcast messages, so it can be used over LAN boundaries. It only uses Samba to scan the shares and their contents. It can also scan known hosts and search indexed files.

It has some features that some other rsync-based backup schemes lack, such as being written in C++, needing no scripts or programs other than rsync and any binaries on which rsync depends (such as SSH), the ability to manage multiple instances of rsync connections to separate clients in parallel, the ability to use multiple logical partitions (vaults) in a configurable fashion for purposes of redundancy and added reliability, and the use of hard links for files that have not changed from one archive to the next.

'rsyncrypto'\ncompresses the plain text file then encrypts it with gzip using the\n"rsyncable" patch, which is available from the rsync sources.\n

905	rsync	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/rsync	http://samba.anu.edu.au/rsync/	FTP program to keep remote files in synch	rsync is a replacement for rcp that has many more\nfeatures. rsync uses the "rsync algorithm" which provides a very fast\nmethod for bringing remote files into sync by sending\njust the differences in the files across the link, without requiring\nthat both sets of files are present at one of the ends of the link\nbeforehand. \n\nAt first glance this may seem impossible because the calculation of\ndiffs between two files normally requires local access to both\nfiles. A technical report describing the rsync algorithm is included\nwith this package.

This improves response times and reduces\nnetwork usage, which is particularly important given the increase in\ndynamic content on the Web (with dynamic content a resource must\nbe exactly the same as the cached instance, or it is downloaded\nfrom scratch). \n

928	rox	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/rox	http://rox.sourceforge.net/	Graphical desktop	The ROX Desktop is based around the file\nsystem. Its core component is ROX-Filer, a graphical file manager that\nsupports `application directories:' directories which contain an\nentire application. When you open an application directory in the\nfiler the application runs. Therefore, installing an application is\nthe same as copying a directory, uninstalling is the same as deleting,\nand to install two different versions of the same application just\ncopy them to different directories on your hard disk. There is no need\nfor special setup programs or root access.\n\nTo read an application's help just choose Help from the filer menu\nto see it (it just opens a subdirectory inside the application *\ncalled 'Help'). There is no need for a separate filer and application\nlauncher. The filer does both, and you always know where your programs\nare. It also has drag-and-drop saving, which means you can save by\ndragging the file back from the application into the filer.

936	root	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/root	http://root.cern.ch/	Data analysis package developed at CERN.	Having had many years of experience in developing the interactive data analysis systems PAW and PIAF and the simulation package GEANT, we realized that the growth and maintainability of these products, written in FORTRAN and using some 20 year old libraries, had reached its limits. Although still very popular, these systems do not scale up to the challenges offered by the LHC, where the amount of data to be simulated and analyzed is a few orders of magnitude larger than anything seen before.\nIt became time to re-think our approach to large scale data analysis and simulation and at the same time we had to profit from the progress made in computer science over the past 15 to 20 years. Especially in the area of Object-Oriented design and development. Thus was born ROOT.\n\nWe started the ROOT project in the context of the NA49 experiment at CERN. NA49 generates an impressive amount of data, about 10 Terabytes of raw data per run. This data rate is of the same order of magnitude as the rates expected to be recorded by the LHC experiments. Therefore, NA49 is an ideal environment to develop and test the next generation data analysis tools and to study the problems related to the organization and analysis of such large amounts of data. \n

939	rocks	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/rocks	http://www.cs.wisc.edu/~zandy/rocks/	Protects sockets-based applications from network failures	Rocks (Reliable Sockets) protects sockets-based\napplications from network failures, especially those common to mobile\ncomputing (link failures, IP address changes, and extended periods of\ndisconnection). Rock-enabled programs keep running after these events;\ntheir broken connections recover automatically (even when one end of\nthe connection has a new IP address), without loss of in-flight data,\nwhen connectivity returns. The program also authenticates the resumed\nconnections. It works entirely at user level and is transparent to\nordinary applications.\n

A specific area can be displayed by entering a street address (street number, street name, city, and state). It interfaces with a GPS receiver through gpsd or the serial line to track the car position. It has been designed to be usable on a Linux desktop or laptop computer, or on a PDA (Linux or PocketPC). It protects\nusers from harmful mail content (virii and worms) by disabling or\nremoving attachments that the user may accidentally execute.\n\n<P>Unlike a conventional virus scanner, there are no specific virus or\nworm definitions. Instead, the program identifies potentially\ndangerous attachments based on filename extension and on encoded body\ncontent. 975	renameutils	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/renameutils	http://www.nongnu.org/renameutils/	Programs to make renaming of files easier	The file renaming utilities (renameutils for\nshort) are a set of programs designed to make renaming of multiple\nfiles faster and less cumbersome. It currently consists of two\nprograms: "qmv" and "imv".  qmv allows files to be renamed by editing\ntheir names in any text editor.  Since the files are listed after each\nother, this allows common changes to be made more quickly. \n\n<P>imv ("interactive mv") is trivial but useful when you are too lazy\nto type (or even complete) the name of the file to rename.  It allows\nthe filename to be edited in the terminal using the GNU readline\nlibrary. This is also useful when renaming files in Midnight\nCommander, where the whole filename has to be entered again.\n

977	remote_update	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/remote_update	http://www.viraj.org/	Automates remote administration tasks	remote_update.pl is a script that uses Expect,\nPERL, and SSH to perform automated remote administration on a large\nnumber of hosts. The script is given a set of passwords, a list of\nremote hosts, a collection of files to copy over, and a set of scripts\nto run on the remote hosts. The only thing required to be running on\nthe remote machines is SSH.\n\n<P>It tries to copy all of the needed files and scripts to the remote\nmachine via SCP as a non-root user, SSH in as the non-root user, su to\nroot on the remote machine if applicable, and then execute the scripts\nyou provided.  This process is cycled for every host given. su'ing to\nroot can be turned off, and also the tasks can be parallelized in\nmultiple processes.\n

1002	rdiffbackup	2010-05-03 16:09:20	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/rdiffbackup	http://www.nongnu.org/rdiff-backup/	Backs up one directory to another	'rdiff-backup' combines the features of a mirror\nand an incremental backup by backing up one directory to another. The\ntarget directory ends up a copy of the source directory, but extra\nreverse diffs are stored in a special directory so you can recover\nfiles lost some time ago.\n\n'rdiff-backup' operates in a space- and bandwidth- efficient\nmanner over a pipe (like rsync): you can use rdiff-backup and ssh to\nsecurely back up to a remote location, and only the differences get\ntransmitted. It also handles symlinks, device files, permissions,\nownership, etc., so it can be used on the entire file system.

The\noutput is less accurate, however. \n\n<P>Rate features four different operating modes, designed to perform\nthe following tasks: estimating overall traffic rates, determining\nnodes generating the highest traffic, determining connections and\nflows generating the highest traffic and extracting strings from\npackets.\n

1017	ragel	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ragel	http://www.elude.ca/ragel/	Compiles finite state machines from regular languages into runnable C code	Ragel compiles finite state machines from regular\nlanguages into runnable C code. It allows you to embed function calls\nat any point in your regular language, and to control the non-determinism\nin the resulting machines. It function calls at any point in your\nregular language, and to control the non-determinism in the resulting\n\n<P>It understands concatenation, union (the "or" operator), kleene\nstar, subtraction, and intersection, as well as some helpers like "!",\n"?" and "+". Ragel's finite state machines are closed under all of its\noperators. This property allows for arbitrary regular lanuages to be\ndescribed. It can be used to create a parser for any language that is\nregular.\n	
1018	radmind	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/radmind	http://rsug.itd.umich.edu/software/radmind	Tools for remote administration	'radmind' is a suite of tools and a server for\nremotely administering file systems of multiple Unix machines. At its\ncore, radmind operates as a tripwire. It detects changes to any\nmanaged filesystem object (e.g. files, directories, links); once a\nchange is detected, radmind can optionally reverse it. \n\nEach managed machine can have its own loadset composed of multiple,\nlayered overloads. This lets (for example) the operating system be\ndescribed separately from applications. Loadsets are stored on a\nremote server. By updating a loadset on the server, changes can be\npushed to managed machines.

1038	qscheme	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/qscheme	http://sof.ch/dan/qscheme/index-e.html	Implementation of Scheme written in C	Qscheme is a fast and small implementation of\nScheme written in C. It is easy to interface with dynamic libraries\n(since most of the external functions and variables can be declared\ndirectly in Scheme, without any special C coding) and should be easy to\nuse as an extension language.\n\nQscheme supports foreign function call and dynamic library. A\nPerl-like regular expression module is provided as an\nexample. Benchmarks show that it is generally between 2 and 70 times\nfaster than other scheme interpreters. It now intergrates GTK/libglade\nbindings. other features include efficient error and exception\nhandling with catch/throw, support for UNIX scripting,\nnative multithreading support, modular programming support, and a new\nsocket interface so you can build a simple client/server on TCP/IP.

1044	qmail-masq	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/qmail-masq	http://www.giunchi.net/qmail-masq	Masks an internal mail address	'qmail-masq' works with qmail to masquerade the\ninternal mail user's address as an external one when sending email\nfrom local users to the outside world. It's useful when you have an\ninternal qmail mail server that is configured with a nonexistent\ninternet domain or a domain that you don't own; if you send an email\nfrom the internal network the recipient cannot reply (or send new\nmail) because the address doesn't really exist. It's also useful if\nyou own the external domain but you want your personal address to\nshow.\n\nThe program parses all mail if the "From" field is from an internal\nusers and the "To:", "CC", or "BCC" fields are to an external one by\nmodifying the From "field" so the sender's email is changed but the\nname is maintained.  Users can also define "exceptions": mail users\nthat will be masqueraded with a specified address instead of the\ndefault one.	
1045	qexo	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/qexo	http://www.gnu.org/software/qexo/	XQuery to Java compiler	Qexo (Query Expressions for XML Objects aka\nKawa-XQuery) is an implementation of W3C's draft XML query language\nXQuery. XQuery is a high-level expression language whose values are\nsequences of nodes (as in DOM) and simple values. It includes syntax\nfor embedding XML or HTML results, and a 'for' statement comparable to\nSQL's 'select'. This implementation uses the Kawa tools to compile\nXQuery programs to Java bytecodes that can run on any JVM. XQuery\nprograms can run as servlets, as standalone applications, or from the\ncommand-line.\n

1056	pythophotopod	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pythophotopod	http://pythophotopod.sourceforge.net/	Python-based GTK+ GUI for synchronizing photos and photo albums with your pod with a color display	<ul>\n  <li>Create Photo Albums: You can create photo albums. Each album contains images located in a directory on your local disk. PythoPhotoPod automatically synchronizes the photo album with the directory contents. Adding, changing or removing photos in your local directory will be recognized by PythoPhotoPod the next time you update your iPod.\n  </li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n  <li>Manage Photo Albums: Change the order of the photo albums as they are shown in the iPod's photo album list. </li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n  <li>Configure Photo Albums:</li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n  <ul>\n    <li>Configure the name of each album as displayed on your pod.</li>\n    <li>Set directory location of each photo album on your local\nmachine.</li>\n    <li>Optionally photos within the subdirectories of the given album\nlocation can be included.</li>\n\n    <li>A list of file masks can be configured to restrict the album to\nimages of certain type *.jpg:*.gif:*.png.</li>\n    <li>A list of exclude masks can be given to identify images which\nshall not be part of the album (e.g. *.jpg: *_thumb.gif.\n    </li>\n  </ul>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n  <li>Image Options:</li>\n\n</ul>\n<ul>\n  <ul>\n    <li>Zoom option: PythoPhotoPod resizes images to fit your iPod\ndisplay. Normally images are shrunk to fit the entire image in the\niPod's display. This, however, may result in black stripes above/below\nyour\nimage, unless your image exactly matches the aspect ratio of the iPod\ndisplay. When the zoom option is enabled PythoPhotoPod removes black\nstripes by zooming-in the image. As a result the image covers the\nentire iPod display, but image areas at the left and right border may\nbe cut off.</li>\n    <li>Rotate option: Images in upright format (image height is\nlarger than image width) will result in large black stripes at the left\nand right edge of the iPod display. With the rotate option enabled\nPythoPhotoPod rotates such images by 90 degrees. To view such images on\nyour iPod - just turn your iPod by 90 degrees - there you go! This\nworks beautifully with entire albums of such images. The rotate option,\nhowever, will only affect thumb images displayed on your iPod directly.\nThe TV image is not affected by this option (Generally it is less\nconvenient to rotate an entire TV just to have a better view on upright\nformat images, so...).<br>\n    </li>\n  </ul>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n  <li>iPod Preview: When you select an image in an album, PythoPhotoPod will immediately display an image preview. This preview reflects the size and shape of the image as it will be displayed on your iPod.</li>\n\n</ul>\n<ul>\n  <li>Supported image formats: Any image format can be used PythoPhotoPod which is supported by your GTK+ installation. Generally this include bmp, jpeg, gif, png, xpm and a large number of further image formats.<br>\n  </li>\n</ul>\n

1079	pydance	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pydance	http://icculus.org/pyddr/	Free version of DDR	'pydance' is a clone of DDR ("Dance Dance Revolution")\nwritten in Python. There's a mat with four directional arrows, and the\ngame scrolls arrows up the screen to the beat while playing a\nsong. When the arrows reach the top of the screen (not sooner and not\nlater), the player hits the corresponding arrow on the pad, and given\nthat it's hit on time with the beat, points are scored. The player is\ngraded at the end of the song based on how well the dance is put\ntogether. Py DDR supports both keyboard and mat play, so you do not\nneed a mat to play PyDDR.\n\n<P>This package was formerly known as 'PyDDR.'\n

Publimark is a command line tool to secretly embed\ntext in an audio file (i.e. audio steganography). Like cryptography, it uses a pair of keys: the public one can be shared, whereas the private one must be kept secret. Anybody can send a steganographic message, but only the private key owner will be able to read it. Of course, marked audio files are still playable without any noticeable change.\n

1108	pth	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pth	http://www.gnu.org/software/pth/pth.html	GNU Portable Threads library	'Pth' is a portable library that provides\nnon-preemptive priority-based scheduling for multiple threads of\nexecution inside event-driven applications. Threads run in the same\naddress space on the server application, but each one has its own\nindividual program-counter, run-time stack, signal mask and errno\nvariable.\n\nA priority- and event-based non-preemptive scheduler manages the\nthreads; this gives better portability and run-time performance than\npreemptive scheduling. The event facility lets threads wait until\nvarious events occur, including pending I/O on filedescriptors,\nasynchronous signals, elapsed timers, pending I/O on message ports,\nthread and process termination, and customized call back\nfunctions.	
1109	psychopg	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/psychopg	http://initd.org/software/psycopg	PostgreSQL database adapter for Python	psycopg is a PostgreSQL database adapter for the\nPython programming language (just like pygresql and popy). It supports\nthe full Python DBAPI 2.0 and it is thread safe at level 2. It was\ndesigned for heavily multi-threaded applications that create and\ndestroy lots of cursors and make a conspicuous number of concurrent\nINSERTs or UPDATEs. \n\nEvery open Python connection keeps a pool of real (UNIX or TCP/IP)\nconnections to the database. Every time a new cursor is created, one\nof the unused connections from the pool is used instead of a new\nconnection being opened. That makes psycopg very fast in typical\nclient-server applications that create a servicing thread every time a\nclient request arrives.	
1110	psyced	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/psyced	http://www.psyced.org/muve.en.html	Distributed chat &amp;amp;amp; IM system supporting IRC, Jabber, telnet, Web chat, and PSYC.	psyced is a distributed chat and messaging system based on the Protocol for SYnchronous Conferencing. PSYC is multicast and routed between servers and clients in a scalable and efficient way, but users can also comfortably use IRC clients, telnet, Web chat, or Jabber to enter the network. psyced communicates with Jabber/XMPP servers and hosts chat rooms that are freely programmable and cannot be hacked. It also provides gateways to several IRC networks, but unlike IRC, everyone can run a server and be an equal member of the PSYC network.

1117	psmon	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/psmon	http://search.cpan.org/~NICOLAW/psmon/	Process monitor	'psmon' is a script which runs as a stand-alone\nprogram or a fully functional background daemon, capable of logging to\nsyslog with customizable email notification facilities. The user\ndefines a set of rules in a configuration file. These rules describe\nwhat processes should always be running on the system, and any\nlimitations on concurrent instances, TTL, and maximum CPU/memory usage\nof processes. 'psmon' scans the UNIX process table and, using rules\ndefined in the config file, respawns any dead processes, and slays or\n"deals with" any aggressive or illegal processes.\n

1121	psad	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/psad	http://www.cipherdyne.com/	Detects port scans	Port Scan Attack Detector (psad) works with the\nLinux kernel firewalling code (iptables in the 2.4.x kernels, and\nipchains in the 2.2.x kernels) to detect port scans. It has highly\nconfigurable danger thresholds (with sensible defaults provided),\nverbose alert messages that include the source, destination, scanned\nport range, begin and end times, TCP flags and corresponding nmap\noptions (Linux 2.4.x kernels only), email alerting, and automatic\nblocking of offending IP addresses via dynamic configuration of\nipchains/iptables firewall rulesets. \n\nFor the 2.4.x kernels psad incorporates many of the TCP signatures\nincluded in Snort to detect suspect scans for various backdoor\nprograms (e.g. EvilFTP, GirlFriend, SubSeven), DDoS tools (mstream,\nshaft), and advanced port scans (syn, fin, Xmas) can be leveraged\nagainst a machine via nmap.	
1122	ps-watcher	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ps-watcher	http://ps-watcher.sourceforge.net/		'ps-watcher' gets a list of process names via ps,\nand matches them to a list of Perl regular-expression patterns\nspecified in a configuration file. For each match, a Perl expression\nspecified for that pattern is evaluated. The evaluated expression can\nrefer to variables which are set by ps and pertain to the matched\nprocess(es), including the amount memory consumed by the process, or\nthe total elapsed time. If the Perl expression for a matched pattern\nevaluates true, then an action can be run such as killing the program,\nrestarting it, or mailing an alert.\n	
1123	protoize	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/protoize		Creates or removes prototypes from C code	The program 'protoize' is an optional part of GNU\nC. You can use it to add prototypes to a program, thus converting the\nprogram to ANSI C in one respect. The companion program unprotoize\ndoes the reverse: it removes argument types from any prototypes that\nare found.\n\nThe user specifies a set of source files as command line\narguments. The conversion programs then compiles these files to see\nwhat functions they define. The specified files are all eligible to be\nconverted, as are any files they include (whether sources or just\nheaders).  \n\n<p>By default, protoize and unprotoize convert only source and header\nfiles in the current directory. Basic conversion with protoize\nconsists of rewriting most function definitions and function\ndeclarations to specify the types of the arguments. The only ones not\nrewritten are those for varargs functions.\n

1131	programmable_software_ide	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/programmable_software_ide	http://www.whatifwe.com	Developing an enforceable software engineering quality assurance program	The Programmable Code Generator provides a practical, economical means of developing software according to enforceable standard processes and methods.  This is done by first developing a collection of software parts and then using these parts to develop product\nThe Programmable Monte-Carlo Test system provides the capability of rapidly writing, making, and running test programs defined by a random sequence.  This program not only has the capability of testing an executable for proper operation, but also the ability of testing ability of a module or software part in resisting errors made during the development of the product\n	
1132	profoil	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/profoil	http://www.aae.uiuc.edu/m-selig/profoil.html	Wind tunnel data analyzer	PROFOIL-WWW is a Web version of PROFOIL - the\nauthor's low-speed airfoil design code.  PROFOIL is not an all\ninclusive airfoil-design package. Inverse design, as later discussed,\nis its strength; analysis is not - it has none. \n\nThe airfoil performance characteristics (viscous results) are\ndetermined with post-processing analysis tools (the Eppler code, Mark\nDrela's XFOIL, other codes, and finally when things look promising the\nwind tunnel). The Eppler code, XFOIL, the wind tunnel, etc must be\nseparately obtained to complete the design-tool suite.

When a process is created, procwatch reports the time, the\nusername, the PID, and the binary that was run. Its output is suitable\nfor logging to log files and is geared for system administrators who\nare testing a new but as yet untrusted UNIX system. Although it cannot\ndetect, and is not proof against, hacked loadable kernel modules that\nhave modified /proc, it is useful in watching for possible rogue\nbinaries.\n

1152	ppm2html	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ppm2html	http://www.haenselmann.de/homebrew/	Converts an RGB PPM image to an HTML page	'ppm2html' converts an RGB PPM image to an HTML\npage. The page will display an approximated version of the image only\nusing ASCII characters and color definitions. The tool makes full use\nof 24 bit color in HTML. If a 'source string' is being defined this\nstring will repeatedly be used as the character source for rendering\nthe ASCII output. If omitted, random characters between 'a' and 'z'\nwill be used. The 'red', 'green', and 'blue' values define the\nbackground color of the HTML page. If no command line arguments are\ngiven, the page is rendered black.\n\nUser will get the best results by converting segmented objects (the\nbackground of the image is replaced by a single color) and keeping the\nlevel of detail low. A small blur on the image results in a nicer\nvisual appearance, especially when displaying text.  Note that output\nvaries among different browsers; in particular, horizontal scaling\nmight differ a lot. Using unique renderings for each browser yields\nthe best results.

1158	pound	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pound	http://www.apsis.ch/pound/	Reverse HTTP proxy, load balancer, and SSL wrapper	Pound is a reverse HTTP proxy, load balancer, and\nSSL wrapper. It proxies client HTTPS requests to HTTP backend servers,\ndistributes the requests among several servers while keeping sessions,\nsupports HTTP/1.1 requests even if the backend server(s) are HTTP/1.0,\nand sanitizes requests. Pound proxies HTTO _and HTTPS requests\nsimultaneously. In addition, it knows about failed back-end servers\nand can redirect requests according to their availability.\n\nIt can run as setuid/setgid and/or in a chroot jail. Pound does not\naccess the hard-disk at all (except for reading the certificate file\non start, if required, and the pid file) and should thus pose no\nsecurity threat to any machine. It needs at least the configuration\nfile (read-only) and, optionally, the HTTPS server certificate\n(read-only).

1187	pngcheck	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pngcheck	http://www.libpng.org/pub/png/apps/pngcheck.html	PNG integrity tester and dumper/debugger	'Pngcheck' is the official PNG tester and\ndebugger. It verifies the integrity of PNG, JNG and MNG files by\nchecking the internal 32-bit CRCs or checksums, and optionally dumps\nalmost all of the chunk-level information in the image in\nhuman-readable form. For example, it can be used to print the basic\nstats about an image (dimensions, bit depth, etc.); to list the color\nand transparency info in its palette; or to extract the embedded text\nannotations. \n\n<P>Originally designed simply to test the CRCs within a PNG image file\n(e.g., to check for ASCII rather than binary transfer), it has since\nbeen extended to check and optionally print almost all the information\nabout a PNG image and to verify that the image conforms to the PNG\nspecification. The program supports all PNG and JNG chunks, plus\nalmost all MNG chunks (everything but PAST, DISC, tERm, DROP, DBYK,\nand ORDR).\n

1192	pmacct	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pmacct	http://www.ba.cnr.it/~paolo/pmacct/	Gathers IP traffic information	'pmacct' gathers IP traffic information (bytes\ncounter and number of packets). Aggregation of statistics is done\nusing simple primitives (MAC addresses, IP addresses, ports, and IP\nprotocol) that can be used alone or combined together to form complex\naggregation methods. Counters are either global or historical\n(aggregated and separated at fixed timeslots). \n\n<P>Data is stored in an in-memory table or using an SQL database\n(MySQL or PostgreSQL); recovery actions are available to avoid data\nloss during DB failures. Gathering packets off the wire is done using\nthe pcap library; promiscuous mode is only set during online\noperations.\n

1225	pingus	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pingus	http://pingus.seul.org	Pingus is a free Lemmings clone for GNU/Linux	Pingus has started at the end of 1998 with the simple goal to create a Free (as in freedom, not as in free beer) Lemmings clone. It has become  something more than just a clone, it has original artwork, a built-in level editor, new actions, multiplayer and a few other features.\nIf you don't know Lemmings, here comes a short introduction. It's a puzzle game developed in 1991 by DMA Design. The player takes command in the game of a bunch of small animals and has to guide them around in levels. Since the animals walk on their own, the player can only influence them by giving them commands, like build a bridge, dig a hole or redirect all animals in the other direction. The goal of each level is to reach the exit, for fix multiple combination of commands are necessary. The game is presented in a 2D site view.\n	
1226	ping	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ping	http://www.ping127001.com/pingpage.htm	Tests whether or not a give host is online	The Ping utility is essentially a system\nadministrator's tool that is used to see if a computer is operating\nand also to see if network connections are intact. Ping uses the\nInternet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) Echo function.\n\nA small packet is sent through the network to a particular IP\naddress. This packet contains 64 bytes - 56 data bytes and 8 bytes of\nprotocol reader information. The computer that sent the packet then\nwaits (or 'listens') for a return packet. If the connections are good\nand the target computer is up, a good return packet will be\nreceived. PING can also tell the user the number of hops that lie\nbetween two computers and the amount of time it takes for a packet to\nmake the complete trip. Additionaly, an administrator can use Ping to\ntest out name resolution. If the packet bounces back when sent to the\nIP address but not when sent to the name, then the system is having a\nproblem matching the name to the IP address.

1240	phylographer	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/phylographer	http://atgc.org/PhyloGrapher/PhyloGrapher_Welcome.html	Visualizes evolutionary relationships	PhyloGrapher helps you visualize and study\nevolutionary relationships within families of homologous genes or\nproteins (elements). It is a drawing tool that generates custom graphs\nfor the given set of elements. It can be used to visualize any type of\ninteractions between elements you want.\n\nEach gene or protein on a graph is represented as a colored node\n(vertex) and connected to other nodes (vertices) by lines (edges) of\nvariable thickness and color based on the similarity of genes or\nproteins (distance matrix). The user positions these nodes in such a\nway as to optimize visualization of the inter-relationships between\nthe nodes. Unlike classical phylogenetic trees, the physical distances\non the graph between nodes have no information content. The level of\nsimilarity between genes or proteins on PhyloGrapher's graphs is\nindicated by color and line thickness.

Using the combination of\nhardware/software you can control (ie flip on and off) nearly any 120v\ndevice. With a little bit of electronics know-how, you can probably\ncontrol nearly any device at any voltage by modifying the circuit\nboards to meet your needs. The simple circuit included can be created\nand built for around $25.00. The modules cost around $10.00 (basically\na heavy duty relay).\n\nPhantom Home is now compatible with HDML, so if you have an HDML\nwireless phone you can use it to operate the system.	
1304	pgreet	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pgreet	http://pgreet.sourceforge.net/	Internet greeting card application	Penguin Greetings implements Internet greeting\ncards by making them more like email. Cards are sent as multipart MIME\nemail. The text of the card is included and the Reply-to field\ncontains the card sender's email so recipients can reply to the card\neven with a text-only email client. The HTML for the cards and the\ncreation screens are stored in templates so users can easily customize\nthe program.\n\nPenguin Greetings incorporates Embperl so that full Perl\nexpressions can be incorporated into templates for server-side\nprocessing. A separate daemon program carries out the\nemailing function and data storage, so you can mail cards on specific\ndates and improve security and logging.	
1305	pgrd	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pgrd	http://pgrd.sourceforge.net	A tool that allows users to control which programs have access to the Internet.	Program Guard allows the user of a Linux\nworkstation to specify which applications are\nallowed to make TCP/IP connections to the\nInternet. Application program names can be\nspecified by listing them in a file (Static Mode)\nor by querying the user (Query Mode). In Query\nMode, connection attempts by unknown programs\nresult in a Program Guard dialog box being\ndisplayed. In addition to providing connection\ninformation, this gives the workstation user the\noption of allowing or blocking the program either\nfor the current instance of the program or for all\nfuture instances. It consists of a daemon, a\nkernel module, and a GUI interface component and\nmakes use of the Linux Netfilter interface.\n

1318	perl-reference	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/perl-reference	http://www.student.lu.se/~nbi98oli/perl-reference.html	Displays Perl reference documentation	Perl-reference is a program to quickly display\nreference documentation for a Perl function, variable, regexp\noperator, or language keyword. This documentation is generated from\nthe default Perl POD files, namely perlfunc, perlop, and\nperlvar. Unlike perldoc, perl-reference relies on documentation\ngenerated at compile-time, which results in a much higher response\ntime.\n\nIt consists of two parts, mkperlreference and pf. 'mkperlreference' is\nrun once during compile-time to create a cache of the Perl POD\ndocumentation. This cache consists of plain text files, one for each\nfunction, variable, regexp operator and language keyword in\nPerl. These files are usually installed in /usr/share/perl-reference.\n'pf' displays the generated documentation by finding the right cached\nfile and writing its contents to a pager or standard output.

1321	pen	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pen	http://siag.nu/pen/	Load balancer for TCP protocols	Pen is a load balancer for "simple" TCP-based\nprotocols such as HTTP or SMTP. It allows several servers to appear as\none to the outside. It automatically detects servers that are down and\ndistributes clients among the available server for high availability\nand scalable performance.\n\nThe load balancing algorithm tracks clients and tries to send them\nback to the server they visited the last time. The client table has\nslots (default 2048, settable through command-line arguments). When\nthe table is full, the least recently used one is discarded to make\nroom for the new one. This is superior to a simple round-robin\nalgorithm, which sends a client that connects repeatedly to different\nservers. This breaks applications including most modern web\napplications) that maintain state between server connections.

Diagnostics are made not\nonly based on single network events but whether the network sounds\n'normal.' Peep's primary focus is network monitoring, but its\nmonitoring mechanism is general enough that a Peep system can be\nadapted to monitor just about anything.\n\n<P>Peep includes server software, various client utilities, and a\nclient library which can also be used to create new clients. 1331	pdns-recursor	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pdns-recursor	http://www.powerdns.com	An advanced, high-performance, and secure recursing nameserver.	With a small codebase, the PowerDNS Recursor is an advanced recursor currently serving the DNS resolving needs of over 2 million Internet connections. Besides high performance (using kqueue or epoll, over 15 thousand qps on commodity hardware), it provides advanced anti-spoofing measures. In addition, the program caches server performance and timeouts, making it both network and user friendly. It also has built-in hooks for making graphs with rrdtool, providing insight into nameserver performance.

1345	pcb	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pcb	http://bach.ece.jhu.edu/~haceaton/pcb/	Designs printed circuit board layouts 	PCB is a simple tool, without memory and time\nconsuming fuctions like autorouter and auto placement, for designing\nprinted circuit boards. Most settings can be specified by resources,\npassed in the command line or changed at runtime. Layout related\nsettings are saved together with the data.\n\nEach layout has a unique name and color (if supported by your\ndisplay); 8 layers are supported in addition to a silkscreen\nlayer. You can control the visibility of pins and SMD pads. All files\nare 7 bit ASCII and can be preprocessed with any UNIX command that\nwrites its results to stdout (GNU m4 is required). The layout grid\nranges from 1/1000 inch up to 250/1000 inch; the maximum is defined at\ncompilation time. Zooming is supported.

The\nsmallest debt is given extra money (20% of what is\navailable), and when it is paid off, the amount is\nredistributed to the other payments using the\nratio of debt/total debt and the same 80% of what\nis available, with the 20% being added to the new\nsmallest debt.\n

1358	patchutils	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/patchutils	http://cyberelk.net/tim/patchutils/	Tools for manipulating patch files	Patchutils contains the following tools for\nmanipulating patch files: interdiff, combinediff, filterdiff,\nfixcvsdiff, rediff, lsdiff, and splitdiff. You can use \n\n<ul>\n\t    <li>interdiff- creates an incremental patch from two patches\n\t\t       against a common source</li>\n\t    <li>combinediff- creates a single patch from two incremental patches </li>\n\t    <li>filterdiff- selects patches based on files matching shell wildcards</li>\n\t    <li>lsdiff- lists modified files in a patch </li>\n\t    <li>rediff- corrects hand-edited patches</li>\n\t    <li>fixcvsdiff- corrects the output of 'cvs diff'</li>\n\t    <li>splitdiff- separates patches so that each new file alters\n\t\t       a given file only once</li>\n</ul>\n

1372	panorama	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/panorama	http://panorama.sourceforge.net/	Framework for 3D graphics production	'Panorama' includes modeling, rendering, and\npost-processing; animation support will be added soon. It is\nstructured as an API composed of two dynamic lib and several\nplug-ins. It currently includes a console mode front end, but a\ngraphical interface is also being developed. Users can use other\ninterfaces, as long as they use the Panorama API or output some scene\nlanguage that Panorama can read.\n\nPlug-in architecture lets you load just the components you need;\nthese components can be substituted or added to without recompiling.\nThis allows for better interaction of modules and makes the program\nrun faster. Several rendering methods (including raytracing and\nzbuffer) are available without any other change in the input scene\nfile. A post-processing system lets you apply filters to the whole\nimage after it has been generated by the renderer; there are also\nobject filters, which you apply to an object during the rendering\nprocess. Material have a BSDF that encapsulates its properties with\nrespect to the light.

1376	pan	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/pan	http://pan.rebelbase.com/	Threaded newsreader for GNOME 	Pan supports article reading, writing, and\nreplying via usenet or e-mail. Articles can be organized by thread,\nand sorted by author, date, subject, or the number of unread children\nin the thread. They can be filtered by regular expression matching,\nread/unread state, binary/text,etc; groups can also be filtered by\nsubscribe/new/all. Killfiles let you specify authors and thread that\nyou never want to see. The program caches article headers locally for fast\ngroup loading, and you can queue selected articles, threads and entire\ngroups for offline reading.  Pan also supports multiple connections, so you\ncan read articles while downloading binaries.\n\nPan also works well with binaries: it supports single-click decoding,\nopening, or saving of binary messages, automatically groups multipart\narticles together, and supports multiple connections (so you can\ndownload many binaries at once). You can filter nonbinary, incomplete,\nand previously saved messages out of the article list. The task\nmanager lets you cancel, resubmit, and reorder download tasks.

It makes additional checks upon password changes,\nbut it doesn't make the change itself. It only provides functionality\nfor one PAM management group: password changing. This module works in\nthe following manner: if enabled it calls at first the Cracklib\nroutine to check the strength of the password; if crack likes the\npassword, the module does an additional set of strength checks.\n

1384	packet2sql	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/packet2sql	http://sourceforge.net/projects/packet2sql/	Converts files with ipchains packet logs to SQL inserts	Packet2sql will convert any text file/log file\nwhich contains ipchains packet logs into a stream of SQL inserts. The\nSQL can be saved into a file and used as a query to any SQL-92\ncompliant database. This can even be done on-the-fly from syslogd\ndirectly to the database. 1387	p2c	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/p2c	http://packages.debian.org/unstable/devel/p2c.html	Translates Pascal programs into C	P2c is a tool for translating Pascal programs into\nC. The input consists of a set of source files in any of the following\nPascal dialects: HP Pascal, Turbo/UCSD Pascal, DEC VAX Pascal, Oregon\nSoftware Pascal/2, Macintosh Programmer's Workshop Pascal,\nSun/Berkeley Pascal, Texas Instruments Pascal, Apollo Domain\nPascal. Modula-2 syntax is also supported.\n\nOutput is a set of .c and .h files that comprise an equivalent program\nin any of several dialects of C. Output code may be kept machine and\ndialect-independent, or it may be targeted to a specific machine and\ncompiler. Most reasonable Pascal programs are converted into fully\nfunctional C which will compile and run with no further modifications,\nalthough p2c sometimes chooses to generate readable code at the\nexpense of absolute generality.\n

1390	p	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/p	http://www.poojyum.com/p	A bunch of particles interact with each other according to simple rules. And complex behaviour emerg	In p, a bunch of particles interact with each other according to this simple rule: every particle moves towards, away, or watches another particle(s). When the program starts, each particle chooses a random color, position, and the particle(s) it will move towards, away, or watch. As the program runs, some particles join together to form a train and journey together thereafter. Some orbit each other. Some collapse into each other. Some form swarms that split and join. One cannot predict when or where or how many of these behaviours will emerge but they usually do.

1399	otl	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/otl	http://outl.sourceforge.net/	A flexible, customizable text processor for generating markup from simple text	otl is intended to convert a text file to a HTML or XHTML file. It is different than many other text-to-HTML programs in that the input format (by default a simple highly readable plain text format) can be customized by the user, and the output format (by default XHTML) can be user-defined. It can process complex structures such as ordered and unordered lists (nested or not), and add custom &amp;quot;headers&amp;quot; and &amp;quot;footers&amp;quot; to documents. The conversion utilizes Perl regex, adding quite a bit of flexibility and power to the conversion process. Since both the syntax of the source file and of the output can be readily customized, otl in theory can be used for many types of conversions. The package also includes tag-remove, a script for stripping HTML/XHTML-ish tags from documents.

1402	osip	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/osip	http://www.gnu.org/software/osip/	Library supporting the Session Initiation Protocol	This is the oSIP library (for Omnibus SIP), which\nconsists of a parser and a transaction manager. It gives multimedia\nand telecom software developers an easy and powerful interface to\ninitiate and control Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) based sessions\nin their applications. SIP is described in the RFC2543 which is\navailable at http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2543.txt.  The oSIP home page\nincludes links to various useful SIP sites.\n\n'oSIP' is little in size and code and thus could be use to\nimplement IP soft-phone as well as embedded SIP software. oSIP is not\nlimited to endpoint agents, and can also be used to implement "SIP\nproxy".  It does not intend to provide a high layer API for\ncontrolling "SIP Session" at this step. Instead, it currently provides\nan API for the SIP message parser, SDP message parser, and library to\nhandle "SIP transactions" as defined by the SIP document.

These are used to build a wealth of: solvers, to simulate specific problems in engineering mechanics; utilities, to perform pre- and post-processing tasks ranging from simple data manipulations to visualisation and mesh processing; libraries, to create toolboxes that are accessible to the solvers/utilities, such as libraries of physical models. \n

OpenEMR is a medical practice management, electronic medical records, prescription writing, and medical billing application. It is a replacement for medical applications such as Medical Manager, Health Pro, and Misys. It features support for EDI billing to clearing houses such as ProxyMed and ZirMED using ANSI X12.  Medical claim and accounts receivable are accomplished through SQL-Ledger, which has been customized.  Calendar features include categories for appointment types, colors associated with appointment types, repeating appointments, and the ability to restrict appointments based on type.  There is an advanced medical claim management interface, accounting for EOB entry, customization to work with a clearing house for automated 835 or ERA entry against outstanding medical claims, customizable medical encounter forms, support for voice recognition software, electronic or scanned digital document management for records, and support for HL7 messages.

Input is a description of the\ncommand line options you want your program to support. Output is a C\nor C++ function which finds these options in an array of strings\n(typically "argv", the second parameter of the "main" function) and\nsets variables accordingly. \n\n<P>The package supports both short (single character) and long (GNU\nstyle) options. Users can also associate a help string with each\noption. Opag uses these to create a macro which expands to a string\ncontaining a nicely formatted description of the options.\n

1444	onsight	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/onsight	http://onsight.sourceforge.net/	Turn-based multiplayer game	'OnSight' is a turn-based multiplayer game that\nfeatures a turn based game engine, simple game rules, 2 or more human\nplayers, 5 predefined game maps, and 2 recorded game sessions to learn\nfrom.\n\n<P>It differs from classic turn-based strategy (TBS) games in that a\nplayer who has suffered losses can still win. In most games, the\nplayer who loses a unit has instantly fewer possibilities to win the\ngame. He can't recover his previous situation but he has to work with\nwhat he has got. In OnSight, every player always has a theoretical\npossibility of gaining more units and (possibly) a dominating position\nin the game. This is possible because the game units in OnSight never\ndie; they only change sides. Even with a single unit against ten\nopposing units, a player might still convert opposing units to his\nside and thus obtain the dominating position.\n	
1445	online_grades	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/online_grades	http://onlinegrades.sourceforge.net/	Online Grades is free software allows schools post grade information online using exports from sever	Online Grades allows K-12+ student grades to be posted onto a dynamic web site. Online Grades is not a web-based gradebook. Instead, it accepts grade export information from several popular gradebook software programs such as Easy Grade Pro, Gradekeeper, Misty City's Grade Machine, and PGGP and places the grade information online securely.\nStudent, Teachers, Parents, and Administrators each get their own personal login into Online Grades, which allows them to see all of the grades in all of their classes. If parents have more than one student at a school or district, they only need one parent login to see the grades of all of their students.\n\nThe Online Grades software is free; there is no software cost to post your grade results online. However, to use the software, both an internet-accessible web server with PHP and access to a MySQL database are necessary. Because of these requirements, Online Grades is commonly set up and configured by a school or district tech person. If your school or district does not have the resources to set up Online Grades, you can alternatively buy hosting for your grades. Hosting is even available for individual teachers interested in using Online Grades.\n\nOnline Grades is free because the software is developed by volunteers and is in-part sponsored by the schools using the Online Grades software. Online Grades was originally based on the SourceForge project Basmati, and while backward compatibility has been maintained, Online Grades has many more features than the original Basmati grade posting software.\n

This puts Vorbis in the\nsame class as audio representations including MPEG-1, audio layer 3,\nMPEG-s audio (AAC and TwinVQ) and PAC.\n\nVorbis can both encode and decode as a single pass, real-time\nstream, and requires roughly the same encoding and decoding power as\nmp3. 1456	oftpd	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/oftpd		Highly secure anonymous FTP server	'oftpd' is designed to be as secure as an anonymous\nFTP server can possibly be. You can read\nIMAP mail with readers that lack IMAP support\n(same goes for SSL). 1461	octopus	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/octopus	http://www.tddft.org/programs/octopus	Electronic structure based on time-dependent density functional theory	'octopus' is a computer package for the simulation\nof the electron-ion dynamics of finite systems in one and three\ndimensions under the influence of time-dependent electromagnetic\nfields. The electronic degrees of freedom are treated quantum\nmechanically within the time-dependent Kohn-Sham formalism, while the\nions are handled classically. All quantities are expanded in a regular\nmesh in real-space; the simulations are performed in real-time.\n\n<P>'octopus' can also obtain static properties like ground-state\ngeometries or static polarizabilities although it is not optimzed for\nthis). The method employed proved quite reliable and general, and has\nbeen successfully used to calculate linear and non-linear absorption\nspectra, harmonic spectra, laser induced fragmentation, etc. of a\nvariety of systems, from small clusters to medium sized quantum dots.\n	Intermediate

It is intended\nto run on desktop systems as a reliable and fast\ndownload manager without the overhead of a\ngraphical user interface, but it can also be used\nas a centralized download station running in\nnetwork environments with multiple users. To\ncontrol the daemon, an easy and self-explanatory\nnetwork protocol has been defined, so\ncross-platform, cross-language graphical clients\n(based on ncurses, Qt, Gtk, or even HTML/PHP) can\nbe implemented.\n

The database included is the USDA\nNutrient Database for Standard Reference, Release 14, which contains\n6,039 foods. This database contains values for calories, protein,\ncarbohydrates, fiber, total fat, etc.; vitamins A, thiamin,\nriboflavin, niacin, pantothenic acid, B6, etc.; minerals calcium,\ncopper, iron etc.; as well as the omega-6 and omega-3 polyunsaturated\nfatty acids. \n\nNutrient levels are expressed as a percentage of the Daily Value,\nwhich comprise Reference Daily Intake and Daily Reference Values, the\nfamiliar standard of food labeling in the United States.

1478	numdiff	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/numdiff	http://www.nongnu.org/numdiff	Numdiff compares putatively similar files line by line and field by field, ignoring small numeric di	Numdiff is a program with the capability to appropriately compare files containing numerical fields (and not only). By default, Numdiff assumes the fields are separated by white spaces (blanks, horizontal tabulations and newlines), but the user can also specify its list of separators.\nWhen you compare a couple of such files, what you want to obtain usually is a list of the numerical fields in the second file which numerically differ from the corresponding fields in the first file. Well known tools like diff, cmp or wdiff can not be used to this purpose: they can not recognize whether a difference between two numerical fields is only due to the notation or is actually a difference of numerical values. Moreover, you could desire to neglect all small numerical differences too. However, programs like diff and wdiff can not be used to ignore small numerical differences, since they do not even know what a numerical difference is.\n

It prints names in both the American\nand European naming system, and can print the decimal expansion of a\nnumber in either naming system.\n

1484	nsbd	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/nsbd	http://www.bell-labs.com/project/nsbd/	Automated software distribution system	Not-So-Bad Distribution is an automated Web-based\ndistribution system designed for distributing free software on\nthe internet, where users cannot trust the network and cannot entirely\ntrust the software maintainers. NSBD authenticates packages with GNU\nPrivacy Guard (GnuPG) or "Pretty Good(Tm) Privacy" (PGP(Tm)) digital\nsignatures so users can be assured that packages have not been\ntampered with, and it limits the maintainer to only update selected\nfiles and directories on the user's computer. NSBD's focus is on\nsecurity, leaving as much control as is practical in the users' hands.\n\nNSBD handles automated updates by supplying a means of checking\nfor updates to packages and automatically downloading and installing\nthe updates. This "automated pull" style of distribution has the same\neffect as the "push" style of distribution, but gives more control to\nthe user. A direct "push" style is also supported, which is especially\nappropriate for situations where there are multiple contributors to a\nshared server (for example, a shared web-page server). NSBD can "pull"\ndirectly over http or by using rsync to minimize network usage.\n

1487	nosql	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/nosql	http://www.strozzi.it/cgi-bin/CSA/tw7/I/en_US/NoSQL/Home+Page	Relational database management system for UNIX	NoSQL is a fast, portable relational database\nmanagement system without arbitrary limits (other than memory or\nprocessor speed) that runs under, and interacts with, the UNIX\nOperating system.\n\nIt uses the Operator/Stream DBNS paradigm described in "UNIX Review,"\nMarch 1991 Page 24, entitled "A 4GL Language." There are a number of\n'operators' that each perform a unique function on the data. The\n"stream" is supplied by the UNIX Input/Output redirection\nmechanism. Therefore, each operator p[rocesses some data and then\npasses it along to the next operator via the Unix pipe function. This\nis very efficient as UNIX pipes are implemented in memory. It is very\nportable, and aims to produce small executables that run in small\namounts of memory. It produces medium-fast code, and compilation is\nitself quite fast. It also comes with extensive tool support for\nautomatic compilation, foreign language interfacing, heap and time\nprofiling, tracing, and debugging. (Some of its advanced kinds of heap\nprofiles are not found in any other Haskell compiler.)\n\nIt supports the new common primitive FFI (Foreign Function Interface), \nand includes the most advanced space-profiling facilities of all Haskell\nimplementations. Most importantly, it allows graphical debugging of\nprograms using both Hat and HOOD.\n\nnhc98 is available for all 32-bit Unix-like platforms.  Although it is \nitself written in standard Haskell 98, it can be quickly and easily be\nbootstrapped from C sources, so you do not\nneed another Haskell compiler to get started.\n

1520	nexuiz	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/nexuiz	http://www.nexuiz.com	Nexuiz is a 3d deathmatch game project, created online by a team of developers called Alientrap.	Nexuiz has been in development for close to 5 years by a team of amateur developers lead by Lee Vermeulen. It is a 3d deathmatch game made entirely over the internet. The purpose of the game is to bring deathmatch back to the basics, with perfect weapon balancing and fast paced action, keeping itself away from the current trend of realistic shooters. It uses HFX textures by Evil Lair, and currently has 17 maps to frag in. With an advanced UI, the user can select between 15 different player models to use, with an average of two skins for each, and can connect to our master server to play people from all over the world.\nThe game's content and source are GPL. Meaning, it is entirely free and any of it can be used in other free projects, even if modified. This is a first for any large game project of its type. We hope this will support the free game community, and encourage more GPL projects.\n\nNexuiz is based on the Darkplaces engine. The darkplaces engine is an advanced Quake1 engine developed mainly by Forest "LordHavoc" Hale, who has been working with the Quake1 engine for many years. A few of Darkplaces main features are Quake3bsp support, realtime lighting and shadowing, new particle effects, advanced menu system, and Md3/Md2 model support. Because Nexuiz is based on the Quake1 engine, its source code along with its content is entirely GPL. Nexuiz will also use the Quake1 game code language, called QuakeC, which makes modding the gameplay of the game extremely easy. This gamecode will be included with the release, and will allow anyone to mod it, and because it is entirely serverside you can use it on your servers even if the clients do not have your mod.\n	
1521	newts	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/newts		News-like program designed for use as a message board	Newts is a notesfile program, a news-like program\nfor use as a message board. Newts is designed for *NIX-like systems,\nand resembles the Notesfiles program written early in the 1980s at the\nUniversity at Urbana-Champaign. The client program included emulates\nthe look and feel of Notesfiles, and the UIUC backend is compatible\nwith Notesfiles data files. Future versions of Newts will include a\nseparate daemon to manage multiple local and network connections,\nadditional backends, and additional clients.\n	
1522	newsstar	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/newsstar	http://newsstar.sourceforge.net/	Downloads and posts news	Newsstar fetches news and posts it to a local news\nserver: INN and sn are supported. The program can make multiple\nsimultaneous connections, not only to one server, but to several,\nsupporting up to 10 "threads". Before fetching each article, it checks\nthat it hasn't already been downloaded by another thread or in a\nprevious session. It can also "pipeline" article requests to make more\nefficient use of bandwidth.\n

1531	networkmanager	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/networkmanager	http://people.redhat.com/dcbw/NetworkManager/	Program to provide a persistent network connection	 Networking on GNU/Linux should not suck like it does right now for the desktop user. The desktop user should never need to use the command-line to configure their network; it should "Just Work" as automatically as possible and intrude as little as possible into the users workflow. The computer should use the wired network connection when its plugged in, but automatically switch to a wireless connection when the user unplugs it and walks away from the desk. Likewise, when the user plugs the computer back in, the computer should switch back to the wired connection. The user should, most times, not even notice that their connection has has been managed for them; they should simply see uninterrupted network connectivity.

1534	nettle	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/nettle	http://www.lysator.liu.se/~nisse/nettle/	Cryptographic library	Nettle is a cryptographic library designed to fit\nany context: in crypto toolkits for object-oriented languages, in\napplications like LSH or GNUPG, or even in kernel space. Users need to\nkeep track of available algorithms and their properties and\nvariants. The algorithm selection process is dictated by the protocol\nyou want to implement. Also, requirements of applications differ, so\nan API that fits one application well may be useless for another\n(which is why so many different cryptographic libraries exist).\n\nNettle avoids this problem by doing one thing, the low-level crypto\nstuff, and providing a simple but general interface to it. In\nparticular, it doesn't do algorithm selection, memory allocation, or\nany I/O. However, users can build application- and context-specific\ninterfaces on top of Nettle and share code, testcases, benchmarks,\ndocumentation, etc.	Intermediate
1535	netsukuku	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/netsukuku	http://netsukuku.freaknet.org/	A P2P network system	Netsukuku is a mesh network or a P2P net system that generates and sustains itself autonomously. It is designed to handle an unlimited number of nodes with minimal CPU and memory resources. Thanks to this feature it can be easily used to build a worldwide distributed, anonymous and anarchical network, separated from the Internet, without the support of any servers, ISPs or authority controls. Keep in mind that it is a _physical network_, it isn't built upon any other existing net, therefore there must be computers linked _physically_ each other, then Netsukuku will build the routes. For more information read the section "2.4  So, WTF is it?" of the document.

1537	netrw	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/netrw	http://www.fi.muni.cz/~xdenemar/_en/netrw/	Transports data over the Internet	'netrw' is a simple (but powerful) tool for\ntransporting data over the Internet. Its simplifies and speeds up file\ntransfers to hosts without an FTP server. It can also be used for\nuploading data to another user. It is something like one-way netcat\n(nc) with some nice features concerning data transfers. It computes\nand checks message digests (MD5, SHA-1, and some others) of the data\nbeing transferred, and prints information on progress and average\nspeed. At the end, it sums up the transfer.\n

Presently, netrik\nhas all what is necessary for basic web browsing; none of the advanced\nfeatures are present yet. There are already a few nice little goodies,\nthough.

1572	nail	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/nail	http://nail.sourceforge.net/	MIME-capable mail user agent for *nix systems	"Nail' is a MIME-capable mail user agent derived\nfrom Berkeley Mail 8.1. With\nappropriate support, it can convert between different character\nencodings. When used with a UTF-8 terminal, it supports nearly all\ninternational languages. It also supports external converter programs.\n\n<P>'Nail' also supports SMTP to send messages directly to a remote\nserver (so a local sendmail interface setup is not necessary). It\nsupports POP3 to read messages on a remove server. Nail can read and\ndelete individual messages, so POP3 accounts can be accessed almost\nlike local mail folders.\n

1578	mythtv	2010-05-03 16:09:21	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/mythtv	http://www.mythtv.org	A multi-function PVR	<P>MythTV is a GPL licensed suite of programs that allow you to build the\nmythical home media convergence box on your own using free and open source software\nand operating systems.</P>\n<P>MythTV has a number of capabilities.  The television portion allows you to\ndo the following:\n<UL>\n<LI>You may pause, fast-forward and rewind live Television.</LI>\n<LI>You may install multiple video capture cards to record more than one\nprogram at a time.</LI>\n<LI>You can have multiple servers, each with multiple capture cards in\nthem.  All servers are centrally managed and all programs are scheduled by the\nMaster backend.</LI>\n\n<LI>You can have multiple clients (called "frontends" in MythTV parlance),\neach with a common view of all available programs.  Any client can watch any\nprogram that was recorded by any of the servers.  Clients can be diskless\nand controlled entirely by a remote control.</LI>\n<LI>You may use any combination of standard analog capture card, MPEG-2,\nMJPEG, DVB or HDTV capture devices.  With appropriate hardware, MythTV can\ncontrol set top boxes, often found in digital cable and satellite TV\nsystems.</LI>\n<LI>Program Guide Data in North America is downloaded from Zap2It.com, a\nsubsidiary of Tribune Media Services.  This free service is called\nDataDirect, and provides MythTV almost two weeks of scheduling information. \nProgram Guide Data in other countries is obtained using XMLTV.  MythTV uses\nthis information to create a schedule that maximizes the number of programs\nthat can be recorded if you don't have enough tuners.</LI>\n</UL>\n\nOther modules in MythTV include:\n<UL>\n<LI>MythGallery, a picture-viewing application</LI>\n<LI>MythVideo, a media-viewer for content not created within MythTV</LI>\n<LI>MythDVD, a DVD viewer / ripper</LI>\n<LI>MythMusic, a music playing / ripping application which supports MP3\nand FLAC</LI>\n\n<LI>MythGame</LI>\n<LI>MythWeather</LI>\n<LI>MythNews, a RSS news grabber</LI>\n<LI>MythBrowser, a web browser</LI>\n<LI>MythWeb, which allows you to control your MythTV system using a web\nbrowser.  With MythWeb, you can schedule recordings, delete files, change\nkeybindings and more.  With proper security, you may even schedule a program\nover the Internet and have it immediately acted on by the scheduler.</LI>\n<LI>MythPhone, phone and videophone using SIP.</LI>\n</UL>\n</P>\n
