1636	msort	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/msort	http://billposer.org/Software/msort.html	Sophisticated and flexible sort program	Msort sorts files in sophisticated ways. Records may \nbe fixed size, newline-separated blocks, or terminated by any specified \ncharacter. Key fields may be selected by position, tag, or character \nrange. For each key, distinct exclusions, multigraphs, substitutions, \nand a sort order may be defined or locale collation rules used. \nComparisons may be lexicographic, numeric, numeric string, hybrid, \nrandom, by string length, angle, date, time, month name, or ISO8601 \ntimestamp. Keys may be reversed so as to generate reverse dictionaries. \nOptional keys are supported. Unicode is supported, including full \ncase-folding. Msort itself has a somewhat complex command line \ninterface, but may be driven by an optional GUI.\n

1669	mozart	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/mozart	http://mozart-dev.sourceforge.net/	Framework for compiler development	A framework for developing user-extensible\ncompilers and development tools. In its current state, it contains a\nJava to Java extensible compiler called Moka, considered in "beta"\nphase, and a compiler for a language called LX, in "pre-alpha" stage.\nIt was designed with large and sophiticated software projects in\nmind. \n\nMozart uses the idea of "concept programming," which makes\ndevelopment tools extensible, so that they understand the concepts of\nyour application. You can describe the concepts to the development\ntools, and they become entities that you can manipulate the same way\nas built-in entities. Multiple development tools, including small and\n"custom" ones, can exchange program-related information in a unified\nformat, either through persistent storage (files) or directly in\nmemory.\n

For distribution, Mozart\nprovides a true network transparent implementation with support for\nnetwork awareness, openness, and fault tolerance.  Security is upcoming.\nMozart is an ideal platform for both general-purpose distributed\napplications as well as for hard problems requiring sophisticated\noptimization and inferencing abilities.\n

1675	mosshe	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/mosshe	http://www.wyae.de/software/mosshe/	A lightweight, secure server monitoring system.	MoSSHe (MOnitoring with SSH Environment) is a simple, lightweight (both in size and system requirements) server monitoring package designed for secure and in-depth monitoring of a number of typical Internet systems. It was developed to keep the impact on network and performance low, and to use a safe, encrypted connection for in-depth inspection of the system checked. It is not possible to remotely run (more or less arbitrary) commands via the monitoring system, nor is unsafe cleartext SNMP messaging necessary (yet possible). A read-only Web interface makes monitoring and status checks simple (and safe) for admins and helpdesk. Checking scripts are included for remote services (DNS, HTTP, IMAP2, IMAP3, POP3, samba, SMTP, and SNMP) and local systems (disk space, load, CPU temperature, fan speed, free memory, print queue size and activity, processes, RAID status, shells, log file events (logins, restarts, and brute force attacks), and mail queue).

1688	mon	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/mon	http://www.kernel.org/software/mon/	Scheduler and alert management tool	'mon' is a general-purpose scheduler and alert\nmanagement tool used for monitoring service availability and\ntriggering alerts upon failure detection. It supports arbitrary\nmonitoring facilities and alert methods via a common interface, all of\nwhich are easily implemented with programs in C, Perl, shell, etc.,\nSNMP traps, and special mon traps.\n\n<P>'mon' views resource monitoring as two separate tasks: the testing\nof a condition, and triggering an action upon failure. It implements\neach task as separate, stand-alone programs. mon is fundamentally a\nscheduler which executes the monitors (each test a specific\ncondition), and calls the appropriate alerts if the monitor fails. The\ndecision to invoke an alert is governed by logic which offers various\n"squelch" features and dependencies.\n

1697	mod_tidy	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/mod_tidy	http://mod-tidy.sourceforge.net/	mod_tidy is a TidyLib based DSO module for the Apache HTTP Server Version 2 to parse, clean-up and p	mod_tidy works as a filter that hooks up to the (X)HTML output of an Apache 2 webserver. It passes the webservers' (X)HTML output to TidyLib which parses and optional cleans-up and pretty-prints that output. If TidyLib detects an error, the client receives a HTML page with a list of all found errors and warnings that prevent the input of being a valid (X)HTML document. If TidyLib doesn't complain, the client will get and display the (X)HTML data as without mod_tidy.\nDue to the fact that mod_tidy may affect little response delays of the webserver, its use should be reduced to a developer framework only. mod_tidy is not recommended to be used in a production environment, where response delays of the webserver are undesirable.\n

The compiler runs on the Linux platform\nand targets the x86 architecture.\n\nThe MLKit includes a graphical region profiler, which helps gain\ndetailed control over memory reuse. The example graph to the right\nshows a region profile (region sizes as a function of time) of two\nhundred generations of the `Game of Life'.  Programmers who are\ninterested in real-time programming can exploit the possibility of\ndisabling reference-tracing garbage collection. 1730	minpair	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/minpair	http://www.cis.upenn.edu/~wjposer/minpair.html	Generates a list of minimal pairs	'minpair' generates a list of minimal pairs (words\ndiffering in exactly one segment) from a list of words. The input\nshould consist of one word per line in UTF-8 Unicode. The output lists\nthe two segments contrasting in the minimal pair, then the two words,\nand then the context for the difference. The segments differing are\nlisted in a order of the character codes so that all tokens of the\nsame pair will sort together.\n\n<P>By default minpair searches only for pairs of words of the same\nlength differing in exactly one segment. Users can optionally add\nsingle insertions, deletions and transpositions.\n

1742	mifluz	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/mifluz	http://www.gnu.org/software/mifluz/	Full text inverted index query library	The purpose of mifluz is to provide a C++ library\nto build and query a full text inverted index. It is dynamically\nupdatable, scalable (up to 1Tb indexes), uses a controlled amount of\nmemory, shares index files and memory cache among processes or threads\nand compresses index files to 50% of the raw data. \n\n<P>The structure of the index is configurable at runtime and allows\ninclusion of relevance ranking information. The query functions do not\nrequire to load all the occurences of a searched term. They consume\nvery few resources and many searches can be run in parallel.\n

1748	miau	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/miau	http://miau.sourceforge.net/	IRC bouncer	'miau' is a small, fully featured IRC\nbouncer. Features include so-called quicklogging, logging,\nauto-opping, and dcc-bouncing. Most features can be enabled/disabled\nwith a configure script. \n\n<P>'miau' offers a service a bit like HTTP-proxy, but for IRC\nnetworks. The difference is that when IRC-client disconnects from\nbouncer, the connection to the server isn't necessarily lost, so your\nnick can stay online and cannot be taken by the others. In case\nbouncer does loses the nick, it can try to get it back automatically.\nAlso, when using bouncer, the hostname appearing in IRC is that of the\nmachine the bouncer is running at, not the one you are IRCing from.\n

1755	metisse	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/metisse	http://insitu.lri.fr/metisse/index.html	An experimental 3D X desktop	Metisse is an experimental X desktop with some OpenGL capacity. It consists of a virtual X server called Xwnc, a special version of FVWM, and a FVWM module FvwmAmetista. Xwnc is a mix of Xvnc and XDarwin. It draws nothing on your screen; everything is drawn into pixmaps. Similarly to Xvnc, but with a different protocol, Xwnc can send these pixmaps (and other information) to a "viewer";. FvwmAmetista is such a viewer; it uses OpenGL for rendering the X desktop into a window of a "regular" 3D accelerated X server.

1757	metahtml	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/metahtml	http://metahtml.sourceforge.net/	Programming language for the Web	Meta-HTML is a powerful, extensible server-side\nprogramming language specifically designed for working on the World\nWide Web. It resembles a cross between HTML and Lisp and has a huge\nexisting function library, including support for sockets, image\ncreation, Perl, GNU plot, etc. It is extensible in both Meta-HTML and\nother languages (C, etc.)\n\nAlthough it is a genuine programming language, suitable for\nlarge-scale symbolic manipulation, it provides the most commonly\ndesired Web functionality as built-in primitives, so you don't have to\nwrite them.\n\n<p>A Web page is written, using both HTML and meta-HTML. When a browser\nrequests a page, that page is passed through the meta-HTML\ninterpreter, which dynamically processes any meta-HTML statements to\nproduce a final HTML page that's delivered to the browser.\n	Intermediate

1763	mercury	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/mercury	http://www.cs.mu.oz.au/research/mercury/	Logic/functional programming language	Mercury is a modern logic/functional programming\nlanguage. It includes a compiler, a debugger, a profiler, and numerous\nlibrary packages and other tools. It is designed to be the successor\nto logic programming languages like Prolog.\n\nIt combines the clarity and expressiveness of declarative programming\nwith advanced static analysis and error detection features. Its highly\noptimized execution algorithm delivers efficiency far in excess of\nexisting logic programming systems, and close to conventional\nprogramming systems. It allows modularity, separate compilation, and\nnumerous optimization/time trade-offs.

1802	maude	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/maude	http://maude.cs.uiuc.edu	High-performance multiparadigm language based on rewriting logic.	Maude is a high-performance multiparadigm language based on rewriting logic, and contains a functional sublanguage based on equational logic.  It can be used for both programming and executable system specification in a variety of areas such as distributed and mobile systems and communication protocols, and functional applications. Thanks to its reflective features it can be used as a metalanguage and is easily extensible with powerful module composition operations as those supported in its Full Maude extension.  It can also be used as a semantic framework to specify and prototype different languages, concurrency calculi, and SOS specifications; and as a logical framework to represent and mechanize different logics and proving tools.

PeerSec Network's MatrixSSL is an embedded SSL implementation designed for small footprint devices and applications requiring low overhead per connection. The library is less than 50K on disk with full cipher suites. It includes SSL client and SSL server support, session resumption, and implementations of RSA, 3DES, ARC4, SHA1, and MD5. The source is well documented and contains portability layers for additional operating systems, cipher suites, and cryptography providers.

1826	makepp	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/makepp	http://makepp.sourceforge.net/	Reimplementation of &#39;make&#39;	Makepp, a build program which has a number of features that allow for\nreliable builds and simpler build files, is a drop-in replacement for\nGNU make. It supports almost all of the syntax that GNU make supports,\nand can be used with makefiles produced by utilities such as automake.\nIt is called makepp (or make++) because it was designed with special\nsupport for C++, which has since been extended to other languages like\nSwig or embedded SQL. Also its relationship to make is analogous to\nC++'s relationship to C: it is almost 100% backward compatible but adds\na number of new features and much better ways to write makefiles.\n\nSome features that makepp adds to make are: greatly improved handling of\nbuilds that involve multiple makefiles (recursive make is no longer\nnecessary); automatic scanning for include files; rebuilds triggered if\nbuild command changes; checksum-based signature methods for reliable\nbuilds, smart enough to ignore whitespace or comment changes;\nextensibility through perl (within your makefile); repositories\n(automatically importing files from another tree); build caches (not\nrecompiling identically what a user of the same cache already did).	Intermediate

1830	make	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/make	http://www.gnu.org/software/make/make.html	Generates executables and other non-source programs	Make examines a set of related files, determines\nwhich of them are out of date, and runs just the commands necessary to\nbring them back up to date. Make is typically used to compile and link\nprograms, but it can be useful in many other situations as well.\n\nMake reads a file called a 'makefile' to learn how the files in your\nprogram are put together. It may also contain rules to install the\nproduct, clear up the workspace, generate distribution packages, or\nother tasks. When you write a program, you should also create a\nmakefile for it so that it is possible to use Make to build and\ninstall it.	
1831	mairix	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/mairix	http://www.rc0.org.uk/mairix	Indexes and searches messages in Maildir, MH, or mbox folders	'mairix' is a tool for indexing and searching\nemail messages stored in Maildir, MH, or mbox folders. The index\ncontains a map of which words occur in which parts of which\nmessages. Searches generate symlinks to the matching messages in a new\nMaildir or MH folder, or copies of matching messages in an mbox\nfolder, which can be browsed normally in a mail client.\n\n<P>Searching and indexing are very fast. Indexing runs incrementally\non new messages, so any particular message only gets scanned once in\nthe lifetime of the index file.\n

1839	mailfilter	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/mailfilter	http://mailfilter.sourceforge.net/	Gets rid of spam in POP mailboxes.	Mailfilter is a flexible utility for *nix (-like)\noperating systems to get rid of unwanted spam mails, before having to go\nthrough the trouble of downloading them into the local computer. It\noffers support for one or many POP accounts and is especially useful for\ndialup connections via modem, ISDN, etc.\n\n<P>Mailfilter connects to any POP mail box and compares part of its content\nto a set of user defined filter rules. That way the spam gets deleted\ndirectly on the mail server.\n\n<P>With Mailfilter you can define your own filters (rules) to\ndetermine which e-mails should be delivered and which are considered\nwaste. Rules are regular expressions, so you can make use of familiar\noptions from other mail delivery programs such as e.g. procmail.\n

1841	maildrop	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/maildrop	http://www.flounder.net/~mrsam/maildrop/	Email filter and delivery agent	Maildrop is a powerful email filter/delivery\nagent. Large messages are saved in a temporary file, and are\nfiltered from the temporary file. Temporary files are saved in the\nuser's home directory. If standard input is a file (not a pipe) a\ntemporary file is not necessary.\n\n<P>Maildrop also checks the syntax of the mail delivery instructions\nthe filter file, before attempting to deliver a message. If the filter\nfile contains syntax errors, maildrop terminates without delivering\nthe message. Users can fix typos without losing mail.\n

It is an alternative to Matlab, Python, and\nScheme, and lets users mix Lisp and C within a single function for a\nunique combination of flexibility and efficiency.\n\nLush is ideal for researchers in AI, computer vision, audio, image,\nand video processing, machine learning, statistics, bio-informatics,\ninteractive graphics, and multimedia applications.

1867	lufs	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/lufs	http://lufs.sourceforge.net/	Userspace filesystem framework	LUFS is a hybrid userspace filesystem framework\nsupporting an indefinite number of filesystems (localfs, sshfs, ftpfs,\nhttpfs, socketfs, freenetfs, and nutellafs) transparently for any\napplication. It can be regarded as doing the same job as the VFS\n(virtual filesystem switch) in the kernel: it is a switch,\ndistributing the filesystem calls to its supported\nfilesystems. \n\nHowever, LUFS filesystems are implemented in userspace. This would be\na drawback for local filesystems where the access speed is important,\nbut proves to be a huge advantage for networked filesystems where the\nuserland flexibility is most important.	
1868	lucas	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/lucas	http://www.home.unix-ag.org/patrick/index.php?lucas	LDAP monitoring framework	Lets users configure network servers and/or\nservices centrally\n\n<P> The traditonal way to manage UN*X boxes is doing configuring work\non a per host basis. While this works quite well on single host\nsetups, it quickly becomes a nightmare when it comes to clustered\nsystems, load balancing systems or server farms, where configurations\nhave to be shared/spread/replicated between several more or less\nindependant machines. \n\n<P> The LUCAS project aims at creating a framework, where\nconfiguration data may be conviniently kept in an central LDAP\ndatabase and is automatically send to the desired destination from\nthere.\n

The basic gene-centered and modular design of the database follows the recommendations of the Human Genome Variation Society (HGVS) and focuses on the collection and display of DNA sequence variations. With minimal effort, the LOVD platform is extendable with clinical data.

1880	loopess	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/loopess	http://www.essemage.com/loopess/	Loop library	Loopess is a small signal and select loop library\nfor applications running on POSIX operating systems. It provides a\nconvenient abstraction of signals, file descriptor events, and\ntimeouts for single-threaded applications using a simple C++ class\nstructure. \n\nLoopess properly handles the race condition introduced by mixing\nsignals with the select system call. It uses sigsetjmp and siglongjmp\nto jump out of signals that occur just prior to entering the select\ncall. Otherwise, these signals would not be processed until the next\nfile descriptor event. Jumping out of these signals safely prevents\nentering into the blocking select system call.

1885	logalert	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/logalert	http://logalert.sourceforge.net/#info	A log file monitor that takes actions in response to triggers.	logalert is a log file monitor tool which executes a specific action whenever it matches a string (pattern) occurrence. It reads an entire file (or starts at the end, just like tail -f) and keeps track of any changes, waiting for a specific pattern (a syslog process error, a user login, etc.) and starting an action you define when it finds it. It uses regular expressions to match the pattern occurrence and executes commands via shell interaction. It deals with the log rotation and temporary removals normally used by sysadmins.

1891	lndir	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/lndir	http://www.mit.edu/afs/sipb/project/sipbsrc/rt/lndir/	Creates a shadow directory of symbolic links to another directory tree	'lndir' makes a shadow copy (todir) of a directory\ntree (fromdir). The shadow is populated with symbolic links pointing\nat the real files in the fromdir directory tree, not with real files.\nThis is useful for maintaining source code for different machine\narchitectures. You create a shadow directory containing links to the\nreal source (usually mounted from a remote machine). You can build in\nthe shadow tree, and the object files will be in the shadow directory,\nwhile the source files in the shadow directory are just symlinks to\nthe real files.\n\n<P>If you update the source, you need not propagate the change to the\nother architectures by hand, since all source in all shadow\ndirectories are symlinks to the real thing: just cd to the shadow\ndirectory and recompile.\n

1902	lisa	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/lisa	http://lisa.sourceforge.net/	Platform for developing Lisp-based Intelligent Software Agents	'LISA' is a platform for the development of\nLisp-based Intelligent Software Agents. It is a production-rule system\nimplemented in the Common Lisp Object System (CLOS), and is heavily\ninfluenced by CLIPS and the Java Expert System Shell (JESS). Its core\nis a reasoning engine based on an object-oriented implementation of\nthe Rete algorithm solving the many-to-many matching problem.\n\n<P>LISA can reason over CLOS objects without imposing special class\nhierarchy requirements, so users cans augment existing CLOS\napplications with reasoning capabilities. Also, the full power of\nCommon Lisp is available for use within productions; there is no\ndichotomy between the programming language and its implementation.\n\n<P>The project's goals include complete freedom of availability, ease\nof portbility, simplicity (so that new developers can easily\nunderstand code layout and behavior), familiarity (with roots in CLIPS\nand JESS, LISA will be familiar to those who've worked with these\nsystems), and flexibility.\n

1912	linkgrammarwn	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/linkgrammarwn	http://www.eturner.net/linkgrammar-wn/	A lexicon expansion for the Link Grammar Parser.	LinkGrammar-WN is a lexicon expansion for the Link\n Grammar Parser. The Link Grammar Parser is a \nsyntactic parser of the English language that is \ncapable of handling a wide variety of syntactic \nconstructions and is considered quite robust.  The\nLinkGrammar-WN project aims to import lexical \ninformation from WordNet in an effort to increase\n the size of the LGP lexicon. This project is of \ninterest to anyone interested in NLP (natural \nlanguage parsing) of English text.\n

1915	lingerd	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/lingerd	http://www.iagora.com/about/software/lingerd/	Accelerator daemon for apache	Lingerd is a daemon designed to properly close\nnetwork connections from an HTTP server (ie Apache). This frees the\nserver from doing the boring but time-consuming job of "lingering\ncloses", and lets each process go on to the next connection\nimmediately. As a result, Apache needs fewer processes to handle high\nloads. This saves memory, reduces kernel contention, and makes Apache\nmore scalable.\n

1921	lightspeed	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/lightspeed	http://packages.debian.org/unstable/misc/lightspeed.html	Simulates a geometric lattice	Light Speed! is an OpenGL-based program which\nillustrates the effects of special relativity on the appearance of\nmoving objects. When an object accelerates past a few million meters\nper second, these effects begin to grow noticeable, becoming more and\nmore pronounced as the speed of light is approached. These\nrelativistic effects are viewpoint-dependent, and include shifts in\nlength, object hue, brightness and shape.\n\nThe moving object is, by default, a geometric lattice. 3D Studio and\nLightWave 3D objects may be imported as well. Best of all, the\nsimulator is completely interactive, rendering the exotic distortions\nin real-time!

1942	libtomcrypt	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libtomcrypt	http://www.libtomcrypt.org	Cryptographic toolkit	LibTomCrypt is a cryptographic toolkit that gives\ndevelopers an array of well known published block ciphers, one-way\nhash functions, chaining modes, pseudo- random number generators,\npublic key cryptography, and many other routines. \n\n<P>It has been designed from the ground up to be very simple to\nuse. 1943	libtmcg	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libtmcg	http://www.nongnu.org/libtmcg/	LibTMCG is a C++ library for creating secure electronic card games.	LibTMCG is a C++ library for creating secure electronic card games. The most remarkable feature is the absence of a trusted third party (TTP), i.e. neither a central game server nor trusted hardware components are necessary. With the present library there is no need for an independent referee, because the applied protocols provide a basic level of confidentiality and fairness by itself. Consequently, the library is well-suited for peer-to-peer (P2P) environments where no TTP is available. Of course, we cannot avoid that malicious players share information about their private cards, but the protocols ensure that the shuffle of the deck is performed randomly (presumed that at least one player is honest) and thus the cards will be distributed uniformly among the players. Further, no coalition can learn the private cards of a player against his will (except for trivial conclusions). The corresponding cryptographic problem, actually called Mental Poker, has been studied since 1979 by many authors. LibTMCG provides the first practical implementation of such protocols.	
1944	libtiff	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libtiff	http://www.remotesensing.org/libtiff/	Library for reading and writing TIFF files	'libtiff' provides support for the Tag Image File\nFormat (TIFF), a widely used format for storing image data. A\nsmall assortment of TIFF-related software for UNIX that has been\ncontributed by others is also included. The library, along with\nassociated tool programs, should handle most of your needs for reading\nand writing TIFF images on 32- and 64-bit machines.\n

1959	libsafe	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libsafe	http://www.research.avayalabs.com/gcm/usa/en-us/initiatives/all/nsr.htm&amp;Filter=ProjectTitle:Libsafe&amp;Wrapper=LabsProjectDetails&amp;View=LabsProjectDetails	Detects and handles buffer overflow attacks	The exploitation of buffer overflow and format\nstring vulnerabilities in process stacks are a significant portion of\nsecurity attacks. 'libsafe' is based on a middleware software layer\nthat intercepts all function calls made to library functions known to\nbe vulnerable. A substitute version of the corresponding function\nimplements the original function in a way that ensures that any buffer\noverflows are contained within the current stack frame, which prevents\nattackers from overwriting the return address and hijacking the\ncontrol flow of a running program.\n\nThe true benefit of using libsafe is protection against future\nattacks on programs not yet known to be vulnerable.  The performance\noverhead of libsafe is negligible, it does not require changes to the\nOS, it works with existing binary programs, and it does not need\naccess to the source code of defective programs, or recompilation or\noff-line processing of binaries.\n	
1960	librsync	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/librsync	http://librsync.sourceforge.net/	Provides checksum-based differencing	'Librsync' provides checksum-based\ndifferencing. 1962	libral	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libral	http://digilander.libero.it/nfragale/	An addressbook engine.	Libral is an address book engine. In a company card you can manage Web links, email addresses, telephone numbers, and notes. XML is used to store data. 1963	libquantum	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libquantum	http://www.enyo.de/libquantum/	Simulation of a quantum computer	'libquantum' is a simulation of a quantum\ncomputer. It provides an interface for a quantum register and for all\nimportant quantum operations. An efficient model for decoherence\nallows an analysis of quantum computation in a realistic environment.\n\n<P>Features include the simulation of arbitrary algorithms, high\nperformance and low memory consumption and interfaces for quantum\nerror correction (QEC) and the density operator formalism. The\npackage includes implementations of Shor's factoring algorithm and\nGrover's search algorithm.\n	
1964	libptytty	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libptytty	http://software.schmorp.de/pkg/libptytty	A library for OS-independent pseudo-TTY management.	Libptytty is a small library that offers pseudo-TTY management in an OS-independent way. It was created out of frustration over the many differences of PTY/TTY handling in different operating systems for use inside "rxvt-unicode". It also offers session database support (utmp and optional wtmp/lastlog updates for login shells) and supports forking after startup and dropping privileges in the calling process. It offers C++ and C-only APIs.

1968	libping	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libping	http://www.joedog.org/libping/index.shtml	Makes ICMP_ECHO requests from a script or program	Libping is a small C library designed to allow a\nprogrammer to make ICMP_ECHO requests directly from a script or\nprogram. The distribution includes pinger, a script-friendly utility\nlinked to the library and intended to be invoked directly from\nscripts. Unlike most ping utilities, libping will timeout on both\nunreachable hosts and unreachable networks. It returns a value every\ntime it is called, a feature which makes programming ICMP echo\nrequests simpler and more reliable.\n	
1969	libpcl	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libpcl	http://www.xmailserver.org/libpcl.html	Portable coroutine library	'libpcl' is a Portable Coroutine Library\nimplementation written in ANSI C. Coroutines can be used to implement\ncooperative threading among many tasks without overloading the OS with\nthreads/processes. Since context switch between coroutines is very\nfast, certain applications might have performance gain in using this\ntype of threading. It can use either the ucontext.h functionalities \n( getcontext()/makecontest()/swapcontext() ) or the standard\nlongjmp()/setjmp().\n

The XML file format is that of the\nuser interface builder GLADE, so libglade acts as an alternative to\nGLADE's code generation approach. You can change the look of your\napplication without recompiling.\n\n<P>Libglade also provides a simple interface for connecting handlers\nto the various signals in the interface (on platforms where the\ngmodule library works correctly, it is possible to connect all the\nhandlers with a single function call). 1998	libferris	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libferris	http://www.libferris.com/	Virtual filesystem	'libferris' is a virtual filesystem that exposes\nhierarchical data of all kinds through a common C++ interface. Access\nto data is performed using C++ IOStreams and Extended Attributes (EA)\ncan be attached to each datum to present metadata. Ferris uses a\nplugin API to read various data sources and expose them as contexts\nand to generate interesting EA. \n\nCurrent implementations include Native (kernel disk IO with event\nupdates using fam), xml (mount an xml file as a filesystem), edb\n(mount a berkeley database), ffilter (mount an LDAP filter string) and\nmbox (mount your mailbox). EA generators include image, audio, and\nanimation decoders.

2001	libevent	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libevent	http://www.monkey.org/~provos/libevent/	Event notification library	The libevent API executes a callback function when\na specific event occurs on a file descriptor or after a timeout has\nbeen reached. It also supports callbacks due to signals or regular\ntimeouts. It is meant to replace the asynchronous event loop found in\nevent-driven network servers.\n\n<P>'libevent' currently supports /dev/poll, kqueue(2), select(2),\npoll(2) and epoll(4). It also has experimental support for real-time\nsignals. The internal event mechanism is independent of the exposed\nevent API, so a simple update of libevent provides new functionality\nwithout having to redesign applications. As a result, Libevent allows\nfor portable application development and provides the most scalable\nevent notification mechanism available on an operating system.\n

2020	libbnr	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libbnr	http://www.nuclearelephant.com/projects/dspam/bnr.html	Implementation of the Bayesian Noise Reduction (BNR) algorithm	'libbnr' implements of the Bayesian Noise\nReduction (BNR) algorithm. All samples of text contain some degree of\nnoise (data irrelevant to accurate statistical analysis of the sample\nwhere removal of the data would result in a cleaner analysis). The\nBayesian noise reduction algorithm ensures cleaner machine learning by\nproviding more useful data, which ultimately leads to better sample\nanalysis. With the noisy data removed from the sample, only data\nrelevant to the classification is left. 'libbnr' can be linked in with\na classifier and called using the standard C interface.\n	
2021	libbinio	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libbinio	http://libbinio.sourceforge.net/	Portably stores and retrives binary data	'libbinio' uses its own protocol to store and\nretrieve binary data portably. It uses an fprintf/fscanf interface,\nexporting eight functions: fputf, vfputf, fgetf, vfgetf, fwputf,\nvfwputf, fwgetf, and vfwgetf. \n\nRather than using data types such as "16 bits", it uses standard C\ntypes and uses printf/scanf-style argument lists (it even uses GNU\nargument checking if available). It should be a drop-in replacement\nfor printf/scanf and still work perfectly well. It aims to be portable\nto every C89-conforming implementation, but can use C99 and GNU\nextensions if available.

2026	libTPT	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libTPT	http://tazthecat.net/~isaac/libtpt/	Template scripting language	TPT is a template scripting language implemented\nin C++ and designed to be integrated with C++ programs. The TPT\ninterpreter runs in one pass, so there is no expensive compilation\nstage. The language relies on C++ for I/O, making TPT portable, small,\nand fast. There are no bulky modules to include. TPT does not execute\nas a program or script. \n\nThe LibTPT parser transforms TPT templates into text. The parser,\nwhich integrates with your C++ code through a simple class API, is\nsmall and fast, focusing on functionality instead of rich feature\nsets. Uses include on-the-fly HTML, source code generation, or in any\nsituation where there is a need to generate customized text.

2031	libMPEG	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libMPEG	http://libmpeg2.sourceforge.net/	Library for decoding mpeg-2 and mpeg-1 video streams	libmpeg2 is a free library for decoding mpeg-2 and\nmpeg-1 video streams. Its main goals are:\n<pre>\n    * Conformance - libmpeg2 can decode all mpeg streams that\n      conform to certain restrictions: "constrained parameters" for\n      mpeg-1, and "main profile" for mpeg-2. \n    * Speed - With typical video streams as found on DVD's, and doing\n      only decoding with no display, you should get about 110 fps on a\n      PIII/666, or 150 fps on an Athlon/950. This is less than 20\n      cycles per output pixel. \n    * Portability - most of the code is in C; even platform-specific\n      optimizations we always have a generic C routine to fall back\n      on. This should be portable to all architectures.\n    * Reuseability - we do not want libmpeg2 to include any\n      project-specific code, but it should still include enough\n      features to be used by very diverse projects.\n</pre>\n

2033	libGringotts	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/libGringotts	http://devel.pluto.linux.it/projects/libGringotts/index.php	Thread-safe library that encapsulates data in an encrypted file	'libGringotts' is a small, thread-safe C library\noriginally developed for Gringotts. Its purpose is to encapsulate data\nin an encrypted and compressed file. It uses strong cryptographic\nalgorithms (RIJNDAEL 128/256, SERPENT, TWOFISH, CAST256, SAFER+,\nLOKI97, and 3DES for encryption, and SHA1 and RIPEMD-160 for hashing)\nto ensure that data is as safe as possible, and that the user has\ncomplete control over all encryption, hashing, and compression\nalgorithms used in the process. It also provides functions for\nencrypting temporary files and to securely manage memory. It is based\nupon libmcrypt and mhash, and supports pkgconfig.\n

2052	leafnode	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/leafnode	http://www.leafnode.org/	Offline news server	Leafnode is a news server designed for small\nsites, with a few tens of readers and only a slow link to the net. It\nuses very little disk space and bandwidth compared to other servers,\nis easily configured and maintained, and tries very hard to recover\nautomatically from error situations. Each article is stored in a\nseparate file.\n\n<P>There are six programs, three essential and several add-ons. The\nessentials are leafnode (NNTP server-- talks to news clients and\nstores readership data); fetchnews (NNTP news-gatherer-- looks at\nstored readership data and selects groups to pull news from); and\ntexpire, which deletes old and uninteresting news. Add-ons are\napplyfilter (deletes articles fitting a certain pattern); checkgroups\n(inserts newsgroup titles into the database; newsq (shows which news\nare waiting to be transferred to your upstream server).\n

2058	ldapdiff	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ldapdiff	http://webtomware.rhoen.de/	Compares and adjusts ldif files with a running LDAP server	'Ldapdiff' compares ldif files with a running LDAP\nserver and does an appropriate add/delete/update for every different\nentry/attribute. Essentially, it combines "diff" and "patch" in one\napplication (although it is designed for "patching" ldap directories\nusing ldif files, not for use on flat ascii files).\n\nldap based directories often have problems with automatic updates,\nbecause the only offline interface between a company database and the\nldap directory are ldif files, and the company's data is stored in a\nrelational database, since it can be hard to keep an ldap database\ncurrent. It is time consuming and difficult to create "ldif formatted\ndeltas" for every database change. It is much easier to dump the whole\ndata pool into a ldif formatted file and run ldapdiff.

2067	latex2slides	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/latex2slides	http://latex2slides.sourceforge.net/	Produces HTML/JPEG slides from a TeX or LaTeX source	Latex2slides produces HTML/JPEG slides from a TeX\nor LaTeX source. The program first produces a multipage postscript\n(using latex or tex + dvips). Each postscript page is converted to a\nJpeg image using ImageMagick's convert. The program then makes one\nHTML page for each Jpeg (or slide), and an index.html contents\npage. As a result, each page in your slide presentation corresponds to\none of the postscript pages you would obtain from the LaTeX source.\n\n<P>Alternatively, the source can be a multipage postscript, DVI or PDF\nfile, and the image format for the slides can be set to PNG.\n

LastBASH tries to find its place among the other Last.fm players, filling this gap: the missing console player.\nBasically, it is no more than a TUI frontend, written in Bash. 2070	larbin	2010-05-03 16:09:22	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/larbin	http://larbin.sourceforge.net/index-eng.html	Web crawler	Larbin is an HTTP Web crawler that can fetch more\nthan 5 million pages a day on a standard PC (pentium II 300, 128 Mo\nSDRAM and a 10 Mbit ethernet card, with a good network). Larbin uses\nstandard libraries, plus adns. The program is multithreaded but\nprefers using select instead of a lot of threads (for efficiency\npurposes).  The advantage of Larbin over wget or ht://dig is that it\nis much faster (because it opens a lot of connexions at a time) and\nvery easy to customize).\n\n<P>Common uses include: a crawler for a standard search engine, a\ncrawler for a specialized search engine (xml, images, mp3...), and to\nprovide statistics about servers or page contents).\n

It can guess tags out of filenames, and fetches the missing parts from musicbrainz. It also cleans up your files into a structured filesystem tree which makes use of the tags in the files. Finally, it is a CD ripper with FreeDB support. A MySQL database can optionally be used for tagging.

It is HTML 4.0 compliant, and\nsupports Javascript, bidirectional scripts, SSL, almost all of CSS\n(Cascading Style Sheets) 1 and most of CSS 2, and can house Java\napplets.\n\n<P>As a file manager, it can display files in either tree or icon\nview, allows copying/moving/deleting by either drag-and-drop or\ncut/paste/delete, and provdes file properties and the ability to\nchange file attributes. It automatically updates directories or\ndeletes files without the user having to refresh or reload the\ndirectory.\n\n<P>Konqueror can also view many different file types. It uses\ncomponents (parts) to view various types of files; this functionality\nis not within Konqueror itself. This means that if you want to view a\nfile that cannot already be viewed by a preexisting part, all you have\nto do is write such a part; there's no need to modify Konqueror\nitself.\n

It acts as a frontend to SSH-agent, but\nlets you have one long running SSH-agent process per system (rather\nthan the norm of one SSH-agent per login session), so you only need to\nenter a passphrase once every time your local machine is\nrebooted. 2210	jpegpixi	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/jpegpixi	http://www.zero-based.org/software/jpegpixi/	JPEG pixel interpolator	'Jpegpixi' interpolates pixels in JFIF images\n(commonly referred to as "JPEG images"). This is useful to correct\nimages from a digital camera with CCD defects. For example, if one\npixel is always bright green, it can be interpolated away with\njpegpixi.\n\nJpegpixi tries to preserve the quality of the JFIF image as much as\npossible. Most programs decode JFIF images when they are loaded, and\nre-encode them when they are saved; this results in an overall loss of\nquality. Jpegpixi, on the other hand, manipulates the encoded image\ndata. The blocks containing the pixels to be interpolated are\nminimally disturbed, and other blocks remain pixel-by-pixel identical\nto the original image.

2260	isabella	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/isabella	http://www.thibault.org/fonts/isabella/	Gothic font	This font, called 'Isabella' is based on the\ncalligraphic hand used in the Isabella Breviary, made around 1497, in\nHolland, for Isabella of Castille, the first queen of united Spain. It\nhas all of ASCII, Latin-1, Latin Extended A, about a third of Latin\nExtended B, Latin Extended Additional, plus punctuation, and should\nwork for most languages that use the Roman alphabet.\n\n<P>Modern characters (@, for example) were drawn as best possible. The\nprimary design goal was to make such characters look like they were\ndone with a calligraphic pen; the secondary goal was to look like the\nother characters of the font. The copyright sign, for example, is made\nby shrinking down the letter "c" and placing it inside a circle. It\nalso has a Euro symbol.\n\n<P>'Isabella' is available in TrueType and PosctScript (author notes\nthat the PostScript version acts oddly in on-screen use).\n

It then puts the stats in an RRD (Round Robin\nDatabase) file and generates graphics about the server and the IRC\nnetwork using RRDTool. It was created to help ircadmins visualize and\nunderstand the traffic on their ircservers and in the IRC network.\n\n<P>'ircGraph' depends on the server ping. It is usually a 600 second\nperiod Higher son some networks, lower on others). When the program\nreceives a ping from the server it is connected, the databases will be\nupdated and a pong response will be sent.\n	
2266	iptables	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/iptables	http://www.iptables.org/	Packet filtering framework in the Linux kernel	'iptables' is built on top of netfilter: the new\npacket alteration framework for v2.4 of the Linux kernel. It is an\nenhancement on ipchains, and is used to control packet filtering,\nNetwork Address Translation (masquerading, portforwarding, transparent\nproxying), and special effects.\n	
2267	ipsvd	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ipsvd	http://smarden.org/ipsvd/	Set of Internet protocol service daemons	'ipsvd' is a set of Internet protocol service\ndaemons for TCP/IP and UDP/IP. A daemon waits for incoming connections\non a socket; for new connections, it conditionally runs an arbitrary\nprogram to handle the connection. The daemons can be told to read and\nfollow pre-defined instructions on how to handle incoming\nconnections. Based on the client's IP address or hostname, they can\nrun different programs, set a different environment, deny a\nconnection, or set a per host concurrency limit.\n\n<P>'ipsvd' can be used to run services usually run by inetd, xinetd,\nor tcpserver. Normally the ipsv daemons are run by a supervisor\nprocess, such as 'runsv' from the runit package, or 'supervise' from\nthe daemontools package.\n

Big displays have so much space that this\nshould be convenient and smaller displays couldn't show more than one\nwindow at a time anyway. The frame layout is dynamic and different on\neach workspace. \n\nGiven the tree instead of coordinate-based frame layout, moving\nbetween the frames can be conveniently done from the keyboard. As in\nPWM, the frames may have multiple clients attached. The author notes\nthat programs with more than one window per document may become\npractically unusable under Ion. 2279	integrit	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/integrit	http://integrit.sourceforge.net/	Intrusion detection system	Integrit is an alternative to file integrity\nverification programs like tripwire and aide. It helps you determine\nwhether an intruder has modified a computer system. It creates a\ndatabase that is a snapshot of the essential parts of your computer\nsystem. You put the database somewhere safe, and then use it to make\nsure that no one has made illicit modifications to the computer\nsystem. If there's a break in, you know exactly which files have been\nmodified, added, or removed.\n\nCurrent features include a small memory footprint, a simple and\nmodular design (for a faster learning curve), up-to-date cryptographic\nalgorithms, cascading rulesets, output that can be XML or a\nhuman-readable form that can be scanned, an option to reset access\ntimes, simultaneous check and update, and a design that is meant for\nunattended use.

The resultant list will once again contain all the\nfiles updated recently, but it will also specially list every file not\nupdated that was previously listed. It also lists everything that has\nbeen deleted since the last time install-log ran.\n

2309	idutils	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/idutils	http://www.gnu.org/software/idutils	Tools for indexing	A package of language independent tools that indexes\nprogram identifiers, literal numbers, or words of human-readable\ntext. Through an "ID database," a binary file containing a list of\nfilenames, a list of tokens, and a simple matrix indicating which\ntokens appear in which files, text-searching tasks become simpler and\nfaster. \n\n<P>The ID utilities handle more than just identifiers; they also treat\nother kinds of tokens, including numeric constants, and the contents\nof certain character strings. Database queries can be issued from the\ncommand-line, or from within emacs, serving as an augmented tags\nfacility.\n\n<P>Programs included are:\t       \n<pre>\nmkid: (id-utils)mkid invocation.        Creating an ID database.\n* lid: (id-utils)lid invocation.        Matching words and patterns.\n* fid: (id-utils)fid invocation.        Listing a file's tokens.\n* fnid: (id-utils)fnid invocation.      Looking up file names.\n* xtokid: (id-utils)xtokid invocation.  Testing mkid scanners.\n</pre>\n\n\n

2330	hugs	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/hugs	http://www.haskell.org/hugs/	Interpreter for the Haskell functional programming language.	Hugs 98 is a functional programming system based on Haskell 98, the de facto standard for non-strict functional programming languages. Hugs 98 provides an almost complete implementation of Haskell 98, including:\n<ul>\n    <li>Lazy evaluation, higher order functions, and pattern matching.</li>\n    <li>A wide range of built-in types, from characters to bignums, and lists to functions, with comprehensive facilities for defining new datatypes and type synonyms.</li>\n    <li>An advanced polymorphic type system with type and constructor class overloading.</li>\n    <li>All of the features of the Haskell 98 expression and pattern syntax including lambda, case, conditional and let expressions, list comprehensions, do-notation, operator sections, and wildcard, irrefutable and `as' patterns.</li>\n    <li> An implementation of the Haskell 98 primitives for monadic I/O, with support for simple interactive programs, access to text files, handle-based I/O, and exception handling.</li>\n    <li> An almost complete implementation of the Haskell module system. Hugs 98 also supports a number of advanced and experimental extensions including multi-parameter classes, extensible records, rank-2 polymorphism, existentials, scoped type variables, and restricted type synonyms.</li>\n</ul>\n

2350	hq3x	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/hq3x	http://www.hiend3d.com/hq3x.html	3x magnification filter	'hq3x' is a fast, high-quality 3x magnification\nfilter.  It was designed for use images with clear sharp edges, like\nline graphics or cartoon sprites, and to be fast enough to process\n256x256 images in real-time.\n\n<P>It sorts each pixel as 'close' or distant' depending on it\nrelationship with its neighbors. This is then filtered through a\nlookup table with 256 entries, one for each combination of\nclose/distant colored neighbors. Each entry describes how to mix the\ncolors of the source pixels from the 3x3 area to get interpolated\npixels of the filtered image. For each combination a vector\nrepresentation is created and rasterised with higher (3x) resolution\nusing anti-aliasing, and the result is stored in a lookup table.\n

2362	hlbr	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/hlbr	http://hlbr.sourceforge.net	An IPS that can filter packets in layer 2 of the OSI. It is a firewall element.	HLBR is an IPS (Intrusion Prevention System) that can filter packets directly in layer 2 of the OSI model (invisible to attackers). Detection of malicious/anomalous traffic is done by rules based on signatures. It is an efficient and versatile IPS, and can be used as a bridge to honeypots and honeynets. HLBR is a firewall element and can use regular expressions to detect malicious traffic. For example, a rule which might detect links to viruses in email messages would be 'tcp regex(href=&"[^]+\\.scr&")'.

2392	hapcluster	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/hapcluster	http://www.daimi.au.dk/~mailund/HapCluster/index.html	An MCMC based statistical tool for association mapping.	HapCluster++ is a software package for linkage\ndisequilibrium mapping using coalescent theory. It\nis based on a Bayesian Markov-chain Monte Carlo\n(MCMC) method for fine-scale\nlinkage-disequilibrium gene mapping using\nhigh-density marker maps. HapCluster++ is a C++\nimplementation of the method described in the\npaper "Fine Mapping of Disease Genes via Haplotype\nClustering" by E.R.B. Waldron, J.C. Whitaker, and\nD.J. Balding. 2393	hanzim	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/hanzim	http://zakros.ucsd.edu/~arobert/hanzim.html	Visual, interactive Chinese character and word dictionary	Hanzim ("Hanzi Master") is an interactive visual\ndictionary for learning and seeing relationships between Chinese\nradicals, characters, and compounds. All the characters with a given\nradical, phonetic component, or pronunciation can be displayed, as\nwell as all words containing a character, with English meanings.\nEither simplified or traditional characters can be used. \n\nThe main character is displayed in a box near the center. Compounds\nemploying it in the initial position are listed to its right; those\nemploying it in the final position are listed to its left. Characters\nwith the same radical are listed in the lower left, those with the\nsame remaining component (character sans radical) in the middle, and\nthose with the same pronunciation are on the right. Clicking on any\ncharacter on the screen makes it the new main character.

2404	h5utils	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/h5utils	http://ab-initio.mit.edu/h5utils/	Utilities for visualization and conversion of data in the HDF5 format	h5utils is a set of utilities for visualization\nand conversion of scientific data in the free, portable HDF5\nformat. Programs included are:\n\n<ul>\n    <li>h5totxt and h5fromtxt: convert HDF5 datasets to/from ASCII\n      text (e.g. comma- or tab-delimited). </li>\n\n    <li>h5topng: convert 2d slices of HDF5 datasets to PNG images, with\n      a variety of color tables and other options. </li>\n\n    <li>h5tov5d: convert HDF5 datasets to the format used by the free 3d+\n      visualization tool Vis5d. </li>\n\n    <li>h5tovtk: convert HDF5 datasets to VTK format for use by the free\n      Visualization ToolKit (along with supporting programs like\n      MayaVi). </li>\n\n    <li>h5read.oct: a plug-in for GNU Octave (a Matlab-like program) to\n      read 2d slices of HDF5 datasets. (The latest versions of Octave\n      also include native support for HDF5.)</li>\n\n    <li>h5fromh4: convert HDF (version 4) datasets to HDF5; mostly\n      superseded by the h4toh5 program included with recent versions\n      of HDF5. </li>\n\n      <em>Please note that the programs to convert to/from PNG, Vis5d, GNU\n      Octave, and HDF(4) will only be built if the corresponding\n      libraries/programs are installed.</em>

2419	gwcc	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gwcc	http://gwcc.sourceforge.net/	GUI interface to the command line	GWCC lets users execute network utilities (ping,\nnslookup, traceroute) and workstation commands (netstat, df, lpr), do\nthings like process 'grep' from a single tabbed window. 2420	gwave	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gwave	http://geda.seul.org/tools/gwave/index.html	Gwave is a waveform viewer.	Gwave is a waveform viewer. Its purpose is for viewing analog data, such as the output from Spice-like simulations. Gwave can read binary or ascii files written by HSpice from transient, AC, or Sweep analyses, "raw" files written by Spice2, Spice3, or ngspice, and transient analysis files from the CAzM simulator. It can also read a generic tabular ASCII format suitable for use with ACS or homegrown tools. It supports multiple "panels" (graticlules) with multiple variables displayed in each. Two vertical-bar cursors are available for time-difference measurements. Multiple files can be loaded, for comparing the results of several simulations.

2430	guile	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/guile	http://www.gnu.org/software/guile/guile.html	GNU extensibility library	An implementation of the Scheme programming\nlanguage built to be used as an extension language. It's a library you\ncan link into your programs. Your program has full access to the\ninterpreter's data structure, so you can extend Guile with your own\nprimitives, datatypes, and syntax, and tailor the language to your\napplication. \n\nIt also lets more people use your language, as they needn't learn the\ninternals of your app. They just need to understand the language and\nthe primitives you've provided, and they can trade and share ideas by\npassing around scripts without you.

2440	guasi	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/guasi	http://www.xmailserver.org/guasi-lib.html	Generic Userspace Asyncronous Syscall Interface	The GUASI library implements a thread based generic asyncronous execution engine, to be used to give otherwise syncronous calls an asyncronous behaviour. It can be used to wrap any syncronous call, so that it can be scheduled for execution, and whose result can be fetched at later time (hence not blocking the submitter thread). The GUASI library can be used as complement to standard event retrieval interfaces like poll(2), select(2) or epoll(4).

It features metric operations (area, volume, curvature, etc.), 2D Delaunay and constrained Delaunay triangulations, robust geometric predicates and set operations on surfaces (union, intersection, etc.), surface refinement and coarsening (multiresolution models), and bounding-boxes trees for collision/intersection detection.

2487	gsl	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gsl	http://www.gnu.org/software/gsl/	Routines for numerical computing	The GNU Scientific Library (GSL) is a collection\nof routines for numerical computing. 2488	gshow	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gshow	http://gshowtv.sourceforge.net/	GUI frontend to view listings and record TV programs	 GShow TV is a TV program schedule viewer and a Personal Video Recorder GUI. GShow TV's basic purpose is to provide a nice GUI for viewing tv program schedule information and for recording the programs. GShow TV doesn't itself do the recording of the selected programs, rather it uses any PVR solution that exists. GShow TV is globally usable as it uses XMLTV to access the program schedules, and xmltv has support for multitude of countries.\n<p> The interface between the recording software and the GUI is two trivial shell scripts, which are of course modifiable by the user as they see fit. The reason for this separation is simple: o GNU/linux almost everybody who has a TV card on their computer uses a different recording solution. The multitude of home-made recording systems is countless. However, most home-made systems don't include a nice GUI and hence GShow TV. Also as nowadays there are better PVR systems, like MythTV, VDR and Freevo, GShow TV makes a nifty remote frontend to these systems.

2502	gringotts	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gringotts	http://devel.pluto.linux.it/projects/Gringotts/	Securely saves sensitive data	Gringotts stores sensitive data (passwords, credit\ncard numbers, PINs, etc.) in an easy-to-read, easy-to-access, and most\nof all very secure form. It makes use of the MCrypt and MHash\nlibraries for encryption, and uses GTK+ 2 for the user interface. It\nlets the user choose from among eight strong encryption algorithms\n(RIJNDAEL-128, RIJNDAEL-256, SERPENT, TWOFISH, CAST-256, SAFER+,\nLOKI97, 3DES), two hashing algorithms (SHA1, RIPEMD 160) and two\ncompression techniques (ZLib and BZip2) with four compression\nratios. Any file can be used as a password, as an alternative to the\nusual text string, giving additional choices.\n

2507	grep	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/grep	http://www.gnu.org/software/grep/	Finds lines that match entered patterns	Package includes the GNU 'grep,' 'egrep,' and 'fgrep,'\nwhich find lines that match entered patterns. By default, grep prints\nthe matching lines.\n\nGNU grep is based on a fast lazy-state deterministic matcher (about\ntwice as fast as the standard Unix grep) hybridized with a\nBoyer-Moore-Gosper search for a fixed string that eliminates\nimpossible text from being considered by the full regexp match without\nhaving to look at every character; the result is usually many times\nfaster than UNIX 'grep' or 'egrep.' 2508	greg	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/greg	http://www.gnu.org/software/greg/greg.html	Software testing framework 	Greg is a framework for testing other programs and\nlibraries by providing a single front end for all tests and a small,\nsimple framework for writing those tests. It's a replacement for\nDejaGNU that lets you use the 'Guile' instead of 'tcl' to write\ntestcases.\n\n<P.Core functionality is a Guile module which can be loaded into any\nsoftware with an embedded Guile interpreter. Therefore, any program\nthat uses Guile as its scripting language can use Greg to test itself\ndirectly. For testing external programs, Greg provides a compiled\nmodule that dynamically links to Guile so you can run an application\nas a child process on a pseudo-terminal, and test terminal-based\nprograms in conjunction with the standard Guile 'expect' module.\n\n<P>All tests have the same output format, which can be parsed by other\nsoftware and used as input to customized testing programs.\n

2512	gravityd	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gravityd	http://www.webopticon.com/software/gravityd/	Graphical display of network testing tools	gravityd is a network management tool that allows\nadministrators to see a diagram of monitored hosts on an IP\nnetwork. This diagram graphically displays the result of various\nnetwork testing tools with a "dot system" that lets sysadmins notice\nfaulty servers more quickly, thus minimizing downtime.\n\nA down server has a red dot, a slow or partially failed node has a\nyellow dot, and a node that passes all tests is green. Users can\nconfigure the tests run on each node by adding new plugins to\ngravityd. gravityd's plugin architecture is open, which allows third\nparty developers to write modules for gravityd to extend its\nfunctionality.

It uses Newtonian\nphysics using the Barnes-Hut N-body algorithm.\nAlthough the main goal of Gravit is to be as\naccurate as possible, it also creates beautiful\nlooking gravity patterns. It records the history\nof each particle so that it can animate and\ndisplay a path of its travels. At any stage you\ncan rotate your view in 3D and zoom in and out.\nGravit uses OpenGL, Lua, SDL, SDL_ttf, and\nSDL_image.\n

2532	gps	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gps	http://gps.seul.org/	Reports process status	gPS (graphical Process Statistics) is a system\ninformation applet based on GTK+. It displays the processes of one or\nmore computers (like ps or top), allows killing, renicing, and signal\nsending, shows lots of details on selected processes, shows CPU/memory/swap\nusage and history graphs, and is capable of watching networked\ncomputers in addition to the local one. It also provides an easy way\nto send signals to processes based on their owners (uid), groups\n(gud), and string matching.\n\nThe process list can be refreshed periodically (like top) or on\nrequest (like ps). The program also allows filtering the process list\nthrough any of the shown fields, sorting on any field in any\ndirection, sending POSIX signals to local processes, and renicing\nlocal processes.

This executable can be quite small\nsince GNU Prolog doesn't need to link the code of most unused built-in\npredicates.\n\n<P>Besides the native code compilation, GNU Prolog offers a classical\ninteractive interpreter (top-level). It also conforms to the ISO\nstandard for Prolog.\n\n<P>The program also includes an efficient constraint solver over\nFinite Domains (FD). 2547	gperf	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gperf	http://www.gnu.org/software/gperf/gperf.html	Generates a hash function	GNU gperf is a perfect hash function\ngenerator. For a given list of strings, it produces a hash function and\nhash table in the form of C or C++ code, for looking up a value\ndepending on the input string. The hash function is 'perfect,' which\nmeans that the hash table has no collisions, and the hash table lookup\nneeds a single string comparison only.\n\nGNU gperf is highly customizable. There are options for generating C\nand C++ code, for emitting 'switch' statements or nested 'ifs' instead of\na hash table, and for tuning the algorithm that gperf uses.

It supports a wide range of Internet\nstandards, databases and application development tools, making it\nextremely versatile. It lets users integrate all popular development\nlanguages and databases, servers, browsers and wireless devices.\nIt comes with a set of simple API libraries and modules, allowing a\nchoice of languages to be used to develop business logic servers.\nServers written in different languages can be mixed and can also\ncommunicate freely provided they use the same data interchange format.\n\n<P>Goldwater allows both XML and custom encapsulation of objects and\nmessage data, transporting them via either a proprietary protocol or\nthe HTTP/1.1 protocol. This lets Goldwater integrate with existing\nfirewall and routing configurations with little or no network\nre-configuration. Since the package is open regarding object and data\nencapsulation, clients facing data presentation servers can render\ntheir output in XML, a custom data stream, or pass this data untreated\nto client applications. Third party applications that can share data\nvia XML will integrate easily into enterprise applications built on a\nGoldwater famework.\n

2576	gnusql	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gnusql	http://www.ispras.ru/~kml/gss/index.html	Database management system	Portable multiuser relational database management\nsystem. 2585	gnuradio	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gnuradio	http://www.gnu.org/software/gnuradio/	Software to create digital radio signals	GNU Radio is a collection of software that when\ncombined with minimal hardware, allows the construction of radios\nwhere the actual waveforms transmitted and received are defined by\nsoftware: it turns the digital modulation schemes used in high\nperformance wireless devices into software problems.\n\n<P>Waveforms are generated as sampled digital signals, converted from\ndigital to analog via a wideband DAC and then possibly upconverted\nfrom IF to RF. The receiver uses a wideband Analog to Digital\nConverter (ADC) that captures all the channels of the software radio\nnode. The receiver then extracts, downconverts and demodulates the\nchannel waveform using software on a general purpose processor.\n

We value free speech above state secrets,\nlaw-enforcement or intellectual property. GNUnet is supposed to be\nan anarchistic network, where the only limitation for peers is that\nthey must contribute enough back to the network such that their\nresource consumption does not have a significant impact on other\nusers.

2594	gnumach	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gnumach	http://www.gnu.org/software/hurd/microkernel/mach/gnumach.html	Microkernel of the GNU system	GNU Mach is the microkernel of the GNU system. A\nmicrokernel provides only a limited functionality, just enough\nabstraction on top of the hardware to run the rest of the operating\nsystem in user space. The GNU Hurd servers and the GNU C library\nimplement the POSIX compatible base of the GNU system on top of the\nmicrokernel architecture provided by Mach.\n\n<P>Currently, GNU Mach runs on IA32 machines. GNU Mach should, and\nprobably will, be ported to other hardware architectures in the\nfuture. Mach was ported to many operating systems in the past.\n

These are files intended to be shared at the source level; Gnulib is not a library meant to be installed and linked against. Unlike most projects, Gnulib does not normally generate a source tarball distribution; instead, developers should just grab modules directly from the repository.\n\nWhile portability across operating systems is not one of GNU's primary goals, it has helped introduce many people to the GNU system, and is worthwhile when it can be achieved at a low cost. 2616	gnowsys	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gnowsys	http://www.gnu.org/software/gnowsys/	Hybrid database server with a kernel for semantic computing	GNOWSYS is an acronym for "Gnowledge Networking\nand Organizing SYStem." It is a web based object oriented database\nserver with each object provided by an unique URL. GNOWSYS is a tool\nto construct and store persistently a Gnowledge Base (GB). The GB\nconsists of the following three groups of constructor classes\n(system and temporal classes under development):\n<pre>\n\t PredicateGroup:  relationType, relation, functionType, function\n         Object Group:    metaType, class, object (with\n                          provision to have classes and objects of declarative,\n                          procedural, encapsulated, temporal etc.)\n         Structure Group: systemType, system, flowType, flow, processType,\n\t\t\t  process\n</pre>\n\n<P>GNOWSYS indexes data and metadata of objects in a catalogue for\nfaster queries. Optionally, data can remain anywhere on the Internet\n(only the metadata stays in the database). Surrogates of procedures\n(classes, functions, and system calls) can also be installed in the\ndatabase as special objects. These procedures execute as web services,\nso users can design applications without writing program in any\nprogramming language by specifying the semantics of a program and\nmapping the elements of the program to the surrogates of procedures is\nsufficient for GNOWSYS to test the application design.\n	Advanced

2619	gnotary	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gnotary	http://www.gnumed.net/gnotary/	Project to produce a digital notary service	Gnotary will prove the integrity and authenticity\nof your electronic health records by countersigning a digital\nsignature of your document (with optional offsite storage, where you\nhave no access). The client will provide a GUI for selecting files for\na backup, calculating strong hashes for each file, and storing files\nin a compressed ZIP archive file. By pressing a single button, the\nhashes of the selected files are calculated and sent to one or more\nnotary servers.\n\n<P>The server will grab incoming mail that matches a filter condition,\npipe it through the GNU privacy guard signing process, retain a copy\nof the signed message, and return the signed message to the sender. In\nthe future, all notary servers will exchange message digests of their\nown certificate log mutually (and get them mutually certified), thus\ncreating a virtually unbreakable chain of evidence (tampering with one\ncertificate invalidates all others in an auditable way).\n\n<P>The project is in an early beta stage; no official releases have\nbeen made. The current code can be downloaded from Savannah, the GNU\nCVS repository.\n	
2620	gnormalize	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gnormalize	http://freshmeat.net/redir/gnormalize/55977/url_homepage/	A ripper, encoder, audio converter, MetaInfo editor, and front end to normalize.	gnormalize is a front end to the normalize tool, ripper, an encoder, and an audio converter. It decodes MP3, MP4 (or M4A or AAC), MPC (or MPP or MP+), OGG, APE, or FLAC files to wave, then normalizes the wave and re-encodes it. It can also rip audio CDs, encode audio data, convert audio formats between MP3, MP4, MPC, OGG, APE, and FLAC, and change the encoding properties and edit Meta Info (like title, artist, album, etc.) of the final normalized files.

2635	gnome-find	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gnome-find	http://gnome-find.sourceforge.net	GUI version of the GNU &#39;find&#39; utility	The original source code to the GNU 'find' utility\n(findutils 4.1) was used, and a GUI component was integrated into\nit. Therefore, the program is not just a front end, or a rewrite of\nthe find utility; it's truly a GUI version of the original utility,\nwith a file finding backend component based on the stable and mature\ncode of 'find' and a contemporary GUI interface. This avoids both common\nportablilty problems that front-ends typically run into when they\nrun on systems without GNU 'find,' as well as the problems with\nforking a new process and communicating with it.\n\n<P>This release features basic searching and multiple windows, as well\nas multi-file and multi-directory searches. Currently, gnome-find uses\na default dialog for most commonly specified searches; a second, more\ndetailed dialog can specify more powerful search parameters: all the\n"Options" and "Actions" for advanced searches are now supported.\n

Its design\ngoal is to provide a simple meshing tool for academic test cases with\nparametric input and up to date visualization capabilities. It can\nrespect a characteristic length field for the generation of adapted\nmeshes on lines, surfaces and volumes, and mix these meshes with\nsimple structured grids.\n\n<P> Gmsh is built around four modules: geometry, mesh, solver and\npost-processing. GMediaServer is a UPnP compatible media server that serves audio and video files to certain network connected media players. Most hardware media players only play music or video - they don't provide the media themselves. Those media files have to come from a device on the network. GMediaServer is a server for such UPnP compatible media players, including the NETGEAR MP101, Linksys WMLS11B and WML11B, Philips Streamium SL300i and RC9800i, Omnifi DMS1 and SMCWAA-B, D-Link DSM-520, Roku M1000, and Terratec NOXON 2. 2681	gmane	2010-05-03 16:09:23	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gmane	http://www.gmane.org/	Converts mailing lists to newsgroups and back	'gmane' funnels mailing lists into news\ngroups. This isn't a new idea, but with Gmane no messages are ever\nexpired from the server, and the gateway is bidirectional. You can\npost to various lists without being subscribed to them. There are\ncurrently 5,944 mailing lists subscribed to Gmane, with a total of\n18,747,653 messages.\n\n<P>The package includes we:search (a search engine), weaverd (a\nback-end daemon that generates thread and group views), weft (takes a\nmail or a news message and formats it into HTML), and loom (news\nreader and front end to weaverd and weft).\n

2805	gcl	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gcl	http://savannah.gnu.org/projects/gcl/	Compiler and interpreter for Common Lisp	GCL is a Compiler and interpreter for Common\nLisp. It compiles to C and then uses the native optimizing C compiler\n(e.g., GCC), giving great portability. It is highly efficient: a function\ncall is basically the same speed as a C function call, in fact\nidentical to a C function call via a pointer. \n\nThe program has a source level Lisp debugger (dbl) for interpreted\ncode, letting you step a line at a time, while displaying your\nposition in an Emacs window.  It has pioneered conservative Garbage\nCollection schemes, but also has the stratified garbage collection\n(SGC) scheme, for only recent allocations, that is based on native\npage fault handling. \n\n<p>There is also a built in interface to Tk widget system. Allows a\nmixture of tcl and common lisp to be used in a user interface--your\nchoice which you use.\n

2819	garpd	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/garpd	https://savannah.gnu.org/projects/garpd	GNU Gratuitous ARP Daemon	Broadcasts Gratuitous ARPs for a list of MAC address <-> IP address mappings on specified interfaces at regular intervals.\nA gratuitous ARP request is an AddressResolutionProtocol request\npacket where the source and destination IP are both set to the IP of\nthe machine issuing the packet and the destination MAC is the\nbroadcast address ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff. Ordinarily, no reply packet will\noccur. Gratuitous ARP reply is a reply to which no request has been\nmade.\n\nGratuitous ARPs are useful to update ARP tables of switches, routers\nand other hosts to route packets to a designated IP address.\n\nGarpd was developed as a part of GNU FreeIPMI project. Some of the\nIPMI implementations doesn't implement GARP broadcast functionality in\ntheir NICS. When the host OS is down and BMC is active listening for\nIPMI packets on the NIC, it needs to inform other switches/routers to\nroute packets to its NIC. Because Garpd is useful for other purposes\ntoo, we decided to make it as a separate project. \n

The toolkit itself,\nhowever, remains feature complete and stable.\n

GAP is used in research and teaching for studying groups and their representations, rings, vector spaces, algebras, combinatorial structures, and more. The system, including source, is distributed freely. You can study and easily modify or extend it for your special use.

2830	gamazons	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/gamazons	http://www.cs.pdx.edu/~yorgasor/gamazons/	Board game	Gamazons is a game played on a 10x10 chess\nboard. Each side has four pieces (amazons) that move in a straight\nline in any direction. The winner is determined by who moves last. \n\n<P>Each move consists of two parts. First an amazon moves to a new square\nand then fires an arrow to another square (in a straight line in any\ndirection from the square the amazon landed on). The square the arrow\nlands on becomes a permanent block for the rest of the game. No one\ncan move over it, or fire an arrow over it. Every turn an amazon must\nmove and fire an arrow, so every turn there is one less square\navailable on the board. \n\n<P>You can block in your opponent, or section off a good chunk of the\nboard for yourself. You can set it to play AI vs AI or whatever you\nlike. There are also Auto Finish and Force Move defaults.\n

2857	g4u	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/g4u	http://www.feyrer.de/g4u/	Lets users clone hard disks by using FTP	g4u ("ghost for unix") is a boot-floppy/CD that\nlets users clone hard disks by using FTP. This is often done to deploy\na common setup on a number of PCs. The floppy/CD uploads the\ncompressed image of a local hard disk to an FTP server, and then\nretrieves that image via FTP, uncompresses it, and writes it back to\ndisk. Network configuration is fetched via DHCP. The hard disk is\nprocessed as an image, so g4u can deploy any filesystem/operating\nsystem. Users can clone local disks as well as partitions.\n
