2863	fwsnort	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/fwsnort	http://www.cipherdyne.org/fwsnort/	Translates snort rules into an equivalent iptables ruleset	'fwsnort' translates snort rules into an\nequivalent iptables ruleset. By using the iptables string match\nmodule, fwsnort detects application layer signatures which exist in\nmany snort rules. It adds a --hex-string option to iptables, which\nlets users directly input snort rules that contain hex characters into\niptables rulesets without modification. \n\n<P>'fwsnort' also uses the IPTables::Parse Perl module to (optionally)\nrestrict the snort rule translation to only those rules that specify\ntraffic that could potentially be allowed through an existing iptables\npolicy.\n	
2864	fwlogwatch	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/fwlogwatch	http://fwlogwatch.inside-security.de/	Firewall log analyzer and realtime monitor/response tool	'fwlogwatch' is a packet filter and firewall log\nanalyzer. It can output its summaries in text and HTML, with various\nformatting options. It can produce customizable incident reports and\nsend them to abuse contacts at offending sites or CERTs. Fwlogwatch\ncan also run as a daemon (with Web interface) doing realtime log\nmonitoring and reporting anomalies or starting attack countermeasures.\n\n<P>It can detect and process log entries in the following formats:\n<pre>\n    * GNU/Linux ipchains\n    * GNU/Linux netfilter/iptables\n    * Solaris/BSD/Irix/HP-UX ipfilter\n    * BSD ipfw\n    * Cisco IOS\n    * Cisco PIX / FWSM\n    * NetScreen\n    * Elsa Lancom router\n    * Snort IDS\n</pre>\n	
2865	fwknop	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/fwknop	http://www.cipherdyne.org/fwknop/	Adds an additional layer of security to services such as SSH	'fwknop' implements an authorization scheme that\nrequires only a single encrypted packet to communicate various pieces\nof information, including desired access through a Netfilter policy\nand/or specific commands to execute on the target system. Its main use\nis to protect services such as SSH with an additional layer of\nsecurity, which makies exploitation of vulnerabilities much more\ndifficult. The authorization server works by passively monitoring\nauthorization packets via libpcap.\n

2879	ftpStats	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ftpStats		Xferlog analyzer	ftpStats is a comprehensive xferlog analyser that\nuses a MySQL backend to store the information. If you can figure out\nhow to get the information in an xferlog into MySQL, Perl is not\nnecessary. The program is available in English, Dutch, Spanish,\nTurkish, and French.\n\n<P>HTML is generated live for each request, pulled from MySQL on the\nfly. Therefore, ftpStats is not suitable for analysing large amounts\nof data. It can realistically store and display the details of about\n100,000 transfers before the pages become too slow to use. On a quiet\nFTP server, you might get years of analysis. On a busy servers, you\nmight exceed this in a day. In the latter case, please consider using\nftpStats as last-day analysis and something like Webalizer for\nlong-term analysis.\n

2898	freenet	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/freenet	http://www.freenetproject.org/	Filesharing program	Freenet allows efficient distribution of\ninformation over the Internet without fear of censorship. Freenet is\ncompletely decentralized: there is no entity in control of, or\nessential to, Freenet so there's no central point that would collapse\nthe entire system if attacked.\n\n<P>It is hard to remove single pieces of information from Freenet,\nsince it's difficult to determine which computer is storing any given\npiece of information. Trying to determine where information is stored\nresults in that information spreading to other nodes within Freenet\n(usually the opposite of what you want to happen). Both authors and\nreaders of information on Freenet can remain anonymous if they wish.\n\nFreenet also employs intelligent routing and caching, meaning\nthat it learns to route requests more efficiently, automatically\nmirrors popular data, makes network flooding almost impossible, and\nmoves data to where it is in greatest demand.

2902	freeipmi	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/freeipmi	http://www.gnu.org/software/freeipmi	Intelligent platform management system	FreeIPMI provides in-band and out-of-band IPMI software based on the\nIPMI v1.5/2.0 specification. The software has been written with a number\nof useful features for large HPC and cluster environments.. Its components include:\n<ul>\n\n <li>Libfreeipmi - A C library that includes KCS, SSIF, and OpenIPMI drivers, IPMI 1.5 and IPMI 2.0 LAN communication interfaces, IPMI packet building utilities, IPMI command utilities, and utilities for reading/interpreting/managing IPMI.\n\n  <li>Bmc-info - A tool to read information about the local BMC such as version information and device support.</li>\n   <li>Bmc-config - A tool to configure usernames, passwords, networking information, security, and other relevant IPMI configuration fields.</li>\n  <li>Bmc-watchdog - A tool/daemon to manage a BMC Watchdog. This tool is typically used for system timeout management and automatic system restarts in the event of a system crash.</li>\n  <li>Ipmi-chassis - A tool to manage/monitor a chassis, such as chassis power, identification, and status.</li>\n  <li>Ipmi-fru - A tool to read field replaceable unit (FRU) information from a motherboard/machine.</li>\n  <li>Ipmi-sel - A tool to read and manage IPMI System Event Log (SEL) records.</li>\n  <li>Ipmi-sensors - A tool to read IPMI sensor readings and sensor data repository (SDR) information.</li>\n  <li>Ipmipower - A tool for remote power control.</li>\n  <li>Ipmiconsole/Libipmiconsole - A tool and library for Serial-over-Lan (SOL) console access.</li>\n  <li>Ipmi-raw - A tool that provides hex input/output of IPMI commands.</li>\n  <li>Ipmi-locate - A tool that can probe for information about the location of a BMC device, such as device addresses.</li>\n  <li>Ipmimonitoring/Libipmimonitoring - A tool and library for used for sensor interpretation/monitoring. The tool is similar to ipmi-sensors, but sensor readings are mapped into Nominal, Warning, and Critical states.</li>\n  <li>Pef-config - A tool to configure IPMI Platform Event Filtering (PEF) configuration.</li>\n  <li>Ipmiping - An IPMI ping tool for debugging.</li>\n  <li>Rmcpping - A RMCP ping tool for debugging.\n  <li>Ipmidetect/Ipmidetectd/libipmidetect - A tool, daemon, and library for IPMI node detection.\n   </ul>	Intermediate

2913	freeVSD	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/freeVSD	http://freevsd.org.uk/	Web hosting platform	FreeVSD facilitates Linux virtual servers within a\n'chroot' environment, allowing Web servers and other applications to\nbe deployed and administered discretely, without compromise to\nsecurity. 2914	freeSWAN	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/freeSWAN	http://www.xs4all.nl/~freeswan/	IPSEC and IKE for GNU/Linux systems	GNU/Linux FreeS/WAN is an implementation of IPSEC\n(Internet Protocal SECurity) and IKE for GNU/Linux systems.  It uses\nstrong cryptography to provide both authentication and encryption;\nauthentication ensures that packets are from the right\nsender and have not been altered in transit, and encryption prevents\nunauthorised reading of packet contents.\n\nThese services allow you to build secure tunnels through untrusted\nnetworks. Everything passing through the untrusted net is encrypted by\nthe IPSEC gateway machine and decrypted by the gateway at the other\nend. The result is Virtual Private Network or VPN. This network\n is effectively private even though it includes machines at\nseveral different sites connected by the insecure Internet.

The language syntax is\nsemantically compatible with TP 7.0 as well as most versions of Delphi\n(classes, rtti, exceptions, ansistrings). \n\n<P>FreePascal supports function overloading, operator overloading and\nother such features. 2918	fplan	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/fplan	http://www.ibiblio.org/fplan/	Free flight plan software	fplan helps general aviation pilots to create\nflight plans for cross country flights in powered aircraft. It reads a\nplanfile containing a description of the flight, departure and\ndestination airports, navigation aids, intermediate waypoints, winds\naloft, fuel consumption rates, and produces a flight plan including\nwind corrected magnetic headings, distance, estimated time and fuel\nconsumption for each leg, latitude, longitude and VOR fixes for each\ncheckpoint, etc. A graphical preview of the flight is available on\nsystems with X11 Windows and the XView Toolkit.\n	
2919	fping	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/fping	http://www.fping.com/	Pings multiple hosts at once	'fping' is a ping-like program which uses the\nInternet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo request to determine if\na target host is responding. 'fping' differs from ping in that you can\nspecify any number of targets on the command line, or specify a file\ncontaining the lists of targets to ping. Instead of sending pings to\none target until it times out or replies, fping will send out a ping\npacket and move on to the next target in a round-robin fashion.\n	
2920	fotox	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/fotox	http://kornelix.squarespace.com/fotox/	Photo contrast editing	Modify image brightness distribution to improve balance and detail. Combine a brighter and darker image to make a composite with improved dynamic range. Stitch two images together (panorama).<br>\n<ul>\n<li>reduce fog or haze by removing "whiteness" and intensifying colors</li>\n<li>adjust overexposed / underexposed areas to improve visibility of detail - change brightness of darker / brighter areas independently</li>\n<li>increase "dynamic range" by combining an underexposed and overexposed image of the same subject (improve balance and visibility of detail in both bright and dark areas)</li>\n<li> panorama (stitch two images together to make a wide image)</li>\n</ul>\n

It\nknows common bell-shaped functions (Gaussian, Lorentzian, Pearson 7,\nVoigt, Pseudo-Voigt) and polynomials, but more sophisticated formulae\ncan be added if needed. \n\nIt also enables background substracting, data calibration and task\nautomation with a simple script language. It is being developed to\nanalyze powder diffraction patterns, but can be used to fit analytical\nfunctions to any kind of data.

2975	fileprune	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/fileprune	http://www.spinellis.gr/sw/unix/fileprune/	Automates file deletion	'Fileprune' deletes files from a collection,\ntargeting a given distribution of the file timestamps within time as\nwell as size, number, and age constraints. It is meant to keep a set\nof periodically-created backup files to a manageable size while still\nproviding reasonable access to older versions. \n\n<P>The algorithm used for pruning is based on an exponential, Gaussian\n(normal), or Fibonacci distribution, and provides fine control of the\nfiles to delete and allows the retention of recent copies and\nincreasingly aggressive pruning of older files. The retention schedule\nspecifies the age intervals for which files will be retained.\n

2981	ficc	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ficc	http://www.firsttracks.net/ficc	Manages multiple Tripwire installations	File Integrity Command & Control (FICC) helps\nsystem administrators manage multiple Tripwire installations. It\nmaintains MD5 hashes for three key Tripwire files and verifies that\nthe MD5 checksum of these key files against the signatures in its file\nchecksum database. If they match, it then connects to the host via SSH\nand runs Tripwire. If any signatures do not match, an email is sent to\nthe "FICC administrator" of the system in question.\n

2996	fetchmail	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/fetchmail	http://developer.berlios.de/projects/fetchmail/	Remote mail retrieval utility	Fetchmail is a remote-mail retrieval and\nforwarding utility for use over on-demand TCP/IP links (such as SLIP\nor PPP connections). Fetchmail can start automatically and silently as\na system daemon at boot time. You can edit its dotfile directly, or\nuse the interactive GUI configurator (fetchmailconf) supplied with the\ndistribution.

The nice\nthing is that you have CUPS around, and this means, for instance, that\nyou can check whether your fax has been sent just using your favorite\nbrowser (as you would do for any other printer), even if the fax modem\nis really on a remote server. 3018	fax2png	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/fax2png	http://www.boutell.com/fax2png	1-bit multipage TIFF (fax or scan) to PNG converter	'fax2png' extracts a specified page from a 1-bit\nblack and white TIFF image, such as a fax, and efficiently converts it\nto PNG format without the performance overhead of netpbm-based\nsolutions. It supports antialiasing (for attractive reductions to\ntypical Web browser widths)and 90-degree-interval rotations and\nflips. 3022	fann	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/fann	http://fann.sourceforge.net/	Implements multilayer feedforward ANNs much faster than other libraries	Fast Artificial Neural Network Library (fann)\nimplements multi-layer feedforward networks that support both fully\nconnected and sparsely connected networks. It supports execution in\nfixed point arithmetic to allow for fast execution on systems with no\nfloating point processor. To overcome the problems of integer\noverflow, the library calculates a position of the decimal point after\ntraining and guarantees that integer overflow cannot occur with this\ndecimal point.\n\n<P>FANN is designed to be fast, versatile, and easy to use. Several\nbenchmarks have been executed to test its performance. It is\nsignificantly faster than other libraries on systems without a\nfloating point processor, and comparable to other highly optimized\nlibraries on systems with a floating point processor.\n

The program conforms to the Freenet Client Protocol version 1 as found in Freenet versions 0.5 and 0.6.  The software is used to anonymously publish complete freesites using either one-shot or edition based sites into Freenet's distrubuted file system.  The software is designed to be easy to use and implements complete thread control so that stalled insertion processes can be restarted.\nThe entire program is coded in C and can be compiled using the MinGW compiler on wine.  The program makes use of Zlib and Minizip to implement container freesites.  Networking is done using the sprech multiplatform networking library.  \nDue to the unstable nature of Freenet development and the introduction of mature Freenet Java clients, a version for use with Freenet 0.7 has not been released. Etherboot is normally used for for booting PCs diskless, which\nis particularly usefule with clusters, routers, remote servers, and\nmachines working in environments that are unfriendly to disks.\n\nEtherboot usually boots computers faster than from a disk because\nthere are no delays in spinning up disks, etc. It can work with RAM\ndisks, NFS filesystems, or even local disks. Compared to booting from\nsolid-state devices, it has the advantage of centralising\nmaintainance. The tradeoff is dependence on a server, but this can be\npartly alleviated by having redundant servers. See the home page for a\ncomplete list of hardware and configuration needed to run Etherboot.	
3066	etherape	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/etherape	http://etherape.sourceforge.net/	Network monitor	EtherApe is a network monitor modeled after\netherman with ethernet, ip and tcp modes. It displays network activity\ngraphically. Active hosts are shown as circles of varying size, and\ntraffic among them as lines of varying width with per-protocol color\ncoded displays.\n\n<P>It supports Ethernet, FDDI, Token Ring, ISDN, PPP and SLIP\ndevices. It can filter traffic to be shown, and can read traffic from\na file as well as live from the network.\n

3076	epsjoin	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/epsjoin	http://gertjan.freezope.org/epsjoin/	Creates PostScript document from eps images	'epsjoin' is a gtk2/gnome app that builds a single\npostscript file from a group of loose eps files by putting each eps\nfile on a single page, where it can be individually rotated and\ntranslated to correct scanning imperfections. As this happens at\npostscript level, there are no raster operations, which means no loss\nof quality no matter how many rotations you need to get it\nperfect. The resulting postscript can be directly viewed, printed, or\nopened again to add, remove, reorder or modify images.\n	
3077	epsilon	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/epsilon	http://www.gnu.org/software/epsilon/	Strongly-typed omega-order programming language	'GNU epsilon' is a purely-functional\nstrongly-typed omega-order language, moving towards Lisp in that it\nallows dynamic management of source code at runtime. It is oriented to\nease of development and readability.  The static scoping rule and the\ntype checkings at compile-time should make the language "safe".\n<pre>\nIts features include: \n     * static scoping\n     * first-class functions\n     * Hindley-Milner type system with type inference\n     * modules\n     * synonym, concrete and abstract types, with polymorphism\n     * a scanner generator\n     * a purely functional I/O system, inspired by Haskell\n     * can generate C code, Scheme code, and bytecode for a virual machine\n</pre>\nThe package currently includes a compiler, interpreter,\nruntime system, and garbage collector.  Planned or not yet finished:\nparser generator, classes, an extensive library, optimizer, partial\nevaluator, pretty-printer, an Emacs mode, parellel implementation for\nSMPs and clusters, interoperability with other languages via CORBA.\n

3083	ephemeris	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ephemeris	http://www.ephemeris.com/software.html	Reads, writes and interpolates planetary positions using JPL&#39;s ephemeris files	'Ephemeris' reads, writes, and interpolates the\nJPL planetary ephemeris data that is the world standard planetary\ndataset. It should compile on any machine that uses gcc and supports\nIEEE floating point arithmetic, and has been tested under GNU/Linux.  It\nuses an included library, gnulliver.c, that automatically handles\ninteger and floating point Big-endian/Little-endian byte swapping to\nmatch Big-endian/network order on any computer.  gnulliver.c can be\nused separately under the LGPL 2.1.\n\n<P>This is a redesign of JPL's original FORTRAN code, available on\nJPL's FTP website (ftp://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/pub/eph/export/), with some\nadded flexibility (including patching some inconsistencies in the\noriginal JPL data files). 'Ephemeris' is not associated with JPL or\nNASA, but just uses JPL's data.\n	
3084	epeiosCGI	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/epeiosCGI	http://epeios.org/ecgi	C library to help create CGI-based Web applications	The Epeios libraries are a set of C++ libraries\nfor writing CGIs (software called by a http server and which handles\nuser requests and returns a HTML page). CGIs written using the ECGI\nlibraries are very different from most CGIs. They are actually daemons\nwhich receive the user requests and return an XML flow (they are\nreferered to here as CGIDs-- Common Gateway Interface Daemon-- to\navoid confusion with classical CGIs).\n\n<P>To develop a CGID, the ECGI libraries provide objects dedicated to\nhandling user requests and the managing ksessions.  The core Epeios\nlibraries provide what is needed to generate the XML flow.  CGIDs can\nbe can be hosted by a different server than the one hosting the http\nserver, so several http server can access them simultaneously. This is\nuseful for load balancing and high availability.\n

EncFS is an encrypted pass-through filesystem which runs in userspace on GNU/Linux (using the FUSE kernel module). Similar in design to CFS and other pass-through filesystems, all data is encrypted and stored in the underlying filesystem. Unlike loopback filesystems, there is no predetermined or  pre-allocated filesystem size.

3132	efax	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/efax	http://www.cce.com/efax/	Sends and receives faxes	efax is a small simple fax system for single user\nsystems. 3134	eev	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/eev	http://angg.twu.net/index.html	Emacs support for e-scripts	E-scripts are files containing notes about how to\ndo certain computer tasks. Some parts of an e-script are written in\nEnglish or in other human languages, and are not intended to be\ninterpreted by the computer in any way; other parts contain logs of\nthe interactions with the programs that were involved in the task, in\na form that allows not only inspection and textual modification but\nalso controlled "re-execution" - that is, repeating that interaction\nin another moment, with or without modification, from the steps\nregistered in the log, without the need to repeat each keystroke or\nmouse-click by hand.\n\n<P>So: e-scripts are a way of taking "executable notes" of what you\ndo. If you interact with the system using Emacs and Eev then notes in\ne-script form will get produced more or less automatically, and\nredoing things that you've already done before becomes trivial.\n

3161	e	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/e	http://martin.ankerl.com/2006/08/11/program-e-extract-any-archive	&quot;is a command line utility that extracts lots of different archives.	The program e is a command line utility that extracts lots of different archives. It is very simple and can be extended very easily.\n<br>\nIt is inspired by how firewall use their rulesets, and works like this:\n<ul>\n<li>For each file that has to be extracted, the rules are matched one after the other.</li>\n<li>When a rule matches (either by the filetype or filename), the command is executed.</li>\n<li>If the command does not return an error code  the extraction is considered successful,  otherwise the next rules are matched.</li>\n<li>It currently has rules for zip, rar, 7zip, gzip, bzip2, rpm, cab, arj, ace, ppmd, lzo, tar.bz2, tar.gz, ar, cpio, dar, uharc, zzip, and many more.</li>\n</ul>\n

Dynalbum is a fully dynamic automatic Web photo album generator. The album includes an index page with thumbnails, navigation tools on each album page, and four sizes of each picture. The entire album is dynamically generated from a directory of JPEGs, TIFFs, PNGs, and GIFs when it is accessed. Unlike other photo album generators, it doesn't clutter files with thumbnails and static HTML. It generates each page and each scaled image (including thumbnails) dynamically every time it is accessed. This means that there's no need to keep static copies of anything but the original pictures.

Furthermore, it does not read the postamble, so it can be\nstarted before TeX finishes. \n\n<P>There is a -follow switch that makes dvipng wait at EOF for further\noutput, unless it finds the POST marker that indicates the end of the\nDVI. It supports PK and VF fonts, color specials, and more.\n

3176	dvbcut	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/dvbcut	http://dvbcut.sourceforge.net/	A GUI application for cutting parts out of MPEG videos.	dvbcut is a Qt application that allows you to select certain parts of an MPEG transport stream (as received via Digital Video Broadcasting) and save these parts into a single MPEG output file. It follows a "keyhole surgery" approach where the input video and audio data are mostly kept unchanged, and only very few frames at the beginning and/or end of the selected range are re-encoded in order to obtain a valid MPEG file.

3178	duro	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/duro	http://duro.sf.net./	Duro is a relational  free and open source database library written in C. It is based on the princip	The goal of the Duro project is to create a library which is as compliant with the proposed database language D as it is possible for a C library. This library is supposed to serve as a basis for a truly relational database management system (TRDBMS).\n<ul>\n    <li> Tuples and tables (relvars).</li>\n    <li> Relational algebra: RENAME, select (restrict), project, EXTEND, JOIN, SEMIJOIN, UNION, INTERSECT, MINUS, SEMIMINUS, SUMMARIZE PER, DIVIDEBY PER, WRAP, UNWRAP, GROUP, and UNGROUP.</li>\n    <li> Virtual tables (views).</li>\n    <li> Locking and nested transactions.</li>\n<li> Duro tables are true sets -- uniqueness of tuples (rows) is always enforced. When creating real tables, at least one candidate key must be supplied. A candidate key may be empty.</li>\n<li>User-defined types (including type constraints) and operators.</li>\n<li>Declarative integrity.</li>\n<li>Tcl interface, including support for relational expressions in Tutorial D syntax and operators implemented in Tcl ("stored procedures").</li>\n<li> Simple GUI admin tool. </li>\n</ul>xs\nDuro is implemented on top of the Berkeley DB database library.\n	
3179	dupseek	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/dupseek	http://www.beautylabs.net/software/dupseek.html	Finds and removes duplicate files	Dupseek groups files by size, then reads and\ncompares small chunks of the files of the same size. It creates\nsmaller groups depending on these comparisons. It proceeds with bigger\nand bigger chunks (of size up to a hard-coded limit). It stops reading\nfrom files as soon as they form a single-element group or they are\nread completely (which only happens when they have a very high\nprobability of having duplicates). The program does remove files, but\nit asks first.\n\n<P>Dupseek aims for maximum efficiency by keeping file reads to a\nminimum and is much better than other similar programs when dealing\nwith groups of large files of the same size. It can be interrupted at\nany moment. The user is then presented with partial results and can\neither intervene manually or go on with the reading and computation,\non a group-by-group basis.\n	
3180	dupmerge	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/dupmerge	http://sourceforge.net/projects/dupmerge	Reclaims disk space from redundant files	'dupmerge' reads a list of files from standard\ninput (eg., as produced by "find . -print") and looks for identical\nfiles. When it finds two or more identical files, all but one are\nunlinked to reclaim the disk space and recreated as hard links to the\nremaining copy.\n	
3181	duplicity	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/duplicity	http://savannah.nongnu.org/projects/duplicity	Incremental backup tool	'duplicity' is an incremental backup tool that backs\nup files and directories by building tar-format volumes and uploading\nthem to a file server. By default, these volumes will be GPG\nencrypted, although simple gzipping is also supported. It supports\nlocal, FTP, and ssh/scp back-ends. \n\n<P>Because it uses librsync, archives only record the parts of files\nthat have changed since the last backup. It supports deleted files,\nfull Unix permissions, directories, symbolic links, and fifos, but\ncurrently not hard links.\n

3183	dump	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/dump	http://dump.sourceforge.net/	The &#39;dump&#39; and &#39;restore&#39; functions	This package contains both 'dump' and\n'restore'. 'Dump' examines files in a filesystem, determines which\nones need to be backed up, and copies those files to a specified\nstorage medium. 'Restore' performs the inverse function; it can\nrestore a full backup of a filesystem. It can also layer subsequent\nincremental backups on top of the full backup, and restore single\nfiles and directory subtrees from full or partial backups.\n	
3184	dtl	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/dtl	http://dtemplatelib.sourceforge.net/index.htm	Makes ODBC recordsets look like STL containers	The Database Template Library makes ODBC\nrecordsets look just like STL containers. Users move through\ncontainers using standard STL iterators, and if they insert(),\nerase(), or replace() records in the containers, changes are\nautomatically committed to the database. Since 'dtl' complies with STL\niterator and container standards, users can plug abstractions into a\nrange of STL algorithms for data storage, searching, and\nmanipulation. \n\n<P>The C++ reflection mechanism used to bind to database tables lets\nusers add generic indexing and lookup properties to the containers\nwithout requiring special code. Since the code takes full advantage of\nthe template mechanism, 'dtl' adds minimal overhead (compared with\nusing raw ODBC calls).\n	
3185	dtemplate	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/dtemplate	http://hacks.dlux.hu/dTemplate/	Template system	dTemplate is a flexible template system. It can\ngenerate HTML or newsletters, etc., and is similar to the\nCGI::FastTemplate system in that it separates the code from the design. \n\nYou can define only one kind of template variable (placeholder),\nbut you can assign anything you want to it, even an unnamed\nsubroutine, which can parse other templates. You can define a template\nparse tree this way. Advanced features include printf formatting of\ntemplate variables (for statistic generation), transparent handling of\nmultiple styles of a template (for multi-language sites or skinned\nweb-pages), and encoders (uri_encoder and html_encoder). You can write\ntemplate-parsing routines in the same way the templates are structured\nlogically: starting from the biggest and going to the smallest.\n

3194	drbd	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/drbd	http://www.drbd.org/	Block device for building high-availability clusters	'drbd' is a block device for building\nhigh-availability clusters. DRBD takes over the data, writes it to the\nlocal disk and sends it to the other host. On the other host, it takes\nit to the disk there. The other components needed are a cluster\nmembership service, which is supposed to be heartbeat, and an\napplication that works on top of a block device (ie, a filesystem and\nfsck).\n\n<P>Each device has either a 'primary' or 'secondary' state. The\napplication should run and access the device on the node with the\nprimary device. Every write is sent to the local 'lower level block\ndevice' and to the node with the device in 'secondary' state. The\nsecondary device then writes the data to its lower level block device.\nIf the primary node fails, heartbeat is switching the secondary device\ninto primary state and starts the application there. If the failed\nnode comes up again, it is a new secondary node and will synchronise\nits content to the primary node whithout interruption of service in\nthe background. Only those parts of the device that actually have been\nchanged will resync.\n

3199	dparser	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/dparser	http://dparser.sourceforge.net/	Scannerless GLR parser generator	'DParser' is a scannerless GLR parser generator\nbased on the Tomita algorithm. It is self-hosted and very easy to\nuse. Grammars are written in a natural style of EBNF and regular\nexpressions and support both speculative and final actions.\n\n<P<Through a combination of regular expressions and grammar\nproductions, users specify the form of the text to be parsed. Because\nof the parsing technique (a scannerless GLR parser based on the Tomita\nalgorithm) there are no restrictions.  The grammar can be ambiguous,\nright or left recursive, have any number of null productions, and\nbecause there is no seperate tokenizer, can include whitespace in\nterminals and have terminals which are prefixes of other terminals.\nDParser handles well formed computer languages and data files as well\nas real world situations.\n

3229	distcc	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/distcc	http://distcc.samba.org/	Distributes code compilation across a network	'distcc' distributes compilation of C or C++ code\nacross several machines on a network. It should always generate the\nsame results as a local compile, is simple to install and use, and is\noften significantly faster than a local compile.\n\n'distcc' does not require all machines to share a filesystem, have\nsynchronized clocks, or to have the same libraries or header files\ninstalled. Machines can be running different operating systems, as\nlong as they have compatible binary formats or cross-compilers.\n'distcc' sends the complete preprocessed source code across the network\nfor each job, so all it requires of the volunteer machines is that\nthey be running the distccd daemon, and that they have an appropriate\ncompiler installed.

3238	dirsync	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/dirsync	http://www.viara.cn/en/dirsync.htm	A directory synchronizer.	DirSync is a directory synchronizer that takes a source and destination directory as arguments and recursively ensures that the two directories are identical. It can be used to create incremental copies of large chunks of data. For example, if your file server's contents are in the directory /data, you can make a copy in a directory called /backup with the command "dirsync /data /backup"; The first time you run it, all data will be copied. On subsequent runs, only the changed files are copied.

3251	diffutils	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/diffutils	http://www.gnu.org/software/diffutils/diffutils.html	Finds differences between and among files	A group of utilities that displays difference\nbetween and among text files.\n\n'diff' outputs the difference between two files in any of several\nformats. If the files are identical, it normally produces no ouput; if\nthey are binary (non-text) it normally reports only that they are\ndifferent.\n\n'cmp' shows the offsets and files numbers where two files differ; it\ncan also show, side by side, all the characters that differ between\nthe two files.\n\n'sdiff' merges two files interactively.\n\n'diff3' shows differences among three files. If two people have made\nindependent changes to a common original, diff3 reports that\ndifference between the original and the two changed versions, and\ncan produce a merged file that contains both persons' changes along\nwith warnings about conflicts.       \n

Conversely, when it reads files for inclusion in pwads, it does the necessary conversions (for example, from PPM to Doom picture format). In addition, DeuTex has functions such as merging wads, etc.

3295	deal.II	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/deal.II	http://www.dealii.org/	Adaptive finite element code library	'deal.II' is a software library that supports\nfinite element computations on adaptive 1d, 2d, and 3d meshes. It\ncomes with mesh handling, supports a large number of finite elements,\ncan input and output in various formats, and has a large collection of\nsupport classes. The handling of different space dimensions is hidden\nbehind C++ templates; this lets users treat problems in different\nspace dimensions simultaneously within the same program, and to switch\ndimensions simply by recompilation. This means users can test their\napplication in 2d, and then run production runs in 3d without having\nto debug the program again.\n\n<P>It comes with full documentation of all APIs and 18 example\nprograms showing how to build finite element programs from simple to\nvery complex. The documentation now runs about 4000 pages.\n

Other uses include a file-access\nmonitor/logger or external security implementations. \n\n<P>It operates by intercepting file access calls and passing the file\ninformation to a 3rd-party application. This application then tells\nthe device driver to allow or deny the file access. Every time the points would come out inaccurate and a rather poor reproduction of the actual data. I wanted to write a program that would automate this task, and do a much better job at that. But then, that was three years ago.\n    Finally its done. Its not the best thing that I have created, but certainly, one of the most useful. 3316	darwin2k	2010-05-03 16:09:24	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/darwin2k	http://www.darwin2k.com/	Robotics design and simulation program	'Darwin2k' is a robotics design and simulation\nprogram. Its simulation capabilities support engineering design and\ncontroller prototyping for robotic application; for example, it\nincludes detailed motor and gearhead performance models, and the\nability to estimate stresses in structural elements during simulation.\n\n<P>Darwin2K is *not* an end-user application. Most uses will require\nat least a little coding, usually to specify application-specific\nrobot controllers and models, high-level task descriptions, or\nspecialized simulation components. That being said, Darwin2K does\ninclude a range of general-purpose robot models, controllers, and\nsimulation and analysis capabilities, useful in a wide range of robot\ndesign and programming applications, that eliminate most of the work\nin developing a task-specific simulation or optimized robot prototype.\nThe system also includes a distributed evolutionary algorithm for\nautomated synthesis and optimization.\n

Advanced features of C are not\nnecessary, although they are available. \n\n<P>As of Version 3.0, Dap can read SBS programs, thereby freeing the\nuser from having to learn any C at all to run straightforward\nanalyses. JetDirect) protocols, and adds network\nprinter browsing and PostScript Printer Description ("PPD")-based\nprinting options to support real-world printing under UNIX. \n\nCUPS also includes a customized version of GNU Ghostscript and an\nimage file RIP that are used to support non-PostScript\nprinters. The C pre-processor is widely\nused in Haskell source code, but a true cpp is not often available on\nsome systems, and the common cpp provided by the gcc 3.x series is\nchanging in ways that are incompatible with Haskell's syntax. \n\n<P>This includes problems with, for instance, string gaps, and prime\ncharacters in identifiers. This project attempts to provide an\nalternative to cpp that is more compatible with Haskell and can be\ndistributed with compilers.\n

The archive can be another file on the disk, a magnetic tape,\nor a pipe.\n\nGNU cpio supports the following archive formats: binary, old ASCII,\nnew ASCII, crc, HPUX binary, HPUX old ASCII, old tar, and POSIX.1\ntar. The tar format is provided for compatibility with the tar\nprogram. By default, cpio creates binary format archives for\ncompatibility with older cpio programs. 3399	cowloop	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/cowloop	http://www.ATConsultancy.nl/cowloop/	Copy-on-write loop driver	The cowloop-driver is a copy-on-write loop driver\n(block device) which can be used on top of any other block driver. It\nshields the lower driver from any write access and diverts all\nwrite-accesses to an arbitrary regular file, called the cowfile. \n\n<P>When a modified block is read again later on, the cowloop-driver\ngets the block from the cowfile, while non-modified blocks are\nobtained from the original read-only device. This lets block-devices\nbe used in a read-write fashion without modifying the underlying\nblock-device itself.\n

3401	courier	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/courier	http://www.courier-mta.org/	Integrated mail/groupware server	The Courier mail transfer agent (MTA) is an\nintegrated mail/groupware server based on open commodity protocols\nsuch as ESMTP, IMAP, POP3, LDAP, SSL, and HTTP. It provides ESMTP,\nIMAP, POP3, webmail, and mailing list services within a single,\nconsistent, framework. Individual components can be enabled or\ndisabled at will. Courier now implements basic web-based calendaring\nand scheduling services integrated in the webmail module. \n\nCourier implements SMTP extensions for mailing list management and\nspam filtering. Courier can function as an intermediate mail relay,\nrelaying mail between an internal LAN and the Internet, or perform\nfinal delivery to mailboxes. Courier uses maildirs as its native mail\nstorage format, but it can also deliver mail to legacy mailbox files\nas well. Courier's configuration is set by plain text files and Perl\nscripts. Most of Courier's configuration can now be adjusted from a\nweb browser, using Courier's web-based administration module.

3409	core-restart	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/core-restart	http://www.geocities.com/asimshankar/checkpointing/	Checkpointing and restarting system	'core-restart' is a process checkpointing and\nrestarting system. It does not require the executables to be linked\nwith a library, so processes can be checkpointed without being\nchanged. Also, the restarted process and the restoration code are in\nindependent address spaces which simplifies the mechanism of restoring\nthe stack and register state of the checkpointed process. The system\nruns only on user-level code and requires no modifications to the\nkernel.\n

3412	cook	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/cook	http://www.canb.auug.org.au/~millerp/cook/	Tool for constructing files	Cook is a tool for constructing files. It is given\na set of files to create, and recipes of how to create them. In any\nnon-trivial program there will be prerequisites to performing the\nactions necessary to creating any file, such as include files. Cook\nprovides a mechanism to define these. \n\nWhen a program is being developed or maintained, the programmer\nwill typically change one file of several which comprise the\nprogram. Ccok examines the last-modified times of the files to see\nwhen the prerquisites of a file have changed, implying that the file\nneeds to be recreated as it is logically out of date.

This\ncomes in very handy if, for example, one switches from an 8-bit locale\nto an UTF-8 locale. It has some smart features: it automagically\nrecognises if a file is already UTF-8 encoded (thus partly converted\nfilesystems can be fully moved to UTF-8) and it also takes care of\nsymlinks. It can also convert from normalization form C (UTF-8 NFC) to\nNFD and vice-versa. \n

Contracts in e-commerce are one possible application, but the programs in this package are not limited to any particular use.  The package is desinged with security and resource economy in mind, because of possible embedded applications in handheld devices, smart cards, and other attractive targets for e-commerce.

3422	compilercache	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/compilercache	http://www.erikyyy.de/compilercache/	C and C++ compiler wrapper	'Compilercache' is a wrapperscript around your C\nand C++ compilers. Each time you compile something, it puts the result\ninto a cache. If you compile the same thing again, the result will be\npicked from the cache instead of being recompiled. The same applies if\nyou change your compiler options: the old compilation is picked up\nfrom the cache, which speeds things up considerably. No Makefiles, no\ncleaning up dependencies, and no recompilation if you switch compiler\noptions.\n\n<P>Additionally, if you download an updated version of a package\nalready on your system and compile it using compilercache, only the\nchanged sources will be recompiled.\n

Other\npossible applications include indentifying the author of an\nunattributed piece, or reavealing a point at which an author first\nread a work.

3425	commoncpp	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/commoncpp	http://www.gnu.org/software/commoncpp/	Highly portable C++ class library	Common C++ is a C++ class library that abstracts\nvarious system services in a portable manner, thereby making the\ncreation of portable applications much easier. It is portable code,\nwith very low runtime overhead, that works well on a very wide range\nof target platforms and C++ compilers in everyday use. It includes the\n'ape' project, which was formerly a separate package.\n\n<P>Common C++ manages threads, synchronization, and network sockets by\noffering portable C++ classes that abstract these services, as well as\nsupporting "serial" I/O, daemon specific event logging, object\nserialization (persistence), block/record/page/ oriented file I/O, and\nconfiguration file parsing. It also provides an inheritable class\narchitecture for your application that exploits C++ as needed.\n\n<P>There are two source trees: one for "POSIX" systems such as\nGNU/LINUX and the Hurd, the other for the Win 32 API. This makes\nCommon C++ portable at the source level, as the two trees implement a\nfunctionally similar class interface.\n

'comfigure'\nautomatically recognizes the package name and version from the\ndirectory from which it was called. If the stored version is not equal\nto the current one, 'comfigure' calculates an MD5 digest sum over the\noutput of './configure --help' to see if the available options have\nchanged. If they have, the program asks the user what to do.\n

3433	collectd	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/collectd	http://collectd.org	Collects system information and writes the results in an RRD-file	'collectd' is a small daemon which collects system\ninformation every 10 seconds and writes the results in an\nRRD-file. The statistics gathered include: CPU and memory usage,\nsystem load, network latency (ping), network interface traffic, and\nsystem temperatures (using lm-sensors), and disk usage. 'collectd' is\nnot a script; it is written in C for performance and portability. It\nstays in the memory so there is no need to start up a heavy\ninterpreter every time new values should be logged.\n

3498	checker	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/checker	http://www.gnu.org/software/checker/	Finds memory errors at runtime	'checker' can help find bugs that standard tools\ncannot always find. The best example is memory leaks. A memory leak is\na zone of memory, allocated with malloc that is not used anymore. So\nthe memory allocated is lost. This means you program needs more\nmemory and runs slower, since your OS might have to start swapping. \n\n<P>It detects bad memory accesses such as: reading uninitialized\nmemory, writing in a freed zone, writing or reading outside of a\nmemory block, and using NULL pointers. This is particularly useful\nfor big programs with many functions.\n\n<P>Checker maintains bitmaps to keep track of the status of each byte\nof memory. The status can be writable, readable, both, or none. When\nmemory is allocated, the new memory becomes write-only: you are not\nallowed to read it because it has not been initialized. But when you\nyou write to this new block, those bytes become readable and\nwritable. When the block is freed, the bytes become unreadable and\nunwritable. Red zones are unreadable and unwritable memory, so that\neach access to a red zone produces a warning.

It can automatically run checkaliases and\nnewaliases after saving the aliases file.

3520	cgal	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/cgal	http://www.cgal.org/	A Computational Geometry Algorithms Library	\nThe goal of the CGAL Project is to provide easy access to\nefficient and reliable geometric algorithms in the form of a C++\nlibrary. CGAL is used in various areas needing geometric computation,\nsuch as: computer graphics, scientific visualization, computer aided\ndesign and modeling, geographic information systems, molecular biology,\nmedical imaging, robotics and motion planning, mesh generation,\nnumerical methods...\n<br>\nCGAL offers data structures and algorithms like triangulations (2D\nconstrained triangulations and Delaunay triangulations in 2D and 3D),\nVoronoi diagrams (for 2D and 3D points, 2D additively weighted Voronoi\ndiagrams, and segment Voronoi diagrams), Boolean operations on polygons\nand polyhedra, arrangements of curves and their applications (2D and 3D\nenvelopes, Minkowski sums) mesh generation (2D Delaunay mesh generation\nand 3D surface mesh generation, skin surfaces), geometry processing\n(surface mesh simplification, subdivision and parameterization, as well\nas estimation of local differential properties, and approximation of\nridges and umbilics), alpha shapes, convex hull algorithms (in 2D, 3D\nand dD), operations on polygons (straight skeleton and offset polygon),\nsearch structures (kd trees for nearest neighbor search, and range and\nsegment trees), interpolation (natural neighbor interpolation and\nplacement of streamlines), shape analysis, fitting, and distances\n(smallest enclosing sphere of points or spheres, smallest enclosing\nellipsoid of points, principal component analysis), and kinetic data\nstructures. All these data structures and algorithms operate on\ngeometric objects like points and segments, and perform geometric tests\non them. These objects and predicates are regrouped in CGAL Kernels.\n

3530	celestia	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/celestia	http://www.shatters.net/celestia/	Visual simulation of space	Celestia is a real-time visual simulation of\nspace. Choose a point within the Local Group of galaxies, and Celestia\nwill show you an approximation of how it would appear to your eyes\nwere you actually there. Some of what Celestia shows is necessarily\nhypothetical--the farther away from Earth you get, the less real data\nthere is and the more guesswork is involved. Thus Celestia supplements\nobservational data with good guesses based on models of stellar and\nplanetary processes.\n\nYou can also navigate at an immense range of scales. Orbit a couple\nkilometers above the surface of a tiny, irregular asteroid, then head\noff toward Jupiter, watching it grow from a bright point of light into\na looming sphere filling your field of vision. Leave our solar system\nentirely and observe the sun as it fades from a brilliant disk to a\nbright star, disappearing almost entirely as you head off toward the\nUpsilon Andromeda system to orbit around its innermost giant planet.\n

3544	ccvisu	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ccvisu	http://mtc.epfl.ch/~beyer/CCVisu/	A Tool for General Force-Directed Graph Layout and Co-Change Visualization	The tool CCVisu is a light-weight tool for force-directed graph layout. The tool reads the input graph from a file in RSF (Rigi Standard Format), which is a standard text format for relations. The layout of the graph is computed using standard techniques from force-directed layout. The tool supports several energy models, which can be selected by setting command line parameters. The weighted edge-repulsion LinLog energy model (default) is good for producing layouts that fulfill certain clustering criteria. The Fruchterman Reingold energy model is good for producing layouts that fulfill certain esthetic criteria like uniform edge length. CCVisu stores the resulting layout in certain text file formats such as VRML or SVG, or it displays the layout on the screen.	
3545	ccscript	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ccscript	http://www.gnu.org/software/ccscript/	C++ class framework for creating a virtual machine execution system	GNU ccScript is a C++ class framework for creating\na virtual machine execution system for use with and as a\nscripting/assembler language for state-transition driven realtime\nsystems. It is the core of the scripting engine found in GNU Bayonne.\n\n<P>It is meant to be used where step execution is important, and where\neach step is in response to a callback event or a state machine\ntransition. It offers deterministic execution and low overhead so that\nmany concurrent instances can run together. However, in addition to\noffering step machine execution, GNU ccScript loads all scripts into\nan active image at once. This is for performance, as all operations in\nthe script system, to assure deterministic execution, are in memory.\n\n<P>GNU ccScript also offers the ability to load new scripts en\nmasse. Existing active sessions operate on the currently loaded\nscripts, and new sessions are offered the new script. When the last\nactive session on an old script set completes, the entire script set\nis flushed from memory, so you can operate scripted servers without\ndowntime for rebuilding script images in memory.\n	
3546	ccrypt	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ccrypt	http://ccrypt.sourceforge.net/	Encryption utility	'ccrypt' is a utility for encrypting and decrypting\nfiles and streams. It was designed to replace the standard Unix 'crypt'\nutility, which is notorious for using a very weak encryption\nalgorithm. 'ccrypt' is based on the Rijndael cipher, which is the\nU.S. government's chosen candidate for the Advanced Encryption\nStandard (AES). This cipher is believed to provide very strong\nsecurity.\n\nUnlike unix crypt, the algorithm provided by ccrypt is not symmetric\n(one must specify whether to encrypt or decrypt). Encryption and\ndecryption depend on a user-supplied keyword (key phrase). Keywords can be\nany number of characters; all characters are significant (although\nccrypt internally hashes the key to 256 bits). Longer keywords provide\nbetter security, since they are less likely to be discovered by\nexhaustive search.	
3547	ccruncher	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ccruncher	http://www.generacio.com/ccruncher/	A calculator for the credit risk for large portfolios using Monte Carlo method.	CreditCruncher is a program that uses the Monte\nCarlo method to compute the credit risk of large\nportfolios in which assets are mortgages, loans,\nbonds, endorsements, or the like (all of them of\nfixed income with a policy buy/sell and hold). The\ndefault time is simulated using a gaussian copula,\ntaking into account the transition matrix (or\nsurvival function) and sectorial correlation\nmatrix defined by the user.\n

3552	ccbuild	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ccbuild	http://www.ai.rug.nl/~bneijt/prog/C++/ccbuild	Autobuild utility	'ccbuild' is like a dynamic Makefile: it finds all\nprograms in the current directory (containing "int main") and compiles\nthem. To do this, it reads the C++ sources and looks at all local and\nglobal includes. All C++ files around local includes are considered\nobjects for the main program. \n\n<P>The global includes lead to extra compiler arguments using a\nconfiguration file. ccbuild splits these arguments for compilation and\nlinking, keeping the linking arguments back for later use. It should\nallow development without any scripting and only simple reusable\nconfiguration. 'ccbuild' can also create simple Makefiles and graph\ndependencies using DOT (graphviz) graphs.\n	
3553	ccaudio2	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ccaudio2	http://www.gnu.org/software/ccaudio	Library and software for manipulating audio data	GNU ccAudio is a stand-alone C++ class library and\nnewly designated GNU package for manipulating audio data, whether on\ndisk or in memory.  GNU ccAudio offers the ability to work with audio\nfile formats on disk by treating audio data as sequenced arrays of\nsample data rather than as arbitrary octets as some audio file\nmanipulation libraries do.\n\n<P>In addition to being audio content aware, GNU ccAudio allows header\nmanipulation for setting things like annotation fields. 3554	ccache	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ccache	http://ccache.samba.org/	Compiler cache	'Ccache' is a fast compiler cache. It acts as a\ncaching pre-processor to C/C++ compilers, using the -E compiler switch\nand a hash to detect when a compilation can be satisfied from\ncache. When the same code is compiled again the cached output is used,\ngiving a significant speedup (typically 5x). You can also create\nsymbolic links from your compiler's name to ccache; this lets you use\nccache without any changes to your build system.\n\n'Ccache' produces the same output that the real compiler would,\nincluding the same object files and compiler warnings that the real\ncompiler would produce. The only way to tell you are using ccache is\nthe speed.

3602	bugdar	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/bugdar	http://www.bluestatic.org/software/bugdar/	Is a bug tracking system.	Bugdar is a bug tracking system that is meant to replace other solutions that are slow and cumbersome. It features a completely comprehensive permissions and usergroups system that allows for extremely flexible control over what users can access. To ensure that your server never lags, portions of Bugdar's data is cached to both reduce load and increase speed. If you want to change any aspect of Bugdar's appearance, all you have to do is edit the semantic XHTML templates or one of the CSS definitions that control the entirety of Bugdar.\nOne of the unique features in Bugdar is the "automations" system. This allows administrators to define a macro that will change any field in a bug and then add a comment with the click of a button. This makes marking a bug closed, fixed, and leaving a comment when a bug is done very easy.\n\nOther features include: custom fields, email notifications, Atom syndication, historical logging, "favorite" bugs, voting, and internationalization support.\n

3618	bras	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/bras	http://bras.berlios.de/	Command execution tool	Bras is a rules-based command execution system, a\nla 'make'. It helps to keep targets (usually, but not neccessarily,\nfiles) , up-to-date with respect to a set of dependencies. For every\ntarget, a (freely definable) rule describes what it means for the\ntarget to be out-of-date and what has to be done to refresh it. Bras\ncan follow targets into other directories. It acts there according to\nthe local brasfile to update the target and then reports the result\nback. Because no recursive execution of bras is necessary, the result\nof the reasoning for that other directory is not lost.\n\n<P>Bras is implemented in Tcl. Rules can be mixed with procedural\nparts. In particular control structures can be used to automatically\ncollect lists of targets, find out platform specifics or selectively\nactivate rules. 'Bras' normally runs from the command line, but its\nrule eveluation functionality is available as a TCL module and can be\nused in a GUI application implemented in Tcl/tk.\n	
3619	brag	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/brag	http://brag.sourceforge.net/	Collects and assembles multipart binary attachments	Brag collects and assembles multipart binary\nattachements from newsgroups. It is best suited to run as a cron\njob. It supports for uuencode, MIME base64, and yenc encodings, NNTP\nauthentication, non-default NNTP ports, and message filtering with\naccept/reject patterns. It can combine parts from different newsgroups\nor even different servers, and optionally saves message subjects.\n

3622	bpel2owfn	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/bpel2owfn	http://www.gnu.org/software/bpel2owfn/index.html	translates a web service expressed in BPEL into an oWFN	\nBPEL2oWFN translates a web service expressed in BPEL (Business Process\nExecution Language for Web Services) into an oWFN (open Workflow Net).\nThis oWFN can be used to:\n<ul>\n<li>check for controllability or generate the operating guideline using Fiona (www.informatik.hu-berlin.de/top/tools4bpel/fiona)</li>\n<li>check for deadlocks or any other Petri net property</li>\n<li>check any temporal logic formula with a variety of model checking tools.</li>\n</ul>\nBPEL2oWFN uses static analysis to make the generated oWFN as compact as\npossible to analyze a chosen property. This is called flexible model\ngeneration.\n<br>\nBPEL2oWFN is the successor of BPEL2PN (www.informatik.hu-berlin.de/top/bpel2pn), a Java-based compiler generating low-level Petri nets. BPEL2oWFN is a re-implementation for extensibility and performance issues. Its functionality is a superset of the functionality of BPEL2PN.\n<br>\nGNU BPEL2oWFN was written by Niels Lohmann, Christian Gierds and Martin Znamirowski. It is part of the Tools4BPEL project funded by the Bundesministerium fr Bildung und Forschung.\n

3628	bootstrapper	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/bootstrapper	http://bootstrapper.sourceforge.net/	Creates a customized bootstrapping script	The bootstrapper program creates a customized\nbootstrap script by scanning the autoconf macros in a project's\nconfigure.in file and using them to determine which programs need to\nbe used to create a usable configure script. It then creates a\nbootstrap script which is custom tailored to your project's\nconfiguration.\n\n<P>The resulting bootstrap script is useful for rebuilding the\nconfigure script and Makefile.in files, particularly for a project\nwhich may be downloaded off of a cvs server. By including a bootstrap\nscript in a cvs repository, all auto generated files related to\nconfigure can be excluded from the cvs repository. It is also useful\nfor a developer importing a new project onto a cvs repository. Running\n`make distclean' then `./bootstrap --clean' removes all auto-generated\nfiles, instead of removing them by hand.\n

3659	blossoc	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/blossoc	http://www.daimi.au.dk/~mailund/Blossoc	A block-association mapping tool.	Blossoc is a linkage disequilibrium association\nmapping tool that attempts to build (perfect)\ngenealogies for each site in the input, score\nthese according to non-random clustering of\naffected individuals, and judge high-scoring areas\nas likely candidates for containing disease\naffecting variation. Building the local genealogy\ntrees is based on a number of heuristics that are\nnot guaranteed to build true trees, but have the\nadvantage over more sophisticated methods of being\nextremely fast. Blossoc can therefore handle much\nlarger data sets than more sophisticated tools,\nbut at the cost of sacrificing some accuracy.\n

After setting the source clock rate and output sampling rate, waveforms are generated by specifying the time points where amplitude changes occur. Treble and bass adjustments are also supported.\nMany examples are included that show basic waveform generation, sample buffering schemes, and more advanced topics. They can be made to write output to a wave sound file, or optionally use the SDL multimedia library for real-time playback, waveform display, and mouse control of parameters.\n

3673	bitap	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/bitap	http://sourceforge.net/projects/libbitap/	Regex string matching using the bitap algorithm	The bitap library is a clean implementation of\nregular expression (regex/grep) string matching using the bitap\nalgorithm. Approximate (a.k.a. fuzzy) matching is allowed. This is the\nsame algorithm as the one used in Glimpse and agrep, but it is much\nmore complete with regard to regular expression syntax, and is much\ncleaner. \n\n<P>It is quite fast compared to other greps due to the bitap algoritm\nand modern CPU architechture. Modifying code for special cases speeds\nthings up even futher. Note that the complete 'search' string must be\nmatched by the pattern. If you want to search for substrings of the\nsearch string, prefix and postfix the pattern with '.*'.\n

3679	binfind	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/binfind	http://www.lith.at/binfind/index.html	Searches for a byte sequence in a binary file	'binfind' searches files for a byte sequence. The\npattern can be given on the command line in ASCII or hex, read from a\nfile, or a combination of the above. It uses the Boyer-Moore algorithm\nand can search large files without using a lot of memory. For each\noccurrence of the pattern, 'binfind' prints a line containing the\noffset of the occurrence in the searched file. If the user specifies\nmore than one file, binfind prints the filename and a colon before the\noffset.\n	Intermediate

3696	bffft	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/bffft	http://romo661.free.fr/bffft.html	Fortran 90 2D Vectorized Fast Fourier Transform	Using a simple array as input, a 2-dimensional Fast Fourier Transform consists of two one-dimensional FFTs performed (for instance) on each line first, and on each column next.\nAn important limitation in FFT computer applications dealing with large arrays is the fact that the algorithm is not well suited to parallelization, due to the huge amount of data that has to be transfered between computers. Since the transfers are proportional to the number of operations, network time soon becomes prominent when the number of processors is high. This program uses vectorization as an alternative  to parallelization methods.\n

'Bc' is a\nutility included in the POSIX P1003.2/D11 draft standard.\n\nThis version does not use the historical method of having bc be a\ncompiler for the dc calculator (the POSIX document doesn't specify how\nbc must be implemented). This version has a single executable that\nboth compiles the language and runs the resulting 'byte code.' The\nbyte code is not the dc language.

3719	bash	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/bash	http://www.gnu.org/software/bash/bash.html	Shell of the GNU operating system	Bash is an sh-compatible shell that incorporates\nuseful features from the Korn shell (ksh) and C shell (csh). It is\nintended to conform to the IEEE POSIX P1003.2/ISO 9945.2 Shell and\nTools standard. \n\n<P>It offers functional improvements over sh for both programming and\ninteractive use; these include command line editing, unlimited size\ncommand history, job control, shell functions and aliases, indexed\narrays of unlimited size, and integer arithmetic in any base from two\nto sixty-four. Bash can run most sh scripts without modification.\n	Intermediate
3720	basE91	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/basE91	http://base91.sourceforge.net/	Efficient binary data to ASCII text encoder	'basE91' is an advanced method for encoding binary data as\nASCII characters. It is similar to UUencode or base64, but is more efficient.\nThe overhead produced by basE91 depends on the input data. It amounts at most\nto 23% (versus 33% for base64) and can range down to 14%, which typically\noccurs on 0-byte blocks. This makes basE91 very useful for transferring larger\nfiles over binary insecure connections like e-mail or terminal lines.\n

Bartlby provides\nan open plugin interface to give every\nadministrator an easy to use option to extend the\nplugin base, and a fully customizable GUI (written\nin PHP using a C extension). 3740	backup2l	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/backup2l	http://backup2l.sourceforge.net/	Manages backups 	'backup2l' generates, maintains, and restores\nbackups on a mountable file system. The main design goals are low\nmaintenance effort, efficiency, transparency, and robustness. In a\ndefault installation, backups are created autonomously by a cron\nscript. \n\nIt supports hierarchical differential backups with a user-\nspecified number of levels and backups per level. This means the\nnumber of archives that must be stored only increases logarithmically\nwith the number of differential backups since the last full\nbackup. Hence, small incremental backups can be generated at short\nintervals while time- and space-heavy full backups are only run as\nneeded.

3761	autoproject	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/autoproject	http://packages.debian.org/unstable/devel/autoproject	Creates a skeleton source package for a new program	autoproject interviews the user, then creates a source package for a new program which follows the GNU programming standards. The new\npackage uses autoconf to configure itself, and automake to create the\nMakefile. `make distcheck' succeeds.\n.\nThe idea is that you execute autoproject just once when you start a\nnew project. It will ask a few questions, then create a new directory\nand populate it with standard files, customized for the new project.\n.\nOptionally, the new package will use a command line parser generator.\nCurrently, autoproject supports two parser generators: clig by Harald\nKirsch (kirschh@lionbioscience.com) (see http://wsd.iitb.fhg.de/~kir/clighome/), and\nautogen by Bruce Korb (korbb@datadesign.com) (see\nftp://autogen.sourceforge.net/autoopts).\n

It works well on\nhome router/firewalls where the machine can be switched off every\nnight and powered back up in the morning, and can be configured to not\nshut down until all other computers on the network fail to respond to\npings.\n

3764	autonicedaemon	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/autonicedaemon	http://and.sourceforge.net/	Automatically renices jobs	The auto nice daemon (AND) periodically activates\nitself and renices jobs according to priority and CPU usage. Jobs\nowned by root are left alone. Jobs are never increased in their\npriority.\n\n<P>The renice intervals, the default nice level, and the activation\nintervals can all be adjusted. A priority database stores\nuser/group/job tuples along with their renice values for three CPU\nusage time ranges. Negative nice levels are interpreted as signals to\nbe sent to a process, triggered by CPU usage; in this way, browser\nsessions running amok can be killed automatically. The strategy for\nsearching the priority database can be configured. \n

It\naims to discover the 'natural' classes in the data. \n\nAutoClass is applicable to observations of things that can be\ndescribed by a set of attributes, without referring to other\nthings. 3789	atop	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/atop		System- and process-level monitor	Atop is an ASCII full-screen performance monitor\nsimilar to the 'top' command. For a given interval, it shows\nsystem-level activity related to the CPU, memory, swap, disks and\nnetwork layers, and for every active process it shows the CPU\nutilization in system and user mode, the virtual and resident memory\ngrowth, priority, username, state, and exit code. It also shows\nprocess level activity for processes which finished during the last\ninterval.\n\nAtop shows only the active system-resources and processes, and only\nthe deviations since the previous interval. Unfortunately, the\nstandard kernel does not maintain counters about the number of disk\nand network accesses issued per process. Kernel patches will be made\navailable to add these counters; the current version of atop can\nalready display them.

3809	ascii2binary	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ascii2binary	http://billposer.org/Software/a2b.html	Tools for converting numbers between binary and text.	The Ascii2Binary project consists of two complementary programs that convert between textual and binary representations of numbers. Ascii2Binary reads input consisting of textual representations of numbers separated by whitespace and produces as output the binary equivalents. It is useful for generating test data and linking programs that generate textual output to programs that require binary input. Binary2Ascii converts binary numbers to text. In both programs, the type and size/precision of the input or output is selected using command line flags.

3814	arpalert	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/arpalert	http://www.arpalert.org	Uses ARP address monitoring to help prevent unauthorized connections	'arpalert' listens on a network interface, catches\nall conversations of MAC address to IP request, and compares the MAc\naddresses it detected with a pre-configured list of authorized\naddresses. It represents an\nintermediate layer between mail user agent (MUA) and mail transport agent (MTA),\nreceiving messages from the MUA, applying to them a set of predefined changes and\nfinally inserting modified messages into an MTA routing network. The set of\nchanges applied to a message is configurable on a system-wide and per-user\nbasis. The built-in configuration language used for defining sets of changes allows\nfor considerable flexibility and is easily extensible.\n\nGNU Anubis can edit outgoing mail headers, encrypt and/or sign mail\nwith the GNU Privacy Guard, build secure SMTP tunnels (Simple Mail\nTransport Protocol) using the TLS/SSL encryption even if your mail\nuser agent doesn't support it, or tunnel a connection through a SOCKS\nproxy server.\n	Intermediate

It can\nscan an arbitrarily complex RFC822 or MIME message and remove or\nrename attachments, truncate unusually long MIME header fields and\nsanitize HTML by disabling Javascript, etc. It uses a single-pass pure\nPerl MIME parser, which is more efficient and precise than similar\nprograms. It also has built-in support for third-party virus scanners.\n\n<P>The sanitizer realizes that just because a message contains an\ninfected attachment doesn't mean that the rest of it shouldn't be\ndelivered. Anomy tries to interrupt the normal flow of communication\nas little as possible, and inform the user of any changes that are\nmade.\n

3857	and-httpd	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/and-httpd	http://www.and.org/and-httpd	And-httpd is an HTTP server that maps URLs to files. It currently has a $2000 &quot;security guarant	And-httpd is an HTTP server that maps URLs to files. In other words, in can take an incoming URL and map it to a file in a number of ways (for example, according to content type or language). It can also do authentication or IP based ACLs. It cannot do CGI or other kinds of code execution. It cannot even dynamically create directory listings (although it comes with external tools to do so automatically, and to create a "status page"). It currently has a $2000 "security guarantee" against remote attacks.

Unlike most\nPerl or shell script tools, it does not spawn processes or use much\nCPU time, and is ideal for when one wants continuous monitoring and\nfast response upon target failure. It supports both IPv4 and IPv6.\n\nAlarm Pinger is configurable via $sysconfdir/apinger.conf file. The\nconfiguration file contains definitions for alarms, targets and\nvarious parameters. With Affero, those\nwho receive support from Internet forums or mailing lists, or private\ndiscussions can now say "thanks" quickly and easily through ratings,\ncomments and donations to the causes selected by the person who helped\nthem.\n\n<P>Affero combines a peer based reputation system with a commerce\nsystem. 3936	abscan	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/abscan	http://www.thinknew.ca/analytics/	Automated Baseflow Separation for Canadian datasets (ABScan) is a Hydrograph Analysis tool that auto	Automated Baseflow Separation for Canadian datasets (ABScan) is a Hydrograph Analysis tool that automatically filters streamflow data into runoff and baseflow components. The model is designed to be used with Environment Canada's free HYDAT database which is updated regularly and contains daily, monthly, and instantaneous data for streamflow, water level, and sediment data for over 2500 active and 5500 discontinued hydrometric monitoring stations across Canada. \nThe software offers several filtering algorithms (Lyne and Hollick, Chapman, Eckhardt) and output options (CSV, Excel) for up to 50 years of data at a time. It is suitable for use with any distributed runoff models, and can easily be adapted for use in non-Canadian datasets.\n

3943	abclock	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/abclock	http://odur.let.rug.nl/~kleiweg/abclock/	Analog bitmap clock	'abclock' gives a spatial representation of\ntime. It isn't tied to the design of a mechanical clock, but instead\nuses the natural properties of bitmaps: straight lines and\nrectangles. The clock uses ordinary hours and minutes. Placement and\nmovement of objects is analogous to mechanical clocks. Time has a\nsymmetrical property that is reflected in the way time changes in this\nclock.  It is clear and exact up to parts of minutes, even when the\nbitmap is very small.\n

This\n    generates an absolute pathname with all symlinks resolved and all\n    '.' and '..' characters removed. Many commands do not work well\n    with relative paths or paths containing symlinks. Realpath\n    resolves these absolute paths. \n\n    Filebase- returns the base portion of a filename, that is the\n    filename with its extension (e.g. .txt) removed. It returns\n    everything preceeding the last period in the input string. The\n    period itself is not returned.\n\n    Fileext- returns the extension portion of a filename\n    (e.g. txt). It returns everything following the last period in the\n    input string. The period itself is not returned.\n</pre>\n

Each game is played on a\nset of tracks on which trains run at regular\nintervals. You pick a train and accelerate, brake,\nor stop as necessary to safely guide it to its\ndestination. Since trains are continously being\nlaunched, more than 1 train will want to use the\nsame section of a track, potentially leading to a\ncollision. You must resolve this by making a train\nwait while you rush another train. As a last\nresort, you can send a train back to its base.\n

3959	ZoneMinder	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ZoneMinder	http://www.zoneminder.com/	Applications for video capture, analysis, recording, and monitoring	ZoneMinder is a set of applications which support\ncapture, analysis, recording, and monitoring of video data coming from\ncameras attached to a GNU/Linux system. The image analysis\nsystem is highly configurable: users can retain specific events while\neliminating false positives. \n\nZoneMinder defines a set of individual 'zones' of varying\nsensitivity and functionality for each camera. 3961	Zinc	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Zinc	http://www.tkzinc.org	Tk graphical widget	Zinc is a Tk widget developed with Perl/Tk, Tcl/Tk\nand Python/Tk bindings. Zinc widgets are similar to Tk canvases in\nthat they support structured graphics. Graphical items can be\nmanipulated, and bindings can be associated with them to implement\ninteraction behaviors. But unlike the canvas, zinc can structure the\nitems in a hierarchy, and supports affine 2D transforms.\n\n<P>Clipping can be set for sub-trees of the item hierarchy and the\nitem set is quite more powerful, including field-specific items for\nAir Traffic systems. Zinc is fast enough to allow the implementation\nof 2k2k radar displays with smooth animations, yet structured enough\nto allow the implementation of direct manipulation desktop GUIs.\n
