3966	Z	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Z	http://www.cs.indiana.edu/~kinzler/z/	Frontend for compression utilities	'Z' is a simple frontend for the gzip, bzip, tar,\ncompress/uncompress, and zip/unzip utilities for compressing and\nuncompressing files and directories. The new compressed or\nuncompressed version will be in the same directory as the original.\n\n<P>It processes its arguments according to the type of the file or\ndirectory given: If the argument is a plain file, then the file is\ncompressed; if the argument is a compressed file with a name ending in\n.Z, .gz, .z, .bz2 or .zip, then the file is uncompressed; if the\nargument is a directory, the directory is archived into one file which\nis then compressed; if the argument is a compressed tar or zip archive\nwith a name ending in .{tar.,tar,ta,t}{Z,gz,z,bz2} or .zip, then the\narchive is uncompressed and untarred.\n

4007	WormWarner	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/WormWarner	http://www.jeroen.se/warner.php	Warns hosts that are probably infected by a worm	WormWarner is a scripts that warns hosts that are\nprobably infected by a worm. It currently recognizes\nCodeRed, Nimda, the Linux.Slapper.Worm, and the FreeBSD.Scalper.worm.\nWarning is done by trying to contact the SMTP server on the infected\nhost and sending an email to the postmaster. 4008	WormScan	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/WormScan	http://www.websoup.net/wormscan/	Reports attempted attacks on Apache Web servers	WormScan reports attempted attacks on your Apache\nWeb server. It was written to be able to support an unlimited number\nof worms. It is, however, very extendable, and can be configured to\nsearch and report on just about anything in your Web server's log\nfiles. The program currently supports the Common Log Format (the\ndefault Apache format) and has out of the box detection for Code Red,\nCode Red II, and Nimda worm attacks.\n\nThe reports themselves can be modified to suit your needs, and are\ngenerated in HTML so you don't need additional software to read\nthem. They can be sorted by date, host, hostname, worm, and number of\nattacks, and optionally compressed with gzip. Numerous configuration\noptions let you tweak performance and output.	
4009	WormReport	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/WormReport	http://sourceforge.net/projects/wormreport/	Filters out worm hits	Worm Report is a script that filters out known\nworm hits from the access log, and puts them into their own files\nnamed for the IP/Host that has been "wormed". A report containing the\ncount, hostname, ip, and a guess at the parent domain is printed to\nSTDOUT to facilitate contacting these individuals.\n\n<P>This script is useful in the short term to get the info to the people\nwho need it. Adding a new worm requires adding a new worm hit string\nto the DATA section of the script, nothing so fancy (or exhaustive) as\nan Apache module.\n

4015	Windows32API	2010-05-03 16:09:25	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Windows32API		Header files and libraries for GNU tools	It is a set of header files and import libraries\nthat can be used by GNU tools for compiling and linking programs to be\nrun under operating systems supporting the Windows32 Application\nProgramming Interface.  \n\nHeader files are created by the library's executables based upon a set\nof native Windows32 headers; the creation process follows these general\nsteps:\n\n\t* Install Windows32 API Library on an operating system with\n\tnative Windows32 header files.\n\n\t* Compile the Windows32 API Library executables with the native\n\tWindows32 header files.\n\n\t* Execute the Windows32 API Library executables to generate the\n\tset of freely distributable header files.\n\nThe header files allow source code using the Windows32 API Library to\nbe compiled into object code, but import libraries are required to\nlink with the object code and create executable programs.  Import\nlibraries do not contain the actual code for Windows32 functions, instead\nthey contain function exports which cause the executable to load a DLL\nduring runtime.  A DLL (Dynamic Link Library) contains the executable\ncode for the Windows32 API functions, and the DLL is really a part of the\noperating system and not this library.\n\n<P>This package is no longer under active development.\n

4092	TraceProto	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/TraceProto	http://traceproto.sourceforge.net/index.php	Traceroute replacement	'Traceproto' is a traceroute replacement (the\noriginal traceroute was written before most firewalls and transparent\nredirection and often fails when tracing today's networks). that lets\nusers specify the protocol and port to trace to. It currently supports\nTCP, UDP, and ICMP traces.\n\n<P>'TraceProto' sends packets with a modified time-to-live (ttl)\nfield. As the packets move toward the destination, each hop decrements\nthe time-to-live. If the ttl reaches 0 before the packet reaches its\ndestination (in normal network traffic it is unusual for the ttl to\nreach 0 before the packet reaches it destination), the hop that did\nthe final decrement sends back an icmp packet informing the source\nthat the packet expired before reaching its destination. TraceProto\nuses a series of packets with smaller ttl values, so that each hop\nbetween the source and the destination responds.\n	
4093	Totd	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Totd	http://www.i-i.no/~totd/index.html		Totd is a small DNS proxy nameserver that supports\nIPv6-only hosts/networks that communicate with the IPv4 world using\nsome translation mechanism, which often uses fake or fabricated\naddresses that don't exist in DNS. The program fixes this problem by\ntranslating DNS queries and responses for the faked addresses,\nconstructing fake addresses based on a configured IPv6 translator\nprefix and the records it finds in DNS.\n

It's best suited to smaller sites with\nfewer than 250 images. \n\n<P>For users, a search is similar to using Google: a preceding minus\ncharacter excludes a word, and the OR and NOT operators are supported,\nas are phrases within double-quotes. Returned images are ranked\naccording to how often the search words occur and where. You can also\nweight an image so that it scores higher.\n

Your existing tools generate\nan input file that exactly describes the layout of a printed document,\nand Tiny RML2PDF converts it into PDF. It is intended as an\nalternative to XSL:FO.\n

Tests have shown it to be 6 times faster than id3lib\nand 3 times faster than libvorbisfile at reading tags (CPU time). It\nsupports Unicode.\n\n<P>TagLib offers an abstraction layer that makes it easy to ignore the\ndifferences between the different file formats and their\nimplementations. 4133	TMDA	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/TMDA	http://tmda.net/	SPAM reduction system and local mail delivery agent	The Tagged Message Delivery Agent (TMDA) thwarts\nincoming junk-mail by maintaining a "whitelist" of trusted contacts\nwho are allowed directly into your mailbox. It holds messages from\nunknown senders in a pending queue until they respond to a\nconfirmation request sent by TMDA. \n\nOnce they respond to the confirmation, their original message is\ndeemed legitimate and is delivered to you. Updating your whitelist\ninsures they won't have to confirm future messages. TMDA can even be\nconfigured to automatically whitelist confirmed senders. This method\nis very selective about what it allows in while still letting\nlegitimate, but previously unknown, senders reach you.

4144	SweepOver	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/SweepOver	http://www.maths.ox.ac.uk/~challet/sweepover/sweepover.html		'SweepOver' makes the exploration of a model by\nnumerical simulations easier and faster. For example, take a system\nthat has 4 parameters A,B,C,D and that produces a figure of some\nquantity against A. In code, this corresponds to a loop. If you need\nto see what happens when B is varied, and you modify the loop\nslightly. However, doing this repeatedly becomes tedious very\nquickly. 'SweepOver' gives you a black box, that is, an executable\ncalled PROG that simulates a system for a given set of parameters and\nprints out the relevant quantities. Then SweepOver sweeps over any\nparameter magically.\n

It\nincludes command line interfaces for "tar", "Sun-Tar", "cpio", "pax",\nand "gnutar". \n\n<P>It includes a FIFO for speed, a pattern matcher, multi-volume\nsupport, the ability to archive sparse files and ACLs, the ability to\narchive extended file flags, automatic archive format detection,\nautomatic byte order recognition, automatic archive\ncompression/decompression, remote archives, and special features that\nlet it be used for full and incremental backups. 4162	SpamProbe	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/SpamProbe	http://spamprobe.sourceforge.net/	Uses a Bayesian analysis of the frequencies of terms used in email to block spam	'SpamProbe' is a spam detection program that uses\na Bayesian analysis of how frequently certain terms are used in\nemail. 4163	SpamFilters	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/SpamFilters	http://www.visi.com/~hawkeyd/spamfilters.html	Rulesets that expand on sendmail&#39;s anti-spam facilities	'SpamFilters' is a collection of rulesets that\nexpand on sendmail's anti-spam facilities. These rulesets inspect the\n"To", "From", "Reply-To", "Received", "Subject", and SpamAssassin's\n"X-Spam-Status" email headers, and reject email based on their\ncontents. It integrates into sendmail by way of the sendmail m4 build\nhierarchy, but can be added directly to sendmail's configuration file\nif needed.\n	
4164	SpamAssassin	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/SpamAssassin	http://spamassassin.org/	Tests mail headers and body texts to detect spam	SpamAssassin is a mail filter that uses heuristic\ntests on mail headers and body text to identify spam. Mail can then be\noptionally tagged as spam for later filtering using the user's own\nmail user-agent application. \n\nThe program has a command line tool to perform filtering, as well as\nMail::SpamAssassin, a set of Perl modules which implement a\nMail::Audit plugin; this lets SpamAssassin be used in a Mail::Audit\nfilter or in a spam-protection proxy POP/IMAP server.	
4165	Spam-X	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Spam-X	http://www.lindstromconsulting.com/software/spam-x.html	Anti-Spam application	Spam-X is a small anti-spam program that seeks to\nblock +email harvesting spambots and flood them with hundreds or even\nthousands of worthless e-mail addresses. It "hides" these junk\nmailto: links in the body of a normal-appearing HTML page, which it\ngenerates using words from a dictionary of over 45,000 English\nwords. It generates each page of junk mailto: links very slowly,\nthereby wasting the spambot's time. Last but not least, it includes a\n"loop back" link to itself, with a random parameter, hoping to fool\nthe spambot in to endlessly looping and thereby getting "stuck" on the\nSpam-X link and blocking it from ever reaching your real email\naddress.\n

4169	Socketpipe	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Socketpipe	http://www.spinellis.gr/sw/unix/socketpipe/	Connects the input/output of a remote process with local programs	'Socketpipe' directly connects the input/output of a\nremote process with local programs over a TCP/IP socket. Although the\ninitial communication setup is performed through client-server\nintermediaries such as SSH or RSH, the communication channel that\nsocketpipe establishes is a direct socket connection between the local\nand the remote processes, similar to a local pipe. The use of\nsocketpipe removes the inefficiency of multiple data copies and\ncontext switches through RSH/SSH, and can in many cases offer dramatic\nthroughput improvements.\n

4176	SmokePing	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/SmokePing	http://oss.oetiker.ch/smokeping/	Monitors and graphs network latency	SmokePing measures network latency to a\nconfigurable set of destinations on the network, and displays its\nfindings in Web pages. It consists of a daemon process responsible for\ndata collection and a CGI script presenting the data on the\nweb. SmokePing can also watch out loss/latency patterns and send out\nalerts when it finds a match. This allows for sophisticated monitoring\napplications.\n\nIt deals with machines who frequently change their IP address by\nallowing the remote host to call SmokePing's attention to its new IP\naddress. SmokePing also monitors how long the remote system could keep\nits IP address, and tries to fingerprint each Dynamic IP targets via\nSNMP too ensure that it is not suddenly monitoring the wrong host.

4187	Sglib	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Sglib	http://www.xref-tech.com/sglib	C library inspired by the Standard Template Library from C++	'Sglib' is a generic library for C that was\ninspired by the Standard Template Library from C++. It has a single\nheader file and no binary code. It defines macros for sorting arrays\nand manipulating lists, sorted lists, double linked lists, hashed\ncontainers, and red-black trees. Macros are parametrized by the type\nof the data structure. \n\n<P>The library does not enforce its own data representation, but acts\non user-defined types. Nor does it enforce any particular memory\nmanagement system.\n

4207	SableCC	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/SableCC	http://sablecc.org	Generates compilers and interpreters in Java	'SableCC' is an object-oriented framework that\ngenerates compilers and interpreters in Java. It is based on two\ndesign decisions. First, the framework uses object-oriented techniques\nto automatically build a strictly typed abstract syntax tree. Second,\nthe framework generates tree-walker classes using an extended version\nof the visitor design pattern which enables the implementation of\nactions on the nodes of the abstract syntax tree using inheritance.\nThis means a shorter development cycle for constructing compilers.\n

4214	SQLite	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/SQLite	http://www.sqlite.org/	C library that implements an embeddable SQL database engine	SQLite is a C library that implements an SQL\ndatabase engine. A large subset of SQL92 is supported. A complete\ndatabase is stored in a single disk file. The package has a small\nmemory footprint (less than 25K lines of C code). Its C/C++ interface\nis extremely simple, requiring only three functions and one opaque\nstructure.\n\nApplications can take advantage of the power and flexiblity of an SQL\ndatabase without the administrative hassles of supporting a separate\ndatabase server. By omitting the client-server interaction overhead\nand writing directly to disk, SQLite is faster than the big database\nservers for most operations. The distribution also includes a\ncommand-line tool for interacting with SQLite databases and SQLite\nbindings for Tcl/Tk.

4218	SQLDiff	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/SQLDiff	http://phpsqldiff.sourceforge.net/	Shows the difference between two SQL database tables	'SQLDiff' is a Web application that shows the\ndifference between two SQL database tables. The user provides two\ntables, a master table -- a table that has not changed and a modified\ntable -- which has changed (compared to the master). SQLDiff\ndetermines what has changed and displays it as sets of additions to\nthe master, deletions from the master and columns which have changed\nin the modified table.\n\n<P>If the two tables do not match, SQLDiff shows what columns they\nhave in common; users can choose to do a diff on just those (even when\nthe two tables are identical in format, it's useful to restrict the\ncolumns compared and show fewer changes).\n

4227	SNORT	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/SNORT	http://www.snort.org/	Network intrusion detection system	Snort is a network intrusion detection\nsystem that performs real-time traffic analysis and packet\nlogging on IP networks. It can perform protocol analysis, content\nsearching/matching and can be used to detect a variety of attacks and\nprobes, such as buffer overflows, stealth port scans, CGI attacks, SMB\nprobes, OS fingerprinting attempts, and more.  \n\nSnort has three primary uses: as a straight packet sniffer like\ntcpdump(1), as a packet logger (useful for network traffic debugging,\netc), or as a full blown network intrusion detection system.  Snort\nlogs packets in either tcpdump(1) binary format or in Snort's decoded\nASCII format to logging directories that are named based on the IP\naddress of the "foreign" host. It should work any place libpcap does.\n\n<p>Snort uses a flexible rules language to describe traffic that it\nshould collect or pass, as well as a detection engine that utilizes a\nmodular plugin architecture. It also has real-time alerting\ncapabilities.\n

4243	SGK	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/SGK	http://www.zoomforge.com/index.php?id=sgk	One-way encryption algorithm	SGK (Self-Generating Key) Encryption is an\ninnovative one-way encryption algorithm. It is similar to other\none-way encryption algorithms (known as digital signature algorithms)\nin that it cannot be or is difficult to decrypt, but differs from\nother such algorithms due to the method it uses.\n\n<P>SGK encrypts itself by using itself as the encryption key. SGK does\nnot require a key. SGK uses the original data as the\nkey. Theoretically, your data cannot be retrieved or decrypted without\nthe original copy. SGK is a prototype algorithm that demonstrates the\nconcept of "self-generating keys." Its primary objective is to pave\nthe road for more complex algorithms based on SGK.\n

4296	RSBAC	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/RSBAC	http://www.rsbac.org/	Security extension for the Linux kernel	Rule Set Based Access Control (RSBAC) is a\nsecurity extension for current Linux kernels. It is based on the\nGeneralized Framework for Access Control (GFAC) by Abrams and LaPadula\nand provides a flexible system of access control based on several\nmodules. All security relevant system calls are extended by security\nenforcement code. This code calls the central decision component,\nwhich then calls all active decision modules and generates a combined\ndecision. This decision is then enforced by the system call extensions.\n

'RRDPoller' is meant to form the interface between\nan existing monitoring system like and a set of RRD graphs generated\nby specialized data collectors such. Thus, you can build a very\nmodular monitoring/trend architecture without needing double polling.\n

It lets you include program\ndocumentation in the source code and avoid having to maintain two\nseparate documents. \n\n<P>ROBODoc formats the documentation in HTML, LaTeX, RTF, XML DocBook,\nor ASCII format. It can even include parts of the source code. It\nworks with Assembler, C, C++, Java, Perl, LISP, Occam, Tcl/Tk, Pascal,\nFortran, shell scripts, HTML, and COBOL; or basically any language that\nsupports comments.\n	
4300	RLog	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/RLog	http://pobox.com/~vgough/rlog	Message logging facility for C++	'RLog' is a flexible message logging facility for\nC++ programs and libraries. It is subscription based, meaning you can\nsubscribe to messages of your choice in various ways: by hierarchical\nchannel name (e.g. "debug", "debug/ special", "error", etc.), or\nfilename, component name, etc. Log messages are individually enabled.\n\n<P>It is meant to be fast enough for production code where it may be\ncalled many times, as both the GCC and Intel compilers reduce the\nlogging overhead a few clock cycles if they are dormant (with no\nsubscribers). Other add-on components extend subscriptions to external\nprograms, so you can enable and collect debugging messages remotely.\n	
4301	RKCheck	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/RKCheck	http://www.spaceroots.org/software/rkcheck/index.html	Checks the order of Runge-Kutta methods	'RKCheck' checks the order of a Runge-Kutta\nmethod. The method is specified in an xml file. All computations are\nexact; there is no approximation at all. Because of this, the\napplication can handle only methods for which an exact representation\nof the coefficients exist. 'RKCheck' currently supports integers,\nrational numbers and quadratic surds (i.e. numbers of the form (p1 +\np2 sqrt(d)) / q), and only if all quadratic surds in one file share\nthe same d.\n

4303	REJIK	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/REJIK	http://www.rejik.ru/index_en.html	Web filtering system	'REJIK' is a Web filtering system consisting of a\nSquid redirector and ban lists. Squid lets users put a redirector (a\nprogramme the filters the client's queries) in its configuration.\nEvery time someone downloads a file through your proxy-server, the\nquery data is sent to the redirector, which analyses the data. If\ncertain conditions are fulfilled, it changes the answer it sends.  As\na result the user gets an mp3 from the local web-server instead of the\nfile he wanted from the Internet (for example, a sysadmin can change\npictures from the porno sites into a photo of his grinning face :).\n

4313	QtUnit	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/QtUnit	http://www.uwyn.com/projects/qtunit/	Testing framework for C++	QtUnit is a unit testing framework for C++ which\ncompiles into a shared library. Tests can be compiled into modules\nwhich are automatically reloaded after modification. The text and\ngraphical testrunners are fully localized and integrate perfectly into\nIDEs to show exactly where a failure has happened.\n\n<P>The program consists of the testing framework, the test runner\nframework, and the GUI runner framework. Test cases can be grouped\ninto test suites, which then can be compiled into independent modules\nstored in shared libraries (.so, .dll, ...). This minimizes the number\nof files that must be recompiled when the sources for the test\ndefinitions change.\n\n<P>Projects can be defined in XML files (visually in the gui test\nrunner) to group an arbitrary number of modules together. The entire\nframework compiles into a shared library that creates the actual\nimplementations.\n

4324	Q	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Q	http://q-lang.sourceforge.net/	Equational programming language	Q (which stands for 'equational') is a functional\nprogramming language based on the term rewriting calculus. You specify\na system of equations which the interpreter uses as rewrite rules to\nreduce expressions to normal form. Q lets you formulate programs in a\nhigh-level, declarative style. It is useful for scientific programming\nand other advanced applications, and also as a sophisticated kind of\ndesktop calculator. \n\nFeatures include advanced symbolic expression manipulation, a fast\nbytecode interpreter, a collection of built-in types, support for lazy\nevaluation, exception handling, and multithreading, a libtool-based C\ninterface, a standard library with various list processing functions,\nand add-on modules for interfacing with other programs.

4327	PythonMilter	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/PythonMilter	http://www.bmsi.com/python/milter.html	Python interface to sendmail&#39;s libmilter	PythonMilter provides a Python interface to\nSendmail's libmilter. Milters can run on the same machine as sendmail,\na different one, or even run with a different operating system or\nprocessor than sendmail. \n\n<P>Sendmail talks to the milter via a local or internet socket, and\nkeeps the milter informed of events as it processes a mail\nconnection. At any point, the milter can cut the conversation short by\ntelling sendmail to ACCEPT, REJECT, or DISCARD the message. After\nreceiving a complete message from sendmail, the milter can again\nREJECT or DISCARD it, but it can also ACCEPT it with changes to the\nheaders or body.\n

4330	Python-SIP	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Python-SIP		Generates Python bindings for C and C++ libaries	'SIP' creates Python bindings for C and C++\nlibraries. It was originally developed to create PyQt, the Python\nbindings for the Qt toolkit, but can be used to create bindings for\nany C or C++ library. SIP makes it easy to exploit existing C or C++\nlibraries in a productive interpretive programming environment and to\ntake a Python application and selectively implement parts of it.\n\n<P>SIP consists of a code generator and a Python module. The code\ngenerator processes a set of specification files and generates C or\nC++ code which is then compiled to create the bindings extension\nmodule. The Python module provides support functions to the\nautomatically generated code.\n

Common\nerrors that can be found include forgetting to import a module,\nmisspelling a variable, passing the wrong number of parameters to a\nfunction/method, and not using a module/variable.\n

Resuming connections is fully\nsupported and customizable. \n\nThe new FTPSearch feature enables retrieving of mirrors, and also\npings them to select the fastest server available. 4362	ProGuard	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ProGuard	http://proguard.sourceforge.net/	Java class file shrinker and obfuscator	ProGuard is a Java class file shrinker and\nobfuscator. It detects and removes unused classes, fields, methods,\nand attributes, then renames the remaining classes, fields, and\nmethods using short, meaningless names. The resulting jars are smaller\nand harder to reverse-engineer. Advantages of ProGuard compared to\nother Java shrinkers and obfuscators are compact template-based\nconfiguration, memory efficiency, and speed.\n

4365	PreprocessorSuite	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/PreprocessorSuite	http://www.mbstevens.com/preprocessor/	Preprocessor for websites	The Preprocessor Suite consists of two programs,\nmcat.pl and mflt.pl. 'mcat.pl' joins files together by reading a file\nthat describes how you want your site constructed. Each line of that\nfile tells mcat.pl how to join several files into a final file. On\neach line you simply list the files you want to concatenate, in order,\nfollowed by the name of the final preprocessed file. A Perl module of\nthis script (File::MultiCat) is available at CPAN which lets you add\nthe functionality of this script to your Perl programs with three\nlines of code.\n\n<P>'mflt.pl' performs filter and replace functions by reading '.mflt'\nfiles looking for special commands. It obeys those commands when it\nwrites an '.html' file based on the '.mflt' file. This lets you\ninclude files, datestamp pages, and do various other functions. The\nmflt.pl script searches an entire directory tree for '.mflt' files.\n

4369	PowerPhlogger	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/PowerPhlogger	http://pphlogger.phpee.com/	Counter hosting tool	PowerPhlogger is a counter hosting tool. 4370	PowerMail	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/PowerMail	http://www.powerdns.com/powermail/	Email management package for large systems	PowerMail is a redundant and distributed system\nfor receiving,storing, and forwarding email. It is particularly well\nsuited for installations that handle an extremely large amount of\nmailboxes and/or forwards. PowerMail uses a central database to store\nall information about mailboxes and email forwards that you\nhost. Mailboxes do not need system accounts.\n\nThere is no central storage point of failure. Mailboxes can span\nmultiple machines or disks and individual messages can be present\nredundantly - on more storage nodes than one. This means that even if\npart of the storage subsystem fails, there is no downtime or loss of\nmail. Mail is delivered straight into mailboxes; there is no\nintermediate copying, which greatly improves incoming performance\n(typically the bottleneck for large scale email systems). A side\nbenefit is that messages with many recipients are delivered only\nonce. Identical copies are stored as 'hard links'.

4412	PTunnel	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/PTunnel	http://www.cs.uit.no/~daniels/PingTunnel/index.html	Tunnels TCP connections over ping requests and replies	'PTunnel' reliably tunnels TCP connections over\nICMP echo request and reply packets (aka ping requests and\nreplies). The tunnel works by having a\nproxy run on a machine ping-able from the inside of the firewall; the\nclient runs on the local machine from which TCP access is required.\n

4415	PPL	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/PPL	http://www.cs.unipr.it/ppl/	C++ library for the manipulation of convex polyhedra	The <EM>Parma Polyhedra Library</EM> (PPL)\nis a modern and reasonably complete library providing numerical\nabstractions especially targeted at applications in the field\nof analysis and verification of complex systems.\nThe PPL can handle all the convex polyhedra that can be defined as the\nintersection of a finite number of (open or closed) hyperspaces, each\ndescribed by an equality or inequality (strict or non-strict) with\nrational coefficients. The PPL also handles restricted classes of\npolyhedra that offer interesting complexity/precision tradeoffs. The\nlibrary also supports finite powersets of (any kind of) polyhedra and\nlinear programming problems solved with an exact-arithmetic version of\nthe simplex algorithm.\n\nThe Parma Polyhedra Library is user friendly (you write <code>x + 2 * y\n+ 5 * z &lt;= 7</code> when you mean it), fully dynamic (available virtual\nmemory is the only limitation to the dimension of anything), portable,\nexception-safe, rather efficient, thoroughly documented, and free\nsoftware. It comes with complete interfaces for C++, C, Java, Objective CAML\nand Prolog.

4418	POPauthd	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/POPauthd	http://chrome.primelogic.com/popauthd/	Authorizes connecting hosts for SMTP relaying	POPauthd is a Perl-based daemon that uses POP to\nauthorize connecting hosts for SMTP relaying. It is particularly\nuseful to authenticate roaming users with IP addresses that change\noften. \n\nThe daemon runs in the background, watching the syslog for\nsuccessful POP logins. When it sees one, it enters the IP in sendmail's\naccess database, giving the host authorization to relay through the\nserver. The entries can be expired after a prescribed, configurable\nperiod of time with a companion script run via crontab.\n\n<p>'POPauthd' is designed to run on a FreeBSD server, but should work\nproperly on any UNIX system. It will work with any POP3 daemon that's\ncapable of writing successful POP logins to a log file.\n

It encodes your PHP scripts and applications into\nnon-reversible bytecode, so users of your programs can't see or change\nthe source code, but still have full functionality. It encodes your\napplication's PHP configuration files so someone viewing your source\ncode sees neither your database login not password information.\n\n<P>You can also set restrictions on the encoded scripts, lock a script\nto a particular server IP address, server host name, visitor IP, or\nplace a time limit on the script so it will expire after a set amount\nof time. You specify Text, HTML, or PHP code that should be prepended\nand appended to each file before it is encoded, so you can easily and\nsecurely implement your own licensing scheme.\n

4446	PGMT	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/PGMT	http://w3.uqo.ca/pgmt/	Project to design and build software tools for parallel processors	'PGMT' is a project to design and build software\ntools that allow PGM (Processing Graph Method) to be affordably and\nefficiently used on a wide range of parallel processors so that\napplications, once built, for a parallel processor could be reused\nwith little cost. This will make it easy to translate an engineer's\ndesign of a weapon system into software for the weapon system's\ncomputers. By design, this approach is specifically applicable to\nparallel distributed - computer processing.\n\n<P>PGMT provides: \n<pre>\n\t-Earlier, less costly development of new parallel processor software; \n \t-Faster modernization of parallel-processor software\n\t-Lower costs for modernizing and maintaining software\n\t-More uniform capabilities across parallel-processor architectures\n\t with more compatible software for various hardware configurations\n</pre>\n

It is limited to 3000\nlines of 79 characters; it cuts longer lines at char 79 and inserts\nthe remaining part on the next line while automatically inserting a\n'\\' at the end of the line.\n	Intermediate

4468	OpenEXR	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/OpenEXR	http://www.openexr.com/	High dynamic-range (HDR) image file format	OpenEXR is a high dynamic-range (HDR) image file\nformat developed by Industrial Light & Magic. It is used on all motion\npictures currently in production, and is now ILM's main image file\nformat. The package includes the following libraries and tools:\nIlmImf, Half, Imath, exrdisplay, exrdisplay, exrheader, exrstdattr,\nexrmaketiled, exrenvmap, and exrmakepreview.\n\n<P>OpenEXR's has a higher dynamic range and color precision than\nexisting 8- and 10-bit image file formats. It\nincludes multiple lossless image compression algorithms, some of which\ncan achieve 2:1 lossless compression ratios on images with film grain.\nNew compression codecs and image types can be added by extending its\nC++ classes. New image attributes can be added to OpenEXR image\nheaders without affecting backward compatibility.\n

4480	OSKit	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/OSKit	http://www.cs.utah.edu/flux/oskit/	Tools for operating system development	The OSKit is a framework and a set of 34 component\nlibraries oriented to operating systems. It provides in a modular way\nmost of the infrastructure "grunge" needed by an OS, as well as many\nhigher-level components. Its goal is to lower both the barrier to\nentry, and the cost, of OS R&D.\n\n<P>The OSKit makes it easier to create a new OS, port an existing OS\nto architectures supported by the OSkit), or enhance an OS to support\na wider range of devices, file system formats, executable formats, or\nnetwork services. It can also build OS-related programs, such as boot\nloaders or OS-level servers atop a microkernel.\n\n<P>The OSKit lets language researchers concentrate on issues raised by\nusing advanced languages inside operating systems instead of spending\ntime on ugly code and hardware. With the addition of extensive\nmultithreading and sophisticated scheduling support, the OSKit also\nprovides a modular platform for embedded applications and a\ncomponent-based approach to constructing entire operating systems.\n

4484	OOF	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/OOF	http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/oof/index.html	Calculate macroscopic properties from images of microstructures	'OOF' helps materials scientists calculate\nmacroscopic properties from images of real or simulated\nmicrostructures. It consists of two cooperating parts: 'ppm2oof' and\n'oof'. 'ppm2oof' reads images in the ppm (Portable Pixel Map) format\nand assigns material properties to features in the image. 'oof'\nconducts virtual experiments on the data structures created by ppm2oof\nto determine the macroscopic properties of the\nmicrostructure. \n\n<P>There are now two separate versions of OOF available. The original\nversion solves elasticity problems. The new thermal version solves\nelasticity and thermal diffusion problems. Plans are to include\neventually include electric and magnetic field calculations as well.\n	
4485	OGLFT	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/OGLFT	http://oglft.sourceforge.net/	Renders text in OpenGL programs	The OpenGL/FreeType2 Text Rendering Library\n(OGLFT) supplies an interface between a font and an OpenGL or Mesa\napplication.It uses the FreeType library to read font faces from their\nfiles and renders text strings as OpenGL primitives.\n\nCharacters can be rendered in a variety of ways, including as raster\nimages, as tessellated polygons and as texture maps. Glyphs can be\ndrawn individually or as a string, and can be rendered using UNICODE\ncharacters via the QString class (with Qt support). You can also\ncombine several fonts together in one OGLFT Face to increase the\ncoverage of UNICODE points or for other special effects. Strings can\nbe rotated through any angle, and drawn right, centered or left\njustified. Additionally each character in a string can be rotated\nthrough a given angle.\n

The zone\nfile handling and configuration is therefore slightly different. Two \nadditional functions (to automatically convert incoming strings (RENAME)\nand the resolution of ACE names) are introduced. RENAME essentially \nglues any multilingual requests to its corresponding ACE formatted name \nby setting a dynamic alias (CNAME) between the multilingual name to an \nalphanumeric conversion. 4526	MySQLBackup	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/MySQLBackup	http://worldcommunity.com/opensource/utilities/mysql_backup.html	Backs up databases	MySQL Backup is a Perl script that uses mysqlshow\nto grab the database names and "show tables" to grab the table names\nfor a user's account, and then uses mysqldump to save the data in a\nsubdirectory named in the script. It then tars and gzips the files,\nusing the date and time for the file name. \n\nIt can be run from cron on a daily basis. It removes old files and\nhas an option to email the gzip file to an admin and/or FTP the backup\nfile to a remote server. It also has options to use "select data into\noutfile" or a regular "select" for users who can't use mysqldump. It\nsupports LARGE sets of databases and tables (GNU/Linux utilities such as\ntar, ls and nice break when the argument list gets too long). To do\nthis, the script places all the sql text files in a subdirectory and\ntars the directory. For security, if a .my.cnf file is used then\nmysqlshow and mysqldump run without the --user and --password\nparameters, so the password doesn't display in the process list.

Because of this, MonetDB can be used\nin application areas that have in the past been too slow for using\ntraditional database technology in real-time.\n

4565	Metro	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Metro	http://vcg.sourceforge.net/tiki-index.php?page=Metro	Evaluates the difference between two triangular meshes	'Metro' evaluates the difference between two\ntriangular meshes. It adopts an approximated approach based on surface\nsampling and point-to-surface distance computation, and has been\nwidely used in the surface simplification research community (more\nthan 140 citations according to google).\n\nIt implements three different surface sampling methods:\n<pre>\n    * Montecarlo sampling (pick k random samples in the interior of each face)\n    * Subdivision sampling (recursively subdivide each face along the\n         longest edge and choose the sample in the center of each cell)\n    * Similar Triangles sampling (subdivide each face F in k polygons\n         similar to F and sample the face in correspondence with the\n      vertices of these polygons, internal to F)\n</pre>\n	
4566	Metakit	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Metakit	http://www.equi4.com/metakit.html	Embedded database library	'Metakit' fills the gap between flat-file,\nrelational, object-oriented, and tree-structured databases, supporting\nrelational joins, serialization, nested structures, and instant schema\nevolution. There is a C++ API, a Python binding (Mk4py), and a Tcl\nbinding (Mk4tcl).\n\nData files are portable, use auto-sizing ints and strings, and can\nefficiently store binary data from single bits to multi-Mb\nobjects. MetaKit works well for moderate-size (a few dozen Mb)\ndatasets, and offers excellent performance well beyond that size when\nits column-wise data model is fully taken advantage of.	
4567	Meta-CVS	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Meta-CVS	http://users.footprints.net/~kaz/mcvs.html	Version control system built around CVS	Meta-CVS is a version control system created\naround CVS. It keeps most of CVS's features, but adds support for\nfirst class directory structure versioning, storage of symbolic links,\nand versioning of execute permissions and user-defined properties.\n\nMeta-CVS greatly simplifies branching and merging by keeping track of\nwhat is merged where. It records file types and automatically assigns\na CVS keyword expansion mode to newly added files whose suffixes match\npreviously recorded types. The package also has an importing feature\nthat automatically figures out renames and moves, so it is easy to\nkeep up with patches from multiple sources despite directory structure\nchanges.	
4568	MessageWall	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/MessageWall	http://messagewall.org/	SMTP proxy	MessageWall is an SMTP proxy. It sits between the\noutside world and your mail server and keeps out viruses, spam, and\nmail relaying. It offers filtering via header and body checks,\nDNS-based blacklists for IP addresses (DNSBL) and domains (RHSBL), and\nDNS-based distributed checksumming (DNS DCC) similar to Vipul's\nRazor. Features can be filtered on a per-address basis, and since\nMessageWall communicates via SMTP, it works with any MTA. It also\noffers message tagging as a per-address configurable alternative to\nmessage blocking.\n\nMessageWall organizes filtering customizations into profiles. The\nconfiguration file defines a default profile, and a seperate file\nspecifies addresses and domains with profiles other than the\ndefault. Each profile contains a set of rules for how to filter\nmail. There are currently 14 rules available.

Many other programs like this force the user to write\ninput data using one row only (everything is typed at the same level,\nexponents and bases are on the same row) and use a lot of brackets to\nmake the operation order explicit. Since this is very different from\nthe math you do manually, the aim of this project is to reduce this\ngap providing both cross-platform libraries which can be embedded in\nother programs and a program, MathStudio, which demonstrates their\nusage.\n

These cases include storage of big numbers\n(ie factorials) and the operations associated with them, emulation of\nregisters of large length, and indications of errors in position code.\n

4606	MQS	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/MQS	http://www.foo.be/mqs/	Minimalist queueing system	MQS (Minimalist Queue Services) is a minimalist\nqueueing system that provides basic methods for offering asynchronous\nmessaging. It lets applications store and retrieve messages to a\ndedicated queue in the queue services. This avoids direct connections\nbetween applications and provides a simple asynchronous communication\nsystem.\n\n<P>The MQS Daemon provides a simple set of XML-RPC methods for pushing\nand getting messages in a given queue (you can use the system with any\napplication that can talk XML-RPC). The queue is stored in either a\ndatabase (e.g. Mysql, Postgresql) or in dedicated file(s) (e.g. QDBM).\n	
4607	MQ4CPP	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/MQ4CPP	http://www.sixtyfourbit.org/mq4cpp.htm	Message queueing for C++	MQ4CPP (Message Queuing for C++) is an\nimplementation of enterprise messaging system, aka "message-oriented\nmiddleware" (MOM). It lets C++ application threads communicate with\none another through exchanging messages. A message is a request,\nreport, and/or event that contains information needed to coordinate\ncommunication between different applications. It provides a level of\nabstraction, so you can separate the details about the destination\nsystem from the application code.\n\n<P>MQ4CCP lets C++ applications that share a messaging system exchange\nmessages, and simplifies application development by providing a\nstandard interface for creating, sending, and receiving messages. It\nimplements the following messaging paradigms: Direct/Indirect\nmessaging (local), unsolicited messaging (remote), Request/Reply\n(remote), conversation (remote), and broadcast (local/remote).\n	
4608	MPFR	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/MPFR		Multiple-precision Floating-point library with correct rounding.	Provides a library for multiple-precision floating-point computation with exact rounding.  The computation is both efficient and has a well-defined semantics.  It copies the good ideas from the ANSI/IEEE-754 standard for double-precision floating-point arithmetic.	
4609	MPFI	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/MPFI	http://perso.ens-lyon.fr/nathalie.revol/software.html	Library for arbitrary precision interval arithmetic	MPFI (Multiple Precision Floating-Point Interval\nLibrary) is a library for arbitrary precision interval arithmetic with\nintervals represented using MPFR reliable floating-point numbers. It\nis based on the GNU MP library and on the MPFR library.\n\n<P>The purpose of an arbitrary precision interval arithmetic is on the\none hand to get guaranteed results, thanks to interval computation,\nand on the other hand to obtain accurate results, thanks to multiple\nprecision arithmetic. The MPFI library is built upon MPFR to benefit\nfrom the correct roundings provided by MPFR, it portability, and its\ncompliance with the IEEE 754 standard for floating-point arithmetic.\n

4624	MC	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/MC	http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/jfan/dm/	Converts text documents into a vector space model	MC is a C++ program that creates vector-space\nmodels from text documents that can be used for text mining\napplications. MC provides an efficient multi-threaded implementation\nthat can process very large document collections.\n\n The MC program: \n\t 1. Recursively descends directories, finding text files\n         2. Processes files selectively through full regular\n\t\t     expression matching of file names.\n\t 3. Builds a sparse matrix of word/token counts. The\n\t\t     particular sprse marix format used is given here.\n\t 4. Processes any user specified text formats(email address or\n\t\t     URLs) as a whole token through regular\n\t\t     expression matching or FLEX definition.\n\t 5. Prunes vocabulary by word length and frequency\n\t 6. Excludes user specified stop words\n\t 7. Sets word vector weights according any of the txx, txn,\n\t\t      tfn, tfx, lxx, lxn, lfn, lfx scaling schemes.\n\t 8. Writes all data structures to disk in the Compressed\n\t\t      Column Storage format.\n\n<p> The application does not have English parsing or\npart-of-speech tagging facilities or complete documentation\n	Intermediate

4645	LinkGrammar	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/LinkGrammar		Syntactic parser for the English language	The Link Grammar Parser is a syntactic parser of\nEnglish, based on link grammar, an original theory of English\nsyntax. The system assigns to a sentence a syntactic structure, which\nconsists of a set of labeled links connecting pairs of words. The\nparser also produces a "constituent" representation of a sentence\n(showing noun phrases, verb phrases, etc.).\n\n<P>The parser has a dictionary of about 60000 word forms. It covers a\nrange of syntactic constructions, including many rare and idiomatic\nones. The parser skips over the portions of the sentence that it\ncannot understand, and assigns some structure to the rest of the\nsentence. It can handle unknown vocabulary, and makes intelligent\nguesses from context and spelling about the syntactic categories of\nunknown words. It understands capitalization, numerical expressions,\nand various punctuation symbols.\n	Intermediate
4646	LinkChecker	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/LinkChecker	http://linkchecker.sourceforge.net/	Checks for broken links	With LinkChecker, you can check HTML documents for\nbroken links. It features recursion, robots.txt exclusion protocol\nsupport, HTTP proxy support, i18n support, multithreading, regular\nexpression filtering rules for links, and user/password checking for\nauthorized pages. Output can be colored or normal text, HTML, SQL,\nCSV, or a sitemap graph in GML or XML format. Supported link types are\nHTTP/1.1 and 1.0, HTTPS, FTP, mailto:, news:, nntp:, Gopher, Telnet,\nand local files. LinkChecker does not run with Python 2.2b2 due to a\nregex bug in Python!\n

It can check an entire site, or just\nsubdirectories. It flags pages that are particularly slow to\ndownload. 4655	LibSysCtr	2010-05-03 16:09:26	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/LibSysCtr	http://www.xmailserver.org/sysctr-lib.html	GNU/Linux system call tracing library	LibSysCTr intercepts system call functions on a\nGNU/Linux system. Process monitoring and sandboxing are just two of\nits potential uses. LibSysCTr uses the ptrace(2) functionalities by\nmonitoring and reporting events to the library caller. LibSysCTr is\ncallback driven, which means the user initializes the library with\nsystr_init_library(), registers the system calls he wants to monitor\nwith systr_trace_syscall(), and calls systr_run() to start receiving\nevents in the form of callback invocation.\n\n<P>For each intercepted system call, two calls to the registered\ncallback function are performed: one during the system call entry,\nbefore the system call iteself will be executed by the kernel, and one\nafter the kernel has processed the system call (right before returning\nthe userspace). Utility functions are supplied to, retrieve\ninformation about the process, get/set the system call parameters, and\nread/write the monitored process address space.\n

4666	LavaPS	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/LavaPS	http://www.isi.edu/~johnh/SOFTWARE/LAVAPS/index.html	Interactive process-tracking program	'LavaPS' is an interactive process-tracking\nprogram that presents a small amount of important information in a\ngraphical analog form (as opposed to lots of information presented\ndigitally). It runs in the background and quickly and simply gives you\na rough idea of what's happening.\n\n<P>Each blob represents a process. Blob size is proportional to memory\nusage, and movement is proportional to CPU usage. Color is a\ncombination of program name (which decided the hue) and time since the\nprogram last ran (which decides saturation): things that haven't run\nin a while are stationary and dark, while things that run a lot are\nbright and moving. A popup box gives more information about a\nprocess. Clicking the left button brings up the popup, the right\nbutton brings up a control menu.\n

4693	Keystone	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Keystone	http://www.indexdata.dk/keystone/	Digital library suite	The Keystone Digital Library Suite is a family of\ndigital content management, portal management and information\ndiscovery software packaged together to provide state-of-the-art\ndigital library services. There is one type\nof interface and one look-and-feel for all administration services and\nmetadata creation throughout the suite.\n\n<P>The two components of the suite are the Keystone Organizer and the\nKeystone Retriever. Back end communication program can be created\nusing very little memory on the target device.\n

Because Jam\nunderstands C/C++ dependencies, you need not declare header or object\nfiles. The built-in Jam rule "Main" handles header file dependencies\nand object files both automatically and on-the-fly.\n\n<P>Before any targets are updated, Jam gathers complete dependency\ninformation for C/C++ source files. This lets Jam build as much as\npossible, instead of stopping on the first build error, avoid building\ntargets if targets on which they depend fail to build, and build\nacross parallel paths with multiple, concurrent processes.\n

4746	Io	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Io	http://www.iolanguage.com/	Small, prototype-based programming language	Io is a small prototype-based programming\nlanguage. The ideas in Io are mostly inspired by Smalltalk (all values\nare objects) and Act1, Self, and NewtonScript (actors and futures,\ndifferential protos, inheritance by delegation).\n<pre>\nFeatures:\n-  small (~12K lines)\n-  pure object language\n-  reasonably fast (comparable to Python, Perl, Ruby)\n-  differential prototype-based object model\n-  untyped\n-  incremental garbage collection\n-  exceptions\n-  ANSI C implementation (except for inline directive)\n-  embeddable\n-  multi-state (multiple independent VMs can run in the same application)\n-  coroutines (light wieght threads)\n</pre>\n

4784	Hping	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Hping	http://www.hping.org/	Sends custom packets and displays target replies	'Hping' sends custom ICMP/UDP/TCP packets and\ndisplays target replies. It handles fragmentation and arbitrary packet\nbody and size, and can be used to transfer files under supported\nprotocols. \n\n<P>With 'Hping', you can test firewall rules, perform [spoofed] port\nscanning, test net performance using different protocols, packet size,\nTOS (type of service), and fragmentation, do path MTU discovery,\ntranfer files (even between really Fascist firewall rules), perform\ntraceroute-like actions under different protocols, fingerprint remote\nOSs, and audit a TCP/IP stack.\n	
4785	Hotwire	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Hotwire	http://submind.verbum.org/hotwire/wiki	Hotwire is intended to replace the interactive command execution portion of a typical Unix shell.	It includes much of the functionality found in the combination of a terminal emulator, a shell, and core utilities like ls and grep. Most of the commands are named the same, and do basically the same thing. Where it makes sense, Hotwire improves the commands to have better defaults and makes things nicer by using the mouse, and so on. For example, rm moves files to ~/.Trash on Unix and Recycle Bin on Windows, cd automatically lists the contents of the directory you change to, ls links are clickable (view file or cd to directory), filter (analogous to Unix grep) shows matching text in bold, and the ps process list has right-click menu for killing.

It is useful for downloading an entire Web site or certain\nfiles from a Web site to the hard disk for offline browsing later. 4796	Harminv	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Harminv	http://ab-initio.mit.edu/harminv/	Extracts frequencies and decay rates from a time series	Harminv is a program (and accompanying library) to\nsolve the problem of harmonic inversion. Given a discrete-time,\nfinite-length signal that consists of a sum of finitely-many sinusoids\n(possibly exponentially decaying) in a given bandwidth, it determines\nthe frequencies, decay constants, amplitudes, and phases of those\nsinusoids.\n\n<P>Harminv can, in principle, provide much better accuracy than\nstraightforwardly extracting FFT peaks because it assumes a specific\nform for the signal. (Fourier transforms, in contrast, attempt to\nrepresent *any* data as a sum of sinusoidal components.) It is also\noften more robust than directly least-squares fitting the data (which\ncan have problematic convergence).  Harminv employs the "filter\ndiagonalization method" (FDM) of Mandelshtam and Taylor.\n	
4797	Hardware_Lister	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Hardware_Lister	http://ezix.org/software/lshw.html	Is a small tool to provide detailed information on the hardware configuration of the machine.	lshw can report exact memory configuration, firmware version, mainboard configuration, CPU version and speed, cache configuration, bus speed, etc. on DMI-capable x86 or EFI (IA-64) systems and on some PowerPC machines (PowerMac G4 is known to work).<BR>\nInformation can be output in plain text, XML or HTML.<BR>\nIt currently supports DMI (x86 and EFI only), OpenFirmware device tree (PowerPC only), PCI/AGP, ISA PnP (x86), CPUID (x86), IDE/ATA/ATAPI, PCMCIA (only tested on x86), USB and SCSI.\n

4851	GiNaC	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/GiNaC	http://www.ginac.de/	Open framework for symbolic computation within C++	GiNaC is an acronym for GiNaC Is Not A CAS, where\nCAS stands for Computer Algebra System. It lets the user create\nintegrated systems that embed symbolic manipulations together with\nmore established areas of computers sciences under one roof.\n\nIt has been specifically developed to become a replacement engine for\nxloops. However, it is not restricted to high energy physics\napplications. Its design is revolutionary in that contrary to other\nCAS it does not try to provide extensive algebraic capabilities and a\nsimple programming language but instead accepts a given language (C++)\nand extends it by a set of algebraic capabilities.

4859	Geiriadur	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Geiriadur	http://www.cymraeg.ru/geiriadur	Dictionary lookup engine and a dictionary editing system	'Geiriadur' combines a dictionary lookup engine\nand a dictionary editing system. It's developed as a tool to create\nWelsh-Russian and Russian-Welsh dictionaries, but it can also be used\nfor other languages. It consists of two components: a dictionary CORBA\nserver and the Web interface for it.\n\n<P>The system works through "words" and "translations".  A\n"translation" is a pair of words or a word with explanation; a "word"\nmeans a string of letters without a space, possessing independent\nmeaning in some language. Words can have transcription, attributes\n(gender, aspect etc.), and "stems" and irregular forms. Regular forms\nare produced dynamically during a search from "stems" and "endings".\n\n<P>The system understands mutations and different spellings (American\nEnglish, Middle Welsh etc.) If a direct search (with the first word in\ntranslations table) yields no results, the system performs an inverse\nsearch or asks the user to try a cross-search through a third language.\n

4896	GMM	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/GMM	http://www.xmailserver.org/gmm.html	Guarded Memory Move	The Guarded Memory Move tool is useful for\nstudying buffer overflows and catching them together with a "good"\nstack image. Once a stack overflow has been exploited, the back trace\nis already gone, as is information about parameters and local\nvariables that are very important in understanding how the attacker is\nworking out the exploit.\n\n<P>The GMM library uses dynamic function call interception to catch\nthe most common functions that attackers use to exploit stack\nbuffers. It uses the LD_PRELOAD capability and offers two services:\nfirst, it avoids buffer overflow to allow the attacker to execute\nshell-code on your machine. Second, where an exploit is detected, it\nsaves the stack content and triggers a segmentation fault. The\nresulting core dump has the necessary information to debug the exploit\nand fix the software.\n

4899	GLE	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/GLE	http://linas.org/gle/	C functions that draw extruded surfaces	'GLE' is a package of C functions that draw\nextruded surfaces, including surfaces of revolution, sweeps, tubes,\npolycones, polycylinders and helicoids. The extruded surface is\nspecified with a 2D polyline that is extruded along a 3D path. A local\ncoordinate system allows for additional flexibility in the primitives\ndrawn. Extrusions may be texture mapped in a variety of ways. \n\n<P>The GLE library generates 3D triangle coordinates, lighting normal\nvectors and texture coordinates as output. It uses the GL or OpenGL\nAPI's to perform the actual rendering.\n	
4900	GL2PS	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/GL2PS	http://geuz.org/gl2ps/	OpenGL to PostScript printing library	'GL2PS' is a C library providing high quality\nvector output for any OpenGL application. The main difference between\nGL2PS and other similar libraries is the use of sorting algorithms\ncapable of handling intersecting and stretched polygons, as well as\nnon manifold objects. GL2PS provides advanced smooth shading and text\nrendering, culling of invisible primitives, mixed vector/bitmap\noutput, and much more.\n\n GL2PS can currently create PostScript (PS), Encapsulated\nPostScript (EPS) and Portable Document Format (PDF) files, as well as\nLaTeX files for the text fragments.\n

4913	GAUL	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/GAUL	http://gaul.sourceforge.net/	Library for programming applications using genetic algorithms	The Genetic Algorithm Utility Library (GAUL) is a\nprogramming library designed to assist in the development of code\nrequiring genetic algorithms. Standard mutation,\ncrossover and selection operators are provided, while code hooks\nadditionally allow custom operators. \n\n<P>It provides data structures and functions for handling and\nmanipulation of the data required for a genetic algorithm. 4919	FunctionCheck	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/FunctionCheck	http://www.highlandsun.com/hyc/	Profile generator for C/C++ programs	FunctionCheck is a profile generator for C/C++\nprograms. It uses the gcc '-finstrument-functions' feature to track\neach function entry and exit. It computes local and total times in\nfunctions, the number of calls, the average time per call, and\nfunction calls. It can also count time spent in sub-functions not\ncompiled with '-finstrument-functions'. The time balance between\nfunctions is always respected. It also can trace memory allocations\nand report on memory leaks, showing the call stack leading up to the\nallocation of the leaked blocks.\n	
4920	Funct	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Funct	http://sourceforge.net/projects/funct/	Stores and modifies mathematical functions	'Funct' lets users create and edit as many\nfunctions as they need and then quickly and easily apply them to any\nnumber they need to. It can be usefule for many different groups such\nas mathematicians, programmers, digital artists, musicians, etc.\n\n<P>Funct's 2 main goals are to be accesible to everyone and to be easy\nto use. The former derives from the fact that (almost) anybody needs\nto do this task and everyone should have an easy way to do it. The\nlatter derives from the fact that if starting the program, telling it\nthe number and function name and waiting for an answer takes longer\nthan applying the function in your head, then it's not worth the\nbother of using the program.\n

It is meant as an API for the most common video\neffects: simple filters or sources that can be controlled by\nparameters, and to solve recurring reimplementation or adaptation\nissue of standard effects. It is not meant as a generic API for all\nkinds of video applications, nor as a competing standard to more\nambitious efforts. There is no support for special areas like non\nlinear editors, hardware accelerated shader effects, and high\nprecision video processing.\n\n<P>Current effects include Invert0r (inverts the colors of the input),\npreDistort0r (distorts an image in an oldschool plasma way), preFlippo\n(flips the image in x/y planes), TehRoxx0r (a video wall-like effect),\nBw0r (turns images black and white), and Pixeliz0r (computes average\ncolors of blocks and writes them to output frame).\n

4961	FSP	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/FSP	http://fsp.sourceforge.net/	UDP-based protocol for file transfers	FSP is a UDP-based protocol for transferring\nfiles. It has many benefits over FTP, mainly for running anonymous\narchives. It is usable on lines with high packet loss ratio (70%\nWiFi), can go behind firewalls and unnoticed by port scans (because of\nUDP), does not overload networks when hosting ISOs or movies, share\nfiles on modem lines without eating all of the bandwidth, and keeps\nlamers away from your site (they don't know how to get to it). \n\n<P>This project is an active continuation of the FSP code base (abandoned\nfor the last 5 years).\n	
4962	FRT	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/FRT	http://frt.sourceforge.net/	Toolkit for 3D animations using low-end machines	FRT is a toolkit for the generation of 3D\nanimations using low-end machines (slow CPUs, low memory and small\nharddisks); of course, you can still use it with higher-end machines.\nThe program is simple; the whole library is about 1000 lines of\ncode. FRT has been designed with a *NIX-like operating system in mind:\nto avoid filling the harddisk, FRT establishes a master/slave\nrelationship with mpeg_encode and renders frames on demand.\n

4964	FOX	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/FOX	http://www.fox-toolkit.org	Toolkit for GUI development	FOX is a C++-based toolkit for GUI development. FOX incorporates support for XDND for drag\nand drop, X clipboard and X Selection, watching other I/O channels and\nsockets, timers and idle processing, object serialization and\ndeserialization, a registry to save persistent settings, and 3D\nwidgets using Mesa or OpenGL.\n\nFOX emphasizes speed, and minimizes memory use by letting programmers\ncreate and destroy GUI elements on the fly. Widgets can connect to\neach other and pass certain commands between them, which also reduces\nthe amount of code needed. Finally, GUI elements automatically update\nthemselves by interrogating the application's state, so it is easy to\nmaintain the state of the GUI in an application.

4966	FFPF	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/FFPF	http://ffpf.sourceforge.net/	Packet filter specifically designed for speed	The fairly fast packet filter (FFPF) adds many new\nfeatures to existing filtering solutions. It is designed for high\nspeed by pushing computationally intensive tasks to the kernel or to\nnetwork processors, and by minimising packet copying. Also, since it\nprovides a richer programming language and explicit extensibility, it\nis more flexible than existing approaches. Using its extensibility,\nthe language can even be used as a meta- filter to "script" together\nfilters from other approaches.\n

4980	Engauge	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Engauge	http://digitizer.sourceforge.net/	Converts an image file showing a graph or map, into numbers	'Engauge' converts an image file showing a graph\nor map into numbers. The process starts with an image\nfile containing a graph or map; The final result is digitized data\nthat can be used by other tools such as Gnumeric.  \n\n<P>Its features include automatic grid line removal, point matching,\nand curve tracing; the ability to handle cartesian, polar, linear and\nlogarithmic graphs; image processing that highlights data by removing\ngrid lines and backgrounds; context sensitive help; and preview\nwindows that give immediate feedback while modifying various settings.\n	
4981	Enblend	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/Enblend	http://enblend.sourceforge.net/	Smooths out seams in panoramic images	'Enblend' is a postprocessing tool for creating\npanoramic images. After you align image features, there are often\nphotometric problems that lead to ugly seams in the final\ncomposite. Enblend blends away these seams using a multiresolution\nspline. \n\n<P>'Enblend' blends different image features across a transition zone\nproportional to the spatial frequency of the features. Big, smooth\nobjects (sky, clouds) have low spatial frequency and should be blended\nacross a very wide region (we expect the sky to be uniform in\nappearance, so sudden color changes are very noticeable). Images with\nhigh spatial frequency (trees, windowpanes) have sudden changes from\nlight to dark. We expect to see color changes here; if you blend over\na wide area there is the possibility of noticeable ghosting. So\nhigh-frequency components are blended across a narrow transition zone.\n

It takes an EmPy source file, processes it, and\nproduces output. This is done via expansions, which are special\nsignals to the EmPy system and are set off by a special prefix. It can\nexpand arbitrary Python expressions and statements in this way, as\nwell as a variety of special forms.\n\n<P>Textual data not explicitly delimited in this way is sent\nunaffected to the output, so Python can be used as a markup\nlanguage. 4988	ElectricFence	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/ElectricFence	http://perens.com/FreeSoftware/	Memory debugger	Electric Fence (efence) stops your program on the\nexact instruction that overruns (or underruns) a malloc() memory\nbuffer. GDB will then display the source-code line that causes the\nbug. It works by using the virtual-memory hardware to create a\nred-zone at the border of each buffer - touch that, and your program\nstops. Catch all of those formerly impossible-to-catch overrun bugs\nthat have been bothering you for years.\n

5000	EPrints	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/EPrints	http://www.eprints.org/	Online information archiving system	EPrints is an online archiving system. Documents\nare stored in any format as well as in more than one document\nformat. The archive can handle related fields; the administrator\ndecides what fields to use for each document. Users can also view and\nsearch the archive through a configurable, extendable subject\nhierarchy . The software automatically performs data integrity\nchecks. Some "stub" routines let individual sites add their own\nintegrity checks.\n\n<P>Documents are submitted through a Web-based interface, and uploaded\nas files, in a compressed bundled file (such as a .zip file), or\nautomatically mirrored from another site by specifying a URL. Users\nsubscribe either as authors or readers, via the Web or email. Authors\nhave associated metadata. Submitted papers are entered directly or\nthrough a moderation process. This is done through the Web, as is most\nnormal maintenance.\n	
5001	EPM	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/EPM	 http://www.epmhome.org/	Generates software and patch distributions	The ESP Package Manager (EPM) is a simple tool\nthat generates software and patch distributions in various formats,\nincluding AT&T software packages ("pkg") used by Solaris, Debian\n("dpkg"), HP-UX software packages ("swinstall" or "depot"), IRIX\nSoftware Manager ("inst" or "tardist"), portable (installation and\nremoval scripts with tar files), and Red Hat Package Manager ("RPM").\n	
5002	EPICS	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/EPICS	http://www.aps.anl.gov/epics/	Distributed Process Control Tool Kit Components	'EPICS' is a software infrastructure for \nbuilding distributed control systems to operate devices such as\nparticle accelerators, large experiments and major telescopes. These\nsystems comprise tens or hundreds of computers, networked together so\nthey can communicate and provide control and feedback of the various\nparts from a control room, or remotely over the Internet.\n\n<P>EPICS uses Client/Server and Publish/Subscribe techniques to\ncommunicate between the various computers. Most servers (called\nInput/Output Controllers or IOCs) perform real-world I/O and local\ncontrol tasks, and publish this information to clients using the\nChannel Access (CA) network protocol. CA is specially designed for the\nkind of high bandwidth, soft real-time networking applications that\nEPICS is used for, and is one reason why it can be used to build a\ncontrol system comprising hundreds of computers.\n

5012	E	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/E	http://www4.informatik.tu-muenchen.de/~schulz/WORK/eprover.html	Automated theorem prover	E is an equational theorem prover. You give it a\nmathematical specification (in clausal logic with equality) and a\nhypothesis; it will then try to find a proof for the hypothesis (and\nsometimes succeed).\n\n E is build on top of (and by now inseparable from) CLIB, a\ncollection of library functions for building programs the follow the\nbasic input-processing-output paradigm, with additional support for\nmost levels of first-order logic. The code has been used to build a\ncouple of other applications by now.\n\n<p> CLIB is layered, with higher layers becoming more\nspecialized. Lower levels take care of the scientifically\nuninteresting, but necessary services for production-quality efficient\nprograms, e.g. error handling, memory management, parsing of input,\netc. They should be useful for most programs. Higher level modules\nimplement shared and unshared terms, equations, clauses and related\nstuff.\n

5015	DynamicProbes	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/DynamicProbes	http://www-124.ibm.com/linux/projects/dprobes/	Debugger	Dynamic Probes (Dprobes) is a generic and\npervasive system debugging facility that will operate under the most\nextreme software conditions such as debugging a deep-rooted operating\nsystem problem in a live environment. \n\nDprobes allows the insertion of fully automated breakpoints or\nprobepoints anywhere in the system and user space. Each probepoint has\nan associated set of probe instructions that are interpreted when the\nprobe fires. These instructions allow memory and CPU registers to be\nexamined and altered using conditional logic. When the probe command\nterminates, prior to returning to the probed code, a syslog record may\nbe optionally generated.

'DrIFT' automates instance derivation for classes that\naren't supported by the standard compilers.\n\n<P>In addition, instances can be produced in separate modules to that\ncontaining the type declaration. This lets instances be derived for a\ntype after the original module has been compiled. Simple utility\nfunctions can also be produced from a type.\n

5020	DrQueue	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/DrQueue	http://www.drqueue.org/	Distributed rendering queue	Drqueue is a distributed rendering queue. It\nmanages jobs on a renderfarm. It supports Maya, Blender, and Bmrt\n(Renderman) out of the box, and can support any other renderer or\ncomputing task that can be handled via scripting.\n\n<P>The package has three tools: master, slave and drqman. The master\nacts as a server where tasks are stored and where computers running\nslaves report success or failure in executing tasks. The slaves run on\nevery node of the renderfarm. They report load average; if it is below\na set level, they are available for rendering and take the first task\nassigned by the master server. drqman is a GUI for controlling jobs\nand computers. \n

5046	DansTuner	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/DansTuner	http://danstuner.sourceforge.net/	Tells you if you are playing a pitch in tune	'DansTuner' tells you if you are playing a pitch\nin tune. Its features include:\n<pre>\n      *automatic discovery of which note you are trying to play (good for\n           trumpet, singer, etc.)\n      *ability to play a guide tone for you at a configurable volume\n      *a graphical moving "needle", a red/green display, and details about how\n           flat or sharp you are\n      *an easily configurable background noise threshold\n</pre>\n\n<P>This package was written by a trumpet player, who needed to tune\nlots of different notes on the fly. Many of the free packages out\nthere are "guitar" tuners that must first be told which few notes you\nare trying to tune.\n	
5047	DadaMail	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/DadaMail	http://mojo.skazat.com	Lightweight mailing list manager	DadaMail is a lightweight email mailing list\nmanager. It supports announce-only lists and group discussion lists,\narchiving, double opt-in subscriptions, and double opt-out\nunsubscriptions. It can send list mailings using sendmail, qmail, or\neven with a straight SMTP connection (either all at once, or in timed\nbatches).\n\nList administration is done through a browser via DadaMail's\nadministrative control panel. DadaMail is an alternative to programs\nsuch as Majordomo if you want to give more control to the actual list\nowners, who may not have much experience with such applications. The\nprogram can be run simply as a CGI script and needs no special\nmodules installed. The html pages that DadaMail creates can be\ncustomized on a list by list basis with any template you provide.\n\n<P>This package was formerly known as 'MojoMail.'\n	
5048	DUlog	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/DUlog	http://public.planetmirror.com/pub/dulog/	New log notifier and parser	DULog is a new log notifier and parser that periodically tails system logs, parses the output to present it in an easily readable format (parsing modules currently exist only for GNU/Linux), and mails a final report to the administrator. It can run daily or hourly.\nDULog is written specifically for large clusters where many systems (50+) log to a single loghost using syslog or syslog-ng. It can be used on standalone systems, but other packages (ie logwatch) are probably more suitable for such purposes.	
5049	DSPAM	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/DSPAM	http://www.nuclearelephant.com/projects/dspam/	Server-side anti-spam agent	DSPAM is a server-side anti-spam agent for UNIX\nemail servers. It masquerades as the email server's local delivery\nagent and filters/learns SPAM using a Bayesian statistical approach\nwhich provides an administratively maintenance-free, self-learning\nanti-spam service.\n\n<P>Each email is broken down into its most interesting tokens, each\nassigned a spam probability. All probabilities are then combined to\nproduce a statistical probability of spam. This approach, applied to a\nmature corpus of email, has the potential to yield a 99.5% success\nrate with only 0.03% chance of false positives.\n

5055	DIBS	2010-05-03 16:09:27	221	http://directory.fsf.org/project/DIBS	http://sourceforge.net/projects/dibs	Backup system	DIBS is a backup system that protects your data by\ngiving your files to peers (and in return, you store their files) so\nthat if a catastrophe strikes your area, you can recover data from\nsurviving peers. This solves the problem of mirroring your data by\nadding more disks to your own computer only ot have a fire, flood,\npower surge, etc. wiping out your local data center. \n\n<P>Note that DIBS is a backup system, *not* a file sharing system like\nNapster, Gnutella, Kazaa, etc. In fact, DIBS encrypts all data\ntransmissions so that the peers you trade files with can not access\nyour data.\n

An extended BNF syntax lets users define\nnew domain-specific languages or parse existing formats, and a\ntemplate-based syntax lets users write patterns for generating\ncode.
